PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Douglas McClelland) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

We, the undersigned citizens of Australia, being concerned that the Australian Government, in breach of its own stated policies, has lifted the bans on the sale of uranium to France; demand that the Government re-impose the bans on such sales, and further, that the Government ratifies and strengthens the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty to prohibit uranium sales within the region.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate, of the Parliament of Australia assembled. We, the undersigned, plead that Parliament will re-invoke the blasphemy, indecency, and obscenity proscriptions into the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations, by adding those proscriptions to the present Section 4a, sub-regulation 1a (b) (i), for the following reasons:
because there is a flood of obscene publications into the country
because such publications depict the abnormal as normal
because such publications degrade men and women
because such publications create new, offensive demands on women, with which they do not willingly comply (Eysenok and Nias)
because this causes marriage breakdown
because children easily obtain such publications
because children copy what they see

because the child found in possession of such publications is at risk, facing rejection, and carrying the burden of having altered the relationships in his home for the worse, between parents, and between parent and child
because such a child faces, alone, the loss of trust
because I am a reasonable adult person and I am offended by the obscene books which you have legislated into this community.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you will give this matter your earnest attention.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Foreign Military and Intelligence Facilities in Australia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that:

1. The Watsonia Army Barracks contains electronic communication facilities, operated by Australian and American personnel, that gives the United States the ability to pin-point Soviet nuclear submarines, hidden in the Oceans.

2. This would make it possible for U.S. killer-submarines to destroy all Soviet nuclear submarines, while the U.S. nuclear submarines launch their missiles in a ``first strike'' attack. This makes Watsonia a potential nuclear target. A nuclear attack on Watsonia would have a disastrous effect on Melbourne.
3. The `joint U.S.-Australian' bases in Australia endanger rather than protect us. They also add a new menace to nuclear arms race, that must be stopped.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament should close the `joint Australian-U.S.' electronic communication facilities in the Watsonia Army Barracks.

PETITION.TITLE: Pine Gap Defence Space Research Facility
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned shows:

(1) The Agreement between the United States of America and Australia concerning the Joint Defence Space Research Facility at Pine Gap may be terminated by either Government on one year's notice from 19 October 1986.
(2) In the event of war between the United States and the Soviet Union, access by the United States to Pine Gap's facilities makes it a probable nuclear target.
(3) Access by all nations to Pine Gap's capacity to monitor and verify compliance with existing and future nuclear limitations treaties could contribute to world peace and security.
(4) The people of Australia are entitled to be consulted, through their representatives in Parliament, on any extension or modification of the Agreement affecting their lives, security and welfare.
And your petitioners humbly pray that:
(1) The Agreement between the United States and Australia concerning the Joint Defence Space Research Facility at Pine Gap be terminated one year from October 19 1986.

(2) Public discussion and inquiry be instituted into the feasibility of negotiating a new agreement with the United Nations during the International Year of Peace offering the verification facilities of the Pine Gap base to all nations.
(3) Any agreement concerning the future use of Pine Gap be referred to Parliament for ratification.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

DEBATE.TITLE: INCOME TAX RATES BILL 1986INCOME TAX BILL 1986TAXATION LAWS (MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS) BILL 1986MEDICARE LEVY BILL 1986

Second Readings

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bills be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate the second reading speeches in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speeches read as follows-
INCOME TAX RATES BILL 1986
This Bill will declare the rates of income tax payable by individuals and trustees generally for the 1986-87 financial year and for the 1987-88 and subsequent years.

In so doing, the Bill will give effect to the significant personal tax cuts announced as part of the September 1985 tax reform package, and their introduction from 1 December 1986 as announced by the Treasurer in his Budget Speech.
The tax cuts are to be reflected in lower pay-as-you-earn deductions from 1 December 1986.
Another tax reform measure to be implemented by this Bill will allow the tax-free threshold only on a pro rata basis in certain circumstances.

The Bill will also declare the rates of income tax for 1986-87 payable on the 1985-86 incomes of companies, registered organisations and unit trusts treated as companies for tax purposes, as well as on the current year incomes of superannuation funds and certain other trusts.

As announced in the September 1985 tax reform statement, the company tax rate is to be increased to 49 per cent in 1987-88 to help defray the cost of the new imputation system that is to apply from the commencement of that year.

Legislation to declare that higher rate for 1987-88 and subsequent years, which will also be payable by trustees assessed in respect of trust income of non-resident company beneficiaries in 1986-87 and subsequent years, will be introduced later in these sittings.
Accordingly, the rate of tax declared by this Bill for 1986-87 for companies and the other bodies taxed as companies will remain at 46 per cent.

However, lower rates are to be declared by this Bill on the relevant income of some superannuation funds and on ineligible approved deposit funds as a consequence of the reductions in personal income tax rates.
A further lowering of these rates, reflecting the second stage of the personal income tax cuts, will be contained in the later legislation to which I have just referred.
I turn now in more detail to the personal income tax rate measures contained in this Bill.

The personal income tax burden will be substantially reduced by an increase in the tax-free threshold from $4,595 to $5,100, and by a reduction of all marginal rates of tax, with major reductions in those rates applying at average and higher earnings.
The reform of the rate scales will be in two stages. With effect from 1 December 1986 a five step scale will apply and from 1 July 1987 this will reduce to a four step scale.

From 1 December 1986 the existing 25 per cent rate on income to $12,500 will be reduced to 24 per cent and the threshold level will increase to $12,600. The 30 per cent rate will reduce to 29 per cent and the next two rates of 46 per cent and 48 per cent will reduce to 43 per cent and 46 per cent respectively. There will be a significant drop in the highest marginal rate applied to incomes above $35,000 from 60 per cent to 55 per cent.

From 1 July 1987 the marginal rates applying to income in the ranges $19,501 to $28,000 and $28,001 to $35,000 will both be reduced to 40 per cent, and the top marginal rate will drop from 55 per cent to 49 per cent.
These changes to the rate scale will be reflected in the rate payable by non-residents.

Because of the commencement date part-way into the 1986-87 financial year, the rate scale for that year is to be an average of the 1985-86 rate scale and the scale to apply from 1 December 1986-made up of five-twelfths of the 1985-86 scale and seven-twelfths of the new scale.
The average rate scale will mean a tax-free threshold of $4,890 for 1986-87 with the rate of tax on incomes to $12,500 being 24.42 per cent.

A rate of 26.5 per cent will apply in the income range $12,501 to $12,600, 29.42 per cent in the range $12,601 to $19,500 while for taxable incomes in the range $19,501 to $28,000 and $28,001 to $35,000 the rates will be 44.25 per cent and 46.83 per cent respectively.
The maximum marginal rate applying to income over $35,000 will be 57.08 per cent.
An adjustment is to be made to the maximum rate of tax on the unearned income of minors for 1986-87 to reduce the 60 per cent rate now applying to income over $35,000 to 57.08 per cent.
For 1987-88 and subsequent years a flat rate of 49 per cent will apply to all unearned income of minors, subject to shading-in arrangements for such income just over $416.
The rate of tax on trustees assessed under section 99a of the Income Tax Assessment Act will be 57.08 per cent for 1986-87 and 49 per cent in 1987-88 and subsequent years.
I referred earlier to the adjustment in certain circumstances of the level of the tax-free threshold.

In 1986-87 and subsequent years, this threshold will be available only on a pro-rated basis in the year of income in which a person first ceases full-time education at a school, college, university or similar institution.

The adjusted threshold level will be the proportion of the full threshold that reflects the number of whole months in the year when the person was not engaged in full-time education, including the month in which such education ceased.

Where income is derived in the part of the year before the person ceases education, the adjusted threshold level will be increased by the lesser of the amount of that income or the balance of the full year threshold.
The tax-free threshold will also be available only on a proportionate basis where a person becomes, or ceases to be, a resident of Australia in a year of income.
This measure will not affect the present treatment of non-residents receiving Australian social security pensions and repatriation pensions that are taxable in Australia.
The provisions of the Bill are explained in detail in a memorandum that is being made available to honourable senators.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
INCOME TAX BILL 1986
This Bill will formally impose income tax for the 1986-87 financial year at the rates declared by the Income Tax Rates Bill 1986 that I have just introduced.

As explained in my second reading speech on that Bill, the rates imposed on individuals, and trustees generally, reflect the significant cuts in personal income tax that were announced in the September 1985 tax reform package and are to apply with effect from 1 December 1986.

No change is proposed for the 1986-87 financial year in the rates of tax, which will also be imposed by this Bill, on companies, registered organisations and unit trusts treated as companies for tax purposes.
However, for certain superannuation funds and for ineligible approved deposit funds the tax rates will be lowered.

This Bill will also formally impose provisional tax payable for 1986-87, and authorise the collection of instalments of tax payable by companies and unit trusts treated as companies on income of 1986-87 year of income.
Details of the various rates are set out in the explanatory memorandum that is being made available to honourable senators.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
TAXATION LAWS (MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS) BILL 1986
This Bill will amend various taxation Acts, mainly as a consequence of the reforms to be made to the personal income tax rate scale by the Income Tax Rates Bill 1986.
The Bill will also give effect to some 1986-87 Budget proposals.

It will amend the Income Tax Assessment Act to increase the taxable income level, at or below which the maximum pensioner rebate of $250 is available, from $5,595 to $5,914 in 1986-87 and to $6,142 in 1987-88 and subsequent years.

The maximum levels of the beneficiary rebates will also be increased from $220 to $280 for married beneficiaries and from $170 to $190 for other beneficiaries. The income levels above which the rebates are to shade-out will also be increased.

In addition, the Bill will extend the benefit of the beneficiary rebates to recipients of benefits or payments under the Commonwealth's tertiary education assistance scheme and the adult secondary education assistance scheme.
The changes to the pensioner and beneficiary rebates are to take effect from the 1986-87 year.

Other amendments of the Income Tax Assessment Act will reduce the level of the rebates of tax available for net medical expenses in excess of $1,000, payments of home loan interest by a first home buyer and the assessable proceeds of certain life assurance policies.
These rebates will be allowed at the rate of 29.42 per cent for 1986-87 and 29 per cent for 1987-88 and subsequent years.

Also reflecting the changes in personal tax rates, another amendment proposed will adjust the method of calculating the amount of any rebate allowable where payments in consequence of a taxpayer's termination of employment are incurred in his or her assessable income.

Other Acts that are proposed to be amended by this Bill as a consequence of the new personal tax rates are the Income Tax (Bearer Debentures) Act 1971, the Income Tax (Mining Withholding Tax) Act 1979, the Trust Recoupment Tax Act 1985 and the Trust Recoupment Tax Assessment Act 1985.
Detailed explanations of the amendments to these Acts and others I have mentioned are contained in the explanatory memorandum which is being made available to honourable senators.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
MEDICARE LEVY BILL 1986
The Medicare Levy Bill 1986 will declare the basic rate of Medicare Levy for 1986-87 and, until the Parliament otherwise provides, for 1987-88.
As announced in the Budget, the basic rate of the levy is to be increased from 1 per cent to 1.25 per cent from 1 December 1986.
Consequently, a composite rate of 1.145 per cent will apply for the 1986-87 financial year.
The Bill also contains increases in the income threshold levels below which people with low incomes will not be called on to pay any levy.
For 1986-87, individuals with taxable incomes of $8,030 or less, and married couples and sole parents with family incomes of $13,370 or less, will be exempt from the levy.
The income threshold for married couples and sole parents will increase by a further $1,600 for each dependent child or student.
An explanation of the Bill is contained in the explanatory memorandum which is being made available to honourable senators.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1986 BANK ACCOUNT DEBITS TAX AMENDMENT BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bills received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Grimes) agreed to:

That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent the questions with regard to the several stages for the passage through the Senate of the Bills being put in one motion at each stage and the consideration of such Bills together in the Committee of the Whole.
Ordered that the Bills may be taken through all their stages without delay.
Bills (on motion by Senator Grimes) read a first time.
Second Readings

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bills be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speeches incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speeches read as follows-
TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1986
This Bill will amend the income tax law to give effect to several of the taxation measures announced in the 1986-87 Budget.

In that regard, it will vary in some respects the trading stock valuation arrangements relevant to horse breeders, restore the income tax exemption of the pay of defence force reservists and provide income tax deductions for certain gifts.

Other amendments contained in the Bill will authorise deductions in respect of cash bids for off-shore petroleum exploration permits, provide a more generous basis for the offsetting of profit on the disposal of animals under the brucellosis and tuberculosis eradication campaign and effect changes to the withholding tax on interest on overseas borrowings.
In addition, the Bill will amend the income tax law to provide for the calculation of 1986-87 provisional tax.
It will also give the force of law in Australia to a taxation agreement with Austria and a further protocol to the existing taxation agreement with the Netherlands.
Finally, some minor amendments of the income tax and other taxation laws are being effected.
Mr President, I will now outline in more detail the significant measures contained in the Bill.
Trading stock valuation of horses
The Bill will give effect to two 1986-87 Budget measures relating to the valuation of horses for income tax trading stock purposes.

Under the trading stock provisions of the law, live stock on hand at the end of a year may be valued, at the taxpayer's option, at cost price or market selling value or at such other value as circumstances may justify.

A taxpayer may bring natural increase in live stock to account at a cost price not less than prescribed amounts-$1 per head for sheep, $5 per head for cattle and horses and $4 per head for pigs-but substantially less than actual cost.
This allows tax to be deferred until the disposal of the natural increase.
The economic and rural policy statement of 15 April 1986 announced changes to the trading stock valuation arrangements for animal stud breeders generally.

However, reflecting the fact that the tax deferral advantages are generally much greater for horse breeders than for breeders of other animals, it was announced in the 1986-87 Budget that changes would be restricted to horse breeders and would apply only in respect of service fees.

Accordingly, the Bill will amend the law so that for trading stock purposes the cost price of a horse acquired by natural increase is not less than any service fee-whether for physical or artificial service-that is incurred after 19 August 1986 in acquiring the horse.
This is expected to result in a gain to revenue of $7m in 1988-89, with negligible gains in subsequent years.
The second of the 1986-87 Budget amendments under this heading relates to the special valuation option available to horse breeders in respect of sires and brood-mares.

Horse breeders may elect to write down the cost of sires and brood-mares at rates of 50 per cent and 33 1/3per cent respectively on a diminishing value basis or to write down the cost of mares over a minimum period of three years.
In relation to horses acquired after 19 August 1986, the Bill will limit this special option to horses that are aged 3 years or more.
This Amendment, which should have no revenue consequences, will ensure that, as intended, the concessional basis of valuation is available only in respect of breeding stock.
Pay of Defence Force reserve

This Bill will give effect to the Budget announcement to reinstate full taxation exemption of the pay and allowances of members of the Defence Force reserves and emergency reserves for service, other than continuous full time service, on or after 1 January 1987.
Full tax exemption will also be reinstated in respect of any gratuity paid to members of the emergency reserves by reason of a calling out for continuous service on or after 1 January 1987.
These changes are estimated to cost $5m in 1986-87 and $12m in a full year.
There will be an offsetting reduction to outlays of $8m in a full year associated with the discontinuance of the special reserve allowance.
Gifts

Another 1986-87 Budget measure to which the Bill gives effect will allow deductions for gifts of the value of $2 or more made after 19 August 1986 to the Australian Academy of Technological Sciences and to the Australian College of Occupational Medicine.
The estimated cost to revenue of this measure is nil for 1986-87 and less than $60,000 in a full year.
Cash bidding payments

The Bill will implement the proposal announced on 15 January 1986 to allow income tax deductions in respect of payments made to the Commonwealth under the cash bidding system introduced last year for the award of off-shore petroleum exploration permits in highly prospective areas.

This will ensure that Australian companies are not placed at a competitive disadvantage compared with foreign based companies entitled to income tax deduction for the payments in their home countries.

In cases where exploration leads to the development and production of petroleum, cash bids will be able to be written off on a straight line basis over the lesser of 10 years and the life of the producing field.
Write-off will commence in the income year in which a production licence is first acquired in respect of the relevant permit area.

In the event that the original cash bidder disposes of an interest in the permit area before the grant of a production licence, the original bidder may transfer to the purchaser an entitlement to deductions.
If no production licence is granted, or if the permit expires or is wholly surrendered, the amount of the cash bid will qualify as an eligible capital loss for capital gains tax purposes.
The cost to revenue of this proposal is estimated at $1m in the 1988-89 year, increasing to $1.5m in each subsequent year.
Mr President, the Government intends to extend income tax deductibility, on the basis just outlined, to cash bids paid under the Commonwealth Cash Bidding/Work Program system introduced in 1967.
Deductibility will also be extended to cash bids paid under systems in force in the States and the Northern Territory that are comparable to the Commonwealth systems.

In this regard, honourable senators would be aware that, in a joint statement of 16 September 1986, the Minister for Resources and Energy and the Victorian Minister for Industry, Technology and Resources announced the release of a petroleum exploration area straddling Commonwealth and Victorian jurisdictions.
The proposed extension of deductibility will ensure that cash bids paid in respect of that area qualify for income tax deductions.
The further necessary amendments will be introduced into the Parliament as soon as practicable and, like those contained in this Bill, will apply from 15 January 1986.
Profits from death or destruction of livestock

Amendments of the income tax law proposed by the Bill will vary the operation of an existing option available in respect of profits resulting from proceeds on the death or destruction of livestock because of bovine brucellosis or tuberculosis.
The proposal was announced in the economic and rural policy statement of 15 April 1986 and the variation will apply in respect of the death or destruction of livestock after 30 June 1986.

Under the existing law, the average profit per head on livestock that die or are destroyed because of certain diseases may be offset against the cost per head of replacement animals acquired during the year of death or destruction or during the next 5 years.

Mr President, the Government recognises that the replacement of animals lost because of bovine brucellosis or tuberculosis may take longer than 5 years and that a lost herd may be replaced by fewer, but more expensive animals.
The Bill will therefore broaden the basis on which relevant profits may be offset against the cost of replacement animals.
It will extend the period of offset by 5 years.

It will also provide for profits to be offset on a herd basis rather than on a per head basis-that is, the whole of the profits may be offset progressively against the total cost of replacement animals.
The amendments are not expected to have any significant effect on revenue.
Interest withholding tax exemptions

The exemption from interest withholding tax for interest payments on overseas borrowings by a State, or by a Commonwealth or State authority where the loan funds are not used in direct competition with the private sector, is to be withdrawn in relation to borrowings contracted for after 1 July 1986 in accordance with the Government decision announced on that day.
On 28 July 1986, the Treasurer indicated that it was Government policy that public authorities should face a similar environment in respect of borrowings as do private sector borrowers.

Consistent with this policy, the Bill proposes that the States and State and Commonwealth Authorities be exempted from withholding tax for interest payments on public or other widely spread issues of securities overseas in the same way as a resident company raising money for use in an Australian business.

The withdrawal of the interest withholding tax exemption for the States and authorities is to apply to borrowings contracted for after 1 July 1986 but will not affect interest payments made on or before the date on which the Bill receives royal assent.

Pending enactment, the States and authorities may continue to apply for exemption for overseas borrowings in relation to interest payments made on or before the date of royal assent. Thereafter they will be able to obtain exemption to the extent permitted by the amended provisions relating to public or other widely spread issues of securities overseas.
The Bill also proposes removal of the generally applicable conditions for that exemption that the loan be raised in a foreign currency and that interest be payable in a foreign currency.

Advocates of these changes have argued that the existing requirements impose unnecessary additional costs and impede the ability of Australian borrowers to raise off-shore funds in Australian currency and so reduce their foreign exchange exposure.
These amendments will apply to interest payments made after the Bill receives the royal assent.
A recent court decision has shown that roll-overs or extensions of loans contracted for some years ago remain able to benefit from the previous `Australian entity' interest withholding tax exemption.
This is an unintended result as the exemption was withdrawn to have general effect from June 1983.

Accordingly, the Bill proposes to preclude the exemption of interest paid on borrowings resulting from relevant loan roll-overs and loan extensions effected after 1 July 1986 or from the post-1 July 1986 drawing down of funds under a pre-existing loan facility where the borrower was not, before 2 July 1986, contractually bound to use that facility.
Corresponding provisions are proposed in relation to the withdrawal of the exemption for overseas borrowings by the States and by public authorities.

Similarly, another provision of the law which, until June 1983 provided exemption in relation to overseas borrowings by the Australian Industry Development Corporation, is to be amended to make clear that loan roll-overs and loan extensions do not preserve the former exemption.
Those measures will also apply in relation to interest payments made after the date of enactment of the Bill.
Anti-avoidance provisions will prevent the re-arrangement of interest payments to bring them into the period, prior to enactment, in which the relevant exemptions remain available.
Provisional Tax for 1986-87

As provisional tax is part of the pay as you earn system and is designed to collect tax on non salary or wage income within the year in which the income is derived, it is generally accepted that the amount of provisional tax charged should approximate as closely as practicable the amount of tax actually imposed for the year.

Incomes to which provisional tax applies are expected to increase in 1986-87 but, due to the proposed reductions in personal income tax rates from 1 December 1986, effective rates of tax for 1986-87 will be lower than for last year.
As in the past, it is proposed that the basis that would otherwise apply in the calculation of provisional tax be varied for the current year to take account of these two factors.
Accordingly, this Bill provides for 1986-87 provisional tax to be calculated on the basis of 1985-86 taxable income increased by 11 per cent and by applying the lower rates of tax for 1986-87.
Also reflected in the provisional tax calculation will be the proposed increased rate of 1.145 per cent at which the medicare levy is to be imposed for 1986-87.
The increased low income thresholds to apply for levy purposes in 1986-87 will be taken into account.
Generally, rebates and credits will be allowed in the provisional tax calculation at the levels allowed in 1985-86 assessments.
For Christmas Island residents, however, the rebate allowed in their 1985-86 assessments will be reduced by one-third in line with the arrangements for phasing-in personal income tax on the island.

Taxpayers who consider that their taxable income for 1986-87 will increase by less than 11 per cent, or who consider that their rebates will be at a higher level, will continue to have the right to `self-assess' and have the provisional tax for 1986-87 recalculated on the basis of their own estimates.
The Austrian comprehensive tax agreement

I now turn to provisions of the Bill that will provide legislative authority for the entry into force of a comprehensive double taxation agreement dealing with all forms of income flowing between Australia and Austria.
The agreement was signed on 8 July 1986, at which time details were announced and copies of the agreement were made publicly available.
It accords with the other comprehensive taxation agreements concluded by Australia in recent years.
The Bill will insert the text of the agreement into the Income Tax (International Agreements) Act 1953 as a schedule to that Act.
The agreement will not enter into force until all necessary constitutional processes are completed both by Australia and Austria.
The agreement is not expected to have any significant effect on the revenue.
Second Netherlands protocol
The Bill will provide legislative authority for the entry into force of a second protocol amending the existing comprehensive taxation agreement and protocol between Australia and the Netherlands.

The second protocol will enable the Netherlands to close an avenue for avoidance of its tax being exploited by Netherlands investors deriving interest from debt claims secured by mortgage over real property in Australia.
At present, Netherlands tax does not generally apply to such interest which is treated under the agreement as income from real property.
The protocol will treat the income in the same way as other interest is treated under the agreement.

This will allow the Netherlands to tax such interest from Australia in full, subject to the allowance of a credit for Australian tax paid on the interest, instead of the interest being generally free of Netherlands tax and subject only to Australian withholding tax of 10 per cent.

The tax treatment in Australia of interest flowing from Australia to the Netherlands will be unchanged-the gross amount of such interest will continue to be liable to Australian interest withholding tax of 10 per cent.
Mortgage interest derived by Australian residents from the Netherlands is presently exempt from tax in Australia if it is subject to Netherlands tax.
Under the protocol, such interest will be taxable in Australia, with a credit for the Netherlands tax, which is limited to a maximum of 10 per cent of the gross interest.

The protocol will generally have effect in Australia for years of income commencing on or after 1 July 1986 and, in the Netherlands, for taxable years and periods beginning on or after 1 January 1986.

Transitional entry into force arrangements will ensure that the protocol will not apply to interest paid under contractual obligations entered into before 30 June 1986, when the protocol was formally signed, until Australian years of income commencing on or after 1 July 1988 and Netherlands taxable years and periods beginning on or after 1 January 1988.
Appropriate anti-avoidance measures will safeguard the operation of the transitional arrangements.
The protocol will enter into force after the procedures necessary to give it the force of law in both countries are completed.
Minor amendments
The Bill will amend the income tax law to add the Secretary to the Department of Science as an authority to approve bodies as approved research institutes for income tax purposes.
It will also amend various taxation laws to reverse an unintentional alteration to the burden of proof provisions by the Taxation Boards of Review (Transfer of Jurisdiction) Act 1986.

Mr President, an explanatory memorandum which comprehensively explains the measures contained in the Bill, and in another Bill that I will introduce shortly, is being circulated for the information of honourable senators.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
BANK ACCOUNT DEBITS TAX AMENDMENT BILL 1986
This Bill will give effect to the 1986-87 Budget proposal to increase the general rates of bank account debits tax.

For cheque accounts kept with banks outside the Australian Capital Territory, including Jervis Bay, the highest rate of bank account debits tax will be increased from $1.50 to $2, with other rates being increased by up to one-half.
The increased rates will apply to debits made on or after 1 December 1986.

In view of the proposal announced in the Budget to introduce a financial institutions duty in the Australian Capital Territory from 1 July 1987, the rates of bank account debits tax presently applying in the Australian Capital Territory will remain unchanged.
Mr President, increasing the general rates of bank account debits tax is expected to raise additional revenue of $45m in 1986-87 and $90m in a full year.
The explanatory memorandum that has been circulated to honourable senators also explains the provisions of this Bill.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Messner) adjourned.

That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent Business of the Senate, Notice of Motion No. 1 standing in the name of Senator Macklin for the disallowance, two sitting days after today, of the guide to the assessment of rates of veterans' pensions, being called on prior to the consideration of Government Business this day.
Motion (by Senator Grimes) agreed to:
That, unless otherwise ordered, the order of General Business for consideration this day, pursuant to Sessional Order, be as follows:
(a) consideration of Government Papers; and
(b) General Business, Notice of Motion No. 242 standing in the name of Senator Watson relating to the fringe benefits and capital gains taxes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the guide to the assessment of rates of veterans' pensions, made under the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 and presented to the Senate on 2 June 1986, be disallowed.

The guide to the assessment of rates of veterans' pensions arises from the major changes that were made to repatriation legislation over the last year and a half. Honourable senators will remember the protracted debates in this chamber on that matter. Part of the negotiations that had a successful conclusion with the passage of the Veterans' Entitlements Bill in 1986 was agreement that the guide to the assessment of rates of veterans' pensions be treated in a way that would permit it to be disallowed. We wanted to be able to approach the guide as something to be disallowed or allowed by either House of the Parliament. During that whole debate on the veterans' entitlements legislation, and in particular the discussion surrounding the guide, I took the view that the Senate should look closely at the matter in considering disallowance to see whether it was in keeping with the legislation and in conformity with the intentions of the legislation as it passed through this chamber.

A whole range of criticisms could be directed at the guide. The guide to the assessment of rates of veterans' pensions is based on the evaluation of permanent impairment which arises from the American Medical Association. Because of this, I believe it lacks an enormous amount of flexibility that previously has been available in the repatriation area. In particular it does not treat a person who is seeking a pension or a disability allowance as a person to be assessed in totality. Rather, it refers to items in a fixed schedule. If I may give an example, a person with one hip impaired might rate, say, a 20 per cent disability. A person with two hips impaired, by the use of simple addition, would be rated at a 40 per cent disability. We find on page 6, for example, that the rating for the total impairment of a pair of organs or limbs shall be the actual impairment, or twice the rating for the impairment attributable to war-caused injury or disease, whichever is the less.

As honourable senators would realise, in fact the difference between having one-hip impairment and two-hip impairment may very well be the difference between being able to walk with a stick or a crutch and being confined to a wheelchair. One can look at a whole range of those types of impairments and disabilities to see whether or not the actual way that the assessment has been made is in keeping with the total person rather than in keeping with this inflexible rating system.

The level of disability required to obtain a 100 per cent general rate according to the guide is total disability, irrespective of the severity of the injury or the disease. It is unlikely, using this guide, that the assessment would be 100 per cent and consequently the assessment could not satisfy sections 22, 23 or 24 of the Act. To obtain a 100 per cent general rate pension, a veteran would have to be completely dependent and house-bound. The scale is not applicable to the type of assessment that I believe the guide is meant to be dealing with. Fifty per cent of a complete impairment rating would equate much more closely to the intermediate rate.

It certainly seems to be the general opinion of veterans' organisations-this has now been borne out by the material provided at the Estimates committee-that the guide will reduce the ability of veterans to gain support. I believe it reduces the rights of veterans and I believe that in many cases these reductions could be extremely substantial ones. For example, a totally incapacitated veteran will be assessed at the 100 per cent rate. The intermediate and special rates involve additional payments only for the effect of a veteran's incapacity on his or her employability. If the total incapacity rates at 100 per cent, the rate for partial incapacity therefore will have to be correspondingly reduced.

Age is not taken into account. An 18-year-old who is unable to do household tasks gets the same impairment rating as a 70-year-old who is unable to do the same tasks. That does not seem to me to be either fair or just. Pain and suffering receives no assessment rating. The individual who works despite pain-we had a very long discussion of many instances of that during the debate on the actual Bill-will get nothing to compensate him or her for this suffering.

I believe that there is no foresight contained in the guide and no consideration of men and women who may be involved in conflicts or wars in the future. It seems to be modelled on the male veteran from World War II. Yet there are, as we know, many younger veterans from the Korean and Vietnam conflicts and from peace-keeping forces who the Act should also be covering. I do not believe, the way the Act is written, that it covers these veterans adequately. For example, there is no mention of the problems of the female reproductive system in the section on the endocrine and reproductive systems, although there is mention of the male reproductive system. Numerous medical conditions are not mentioned and are covered only in a very general way under the heading `Activities of daily living' on pages 9 and 10 of the guide.

I believe that in keeping with the Act the guide should be flexible enough to cope with changes in our society, in modern weaponry and in the types of injuries that people are likely to suffer. Hence we need to look in a much more flexible way at medical advances, new diseases and new diagnostic instruments which are available and which point us in possible new directions for treatment and understanding things that in the past may have been put down to various possibilities and then put aside. Unfortunately, the near total reliance on fixed assessment tables precludes this from occurring.

War widows are also disadvantaged. The percentage of veterans receiving the totally and permanently incapacitated pension will be considerably reduced and, correspondingly, the number of widows automatically receiving war pensions will be reduced. I think it is unfortunate that the short deadlines which were provided for the ex-service community to comment ensured that those comments could not have been taken into account before the guide was introduced. If one looks at the chronology of the printing of the guide and of the closing dates for comments from the ex-service community, one can see that this is a fact.

The Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt) has advised in response to comments that have been made in the past with regard to this matter that any amendments proposed as a result of those comments would `be considered in the context of an evaluation of the new assessment system to be carried out by my Department during the early days of the system's operation'. That is something that could have been said four or five years ago. I do not believe that it carried terribly much weight today. We have simply to look at the Notice Paper before us or to talk to the Manager of Government Business (Senator Grimes) to see how very difficult it is for any Minister to get a piece of legislation into this place in under 18 months from the beginning of the operation. In other words, we would not be taking the comments made by the veterans' community immediately into account but rather would be waiting until probably the 1988 legislative year before this chamber saw anything with regard to the proposed amendments to the veterans' entitlements legislation.

There is also a great deal of concern in the veteran community about the lifestyle questionnaire which arises out of this guide. I believe that questions asked in the lifestyle questionnaire are intrusive and, in many cases, extremely difficult for veterans to answer. Considering the way the Veterans' Entitlements Bill is written, considering the fact that it retains very strongly the notion of not putting the onus on the veterans, of its being a supportive Bill, I invite honourable senators to listen to the questions asked under the heading `3. Personal relationships'. Questions are asked about the kinds of relationships veterans have with other people. Veterans may tick more than one box. The following questions are listed:
I am always making new friends
I am often irritable with neighbours and family members
I do not mix socially outside my own home
I get out and mix with people as much as I need to
There are some family members I prefer to stay away from
I have fewer chances to get out for entertainment with friends as much as I would like
I find it difficult to keep up a conversation with casual acquaintances
I find it difficult to keep up a conversation with family members
My circle of friends is getting smaller, and I don't seem to be able to make new friends very easily.
Some days I do not feel like mixing with or talking to people. I keep to myself and avoid other people.
That is the list of statements which appear under one question. People can tick any number of those statements.

TALK.START.PARA: —Insane nonsense.

—Yes, it is insane nonsense. I think it would be far better handled if the veteran were able to meet with a sympathetic medical officer so that there could be a one-to-one discussion. That is the method we have traditionally used. Questions certainly are an invasion of privacy. I refer to question No. 4, which I believe is an invasion of privacy:

SPEECH.PARA: This question asks about who does a range of activities that are undertaken regularly in and around the home.
Please tick the boxes which best describe who in your home does the activities listed.
You may tick more than one box for each activity.

There are columns headed `myself', `spouse', `community service help', `paid help', and `other'. The veteran is then asked to specify who the `other' is. These activities are then listed: Making beds; preparing meals; house cleaning; ironing; washing up; gardening; lawn mowing; shopping; banking; home repairs-minor; and washing the car. The only activity that is not listed is major house repairs. I believe that the questions in no way go to the essence of what is required by the Act. I believe they go beyond what is required by the Act. I do not see in any section of the Act any justification for that type of operation with regard to veterans. For that reason, and others, I have moved for the disallowance of the guide. The Senate has a responsibility to make sure that any delegating legislation delegates in a way that depends upon the Act and not upon what the Department wishes to ask or engage in regardless of what the Act has required. The Regular Defence Forces Welfare Association has stated:

The Government has achieved considerable savings on disability war pensions as a result of the amendments to the Repatriation Act. Further considerable savings will result from the introduction of the new Guide. However, the Parliament is morally obligated to provide reasonable and just compensation to veterans for war caused disabilities. This can only be achieved by the early introduction of an exceptional disability allowance or a new pension structure to provide this level . . . and, the withdrawal of the new guide or its disallowance by the coalition or Democrats in the Senate.

I urge the Senate to disallow this guide. I believe it should be disallowed to enable further discussions to take place with veterans' organisations so that the types of items that I raised do not appear in the guide and do not operate for the next two years before some amendments can be made to the Act.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to the motion moved by the Australian Democrats to disallow the guide to the assessment of rates of veterans' pensions made under the Veterans' Entitlement Act 1986. It is not our intention to support the motion for disallowance. But we believe that a number of the matters which have been raised by the Democrats ought to be looked at as the guide comes into operation. We suggest that the guide basically is an improvement but will need major work. I do not think it is likely that any guide of this kind, brought in after the introduction of a new Act, would be expected to work perfectly and not require some amendments and adjustments. But we rely on the commitment by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt) to set up the independent monitoring committee, which he has said will be set up after 12 months. I hope the Minister will make that commitment to the Senate today in this debate, so that there is no doubt that that will occur.

SPEECH.PARA: Equally, I have no doubt that veterans organisations will monitor this most closely. I will do so to the very best of my ability. I know that other senators on this side of the chamber who also have a very deep commitment to the welfare of the veteran community will, in their electorates and areas, monitor how it works and will not be slow in coming forward with suggestions as to changes that ought to be made. If anomalies occur, I hope that the Minister will make quite rapid adjustments to the guide and will not necessarily wait for 12 months to pass before seeing that veterans are treated in the way that this country ought to treat them. Previously, the rather informal guidelines, which seemed to change from time to time, were rather loose; administrative arrangements. I personally prefer this new concept, not so much because it is codified but because of the way the impact on a veteran of an injury is assessed. Apart from the form that Senator Macklin has just referred to, I regard the lifestyle rating concept as a significant part of the assessment. I think it ought to be a beneficial and welcome addition to the way in which veterans' injuries are assessed. I certainly agree with Senator Macklin that the form from which he quoted lacks sensitivity and does not appear in any way to recognise this country's commitment to veterans. I hope that the form can be redrafted to address the issues in a less confrontationist way.

I believe the guide is more comprehensive. It is based differently, on the guides to the evaluation of permanent impairment which have been adopted by the American Medical Association, and the international classification of impairments, disabilities and handicaps, used by the World Health Organisation. Certainly, we have to monitor the guide to see that it is relevant to the veteran community. We say that the system should be given a chance. The guide deals with impairment and, under the lifestyle section, deals with the effects of impairment on an incapacitated individual as a whole person.

I reiterate the defect that Senator Macklin referred to in speaking about the endocrine and reproductive systems. He said, as is the case, that female reproductive organs are not referred to. I regret to say that I see that as a rather significant omission. War widows have been poorly treated by this Government. World War II women veterans have not been treated in the way that they should have been. There are some matters related to defence home loans that need to be addressed so far as women are concerned. I must say that my reaction to this omission is that it is not merely for the sake of brevity or because very few women are involved. I think it is significant that women have been left out of this rather important area.

It is true, of course, that the veteran community is divided on this guide. That is not denied. I have seen correspondence that has been quoted and referred to, from the Regular Defence Force Welfare Association and the Australian Veterans and Defence Services Council, and some people within the Returned Services League have expressed genuine concerns. Others within the RSL and supporters feel that the guide ought to come into effect and be allowed to operate. But they, too, will have to rely on the Minister's commitment to review this matter after 12 months. Hopefully, that review will not take too long to complete. I repeat my hope that anomalies that arise in the very near future will be addressed immediately. The first two organisations that I mentioned have indicated that they would prefer to go back to the old system.

It has been suggested that the guide does not address the problems that younger veterans might face. That may be so, but I do not see that that is a reason for throwing it out. Perhaps there is a need to acknowledge that more flexibility may be required so that changes to the guidelines can be incorporated quickly, and hopefully without fuss, whenever the need arises. This would be preferable to going back to the old system which itself had defects. There is a suggestion that some veterans would be much worse off under these guidelines. As I understand it, those veterans who have already been assessed under the old system are not likely to be reassessed or in any way lose the benefits that they now have. Some people in the other group may be better off and some may be worse off. The same applies, of course, to the old system; that, I would suggest, is inevitable.

The RSL has pointed out an anomaly in table 17 on page 37 of the guide in that a 100 per cent general rate pension will be payable on assessment of a 65 per cent impairment and the same rate will apply to a 95 per cent impairment relating to a comatose condition. It sees it as a gap between reaching the 100 per cent general rate pension and the veteran reaching a comatose state. The RSL regards it as an important principle of compensation that higher levels of compensation should be paid for higher levels of impairment.

There are various ways in which veterans have suffered since this Government came into office, which probably explains why some of the veterans' groups have had the reaction to this Guide that they have. I will not go into detail, but the assets test resulted in 13,000 veterans having their service pensions either reduced or cancelled, costing them $25m. They have been the group hardest hit by the assets test-3.4 per cent of veterans as against 2.8 per cent of general age pensioners. They suffered a number of quite significant cutbacks last year in the mini-Budget. Under the Veterans' Entitlements Act temporary and permanently incapacitated pensioners suffered losses of benefits and that has caused some people to react to the guide. The fact is that throwing out the guide would in no way restore the TPI pension that was eroded under the Veterans' Entitlements Act. That is a point which needs to be made on that issue. Without going into all the details of the mini-Budget and the Veterans' Entitlements Act, there were further erosions of veterans' benefits in the 1986 Budget, particularly those relating to war widows and pharmaceutical benefits.

The Government is trying to bring in a system which will be more easily understood and which will work better. It does incorporate the lifestyle rating system, which I would like to see incorporated because I think it does address a number of issues that have not previously been addressed in assessing veterans. I acknowledge that there is not universal acceptance of the rates. I ask the Minister, as I did earlier, to make the commitment that any particular anomalies will be addressed promptly and that the review will be put into effect in 12 months, and last for only a very short time. The review should not be allowed to drag on for years before we have an opportunity to see how the guide to the assessment of rates of veterans' pensions is operating.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government rejects the proposal of the Australian Democrats to disallow the guide to the assessment of rates of veterans' pensions for a number of reasons which the Government believes are sound, and rejects the basic concept upon which Senator Macklin makes his submission. I have given undertakings in the Senate that a monitoring committee will be established. I draw the attention of the Senate to the fact that the disallowance motion was put down within three months of the passage of the Veterans' Entitlements Bill. If it were to be passed by the Senate it would be disastrous from the point of view of the implementation of the Veterans' Entitlements Act and the determining system, which is an essential part of the commitment of the Government, the Parliament and the community to the veterans of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I point out that there is in fact very little pressure coming from the veteran community to disallow the guide of assessment. Compared to the pressure that was around when we were discussing the Veterans' Entitlements Bill, the views expressed and the pressure with respect to this assessment have been minimal. There has been no demand from within the veteran community, which believes, as the Government does, that there is an obligation on all of us to give the assessment an essential trial period. Once a monitoring committee has been established and the way in which the assessment has been applied is known, then the Senate, after consideration of the various political views, will have an opportunity to make a judgment in respect of these matters.

We have to address issues such as what will be the effect and purpose of disallowing the guide to the assessment of rates of veterans' pensions, what will replace the guide, and how will veterans' pensions be assessed in the future if we do not have that assistance from the guide. How much consideration did Senator Macklin give to these issues-which I believe are vital to veterans-when he gave his notice of motion and today when he moved for its disallowance? The new guide replaces a document entitled `A Guide to the Assessment of Incapacity'. The change that has occurred as a result of the enactment of the Veterans' Entitlements Act by this Parliament came into effect on only 22 May this year. The new guide meets the requirements of that Act. It was approved by me, as the responsible Minister, and has been tabled in Parliament as required by the Act.

To put it as simply as I can, the old system was not working well. It had a lot of shortcomings and received a lot of criticism. The old system was not as well understood as some people would like to believe. The old guide meant different things to different people in different States. That is borne out by some of the peculiar statements made by some of those seeking to encourage Senator Macklin's efforts to disallow the guide. Naturally, an ambiguous guide means that there is inconsistency in decisions around Australia on the levels of disability compensation payable. As a Minister I have found that I regularly get letters from people asking how it is that a pension is granted on certain grounds in one particular circumstance and not in another. They ask why a veteran in one State should receive a different level of disability pension from another veteran with exactly the same disability living in another State. It is a good question. There is no justification for that situation, but it exists. It is therefore important for any national body with responsibility, such as the Repatriation Commission, to ensure that equal treatment is given to veterans wherever they live in Australia. The shortcomings that existed under the old system are well known to anybody familiar with it.

Changes were called for by the Toose Independent Inquiry into the Repatriation System which was conducted in the 1970s. In a report by the Advisory Committee on Repatriation Legislation Review, which was presented to me in November 1983 and which was initiated by my predecessor, Senator Messner, many important recommendations were made about the problems we are now dealing with. This report eventually formed the basis of the Veterans' Entitlements Act. The guide follows a number of recommendations made by that very important Committee, which was comprised entirely of veterans' representatives. As early as 1980, the Federal Court of Australia and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal began to refer to the inappropriate aspects of the old guide. Recently, criticisms of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal have become much more pointed. In a case earlier this year the Administrative Appeals Tribunal said:

It is apparently anticipated in the Veterans' Entitlements Bill that new medical guidelines will be prepared and will be prescribed with statutory effect. If they are already in existence they may prove to be more helpful to decision makers than the present guidelines, the anomalies of which have been pointed out from time to time.

Any veteran who has made a claim for disability compensation will know that it is very difficult for the Repatriation Commissioner to explain how particular levels of general rate pension compensation were selected under the old system. In a climate of developing administrative law and public accountability this situation could not be allowed to continue.

In short, what I am saying to the Senate is that any person with a reasonable working knowledge of the old system knows that it did not measure up to its responsibilities, its need for consistency and particularly its public accountability. The Repatriation Commission's aims in drafting the guide were to provide rules for assessment which meet the requirements of the Veterans' Entitlements Act and to encourage compensation assessments which are comprehensive because they take into account the effects of service on health and lifestyle. I agree with Senator Reid that there is a general acceptance of the lifestyle proposals. The guide encourages consistency of decisions at the level of the dis-ability pension and achieves assessments which in general approximate those which would have been made under the old system.

In case anyone has the impression that the new system of assessment has been rushed, let me put that view to rest. Is is not well founded. I remind the Senate that the Repatriation Commission has been improving the assessment processes for some years. The current document reflects the benefit of over 10 years of research and experimentation by the Department and by various Ministers of State. During that time the American Medical Association's concept of the needs of a repatriation system in the Australian environment was adapted to meet Australian content. The Commission has had the benefit of a vast accumulation of knowledge and skills regarding disability compensation acquired by the medical determining staff over many years.

A draft of the present guide was publicly available in October last year. There are very few substantial differences between last years draft and the document I tabled recently. Veterans's organisations were not able to provide informed or critical comment about the guide for very much the same reason why I believe it is futile for us in the Parliament to attempt to adjust the guide at this stage. That reason is simply that the guide reflects the best available advice to the Government. Until we have had the experience with it and learnt from it-we should bear in mind that the legislation was passed only in May and our experience with it is only in its infancy-nobody can conclude that the guide will not meet the objectives I have mentioned.

The aims of the guide are very clear. We must now measure its performance against those aims. It is essential that we have approximately 12 months to be able to come to any adequate, proper and mature conclusion. I remind honourable senators that in the Veterans' Entitlements Act Parliament has not given the Repatriation Commission carte blanche for the preparation of the guide. Section 29 of the Act quite specifically puts a number of obligations on the Commission. These are that the guide must specify the criteria for assessing incapacity; specify methods for converting the extent of incapacity to a service value of a pension; be binding on the Commission when it makes a pension assessment in a particular case; and have regard to the medical opinion about the nature and effect of incapacity, including the possible effect of any injury or disease, and to the extent to which an incapacity can reasonably be capable of being reduced or removed.

Implementation of the guide commenced progressively from 22 May 1986. From 1 November this year all assessment decisions will be made according to the guide. It will be some time yet before a sufficient number of claims has been processed under the guide to provide us with any conclusive results. However, the signs at this stage are that the objectives of the guide are being met. I am advised that, for example, between 22 May and 26 September, 1,645 cases were assessed under the guide. Those 1,645 cases represent about 4 per cent of the number of cases determined under the old system in the 12 months to 30 June 1986. The number of cases determined under the guide is still too small for any meaningful conclusion to be drawn or comparisons made with the results under the old system. However, the results in the small number of cases determined to date show that the average pension increase under the new system is very close to the average increase under the old system. The average increase for cases assessed under the guide so far is 19 per cent and the average increase for cases assessed under the old system during the same period-22 May to September 1986-is 21 per cent.

I believe some people in the veteran community, as well as perhaps some members of the Senate, may not realise the effects that disallowance of the guide would have. It would have devastatingly important effects for veterans. After 1 November 1986 the Veterans' Entitlements Act will operate so that all decisions on disability compensation must be made under a guide that has been prepared in accordance with section 29 of that Act. That is the guide that Senator Macklin now wishes to disallow. In the event of its being disallowed, the Repatriation Commission will have no legal authority to make any decision on the general rates of compensation for disability after 1 November 1986. That is a very serious situation.

What will the supporters of the disallowance proposal say to veterans who will be unable to have their rates of pension set? What of the veterans themselves who will be denied increases in pensions because of the impact of disallowance? No one expects the guide to be perfect; there is no perfect way to compensate for incapacity with cash. We are dealing with hundreds of thousands of veterans who have had various experiences and have various disability problems, and it is very difficult to have a system operating that deals with people equitably and in a way in which no person is disadvantaged.

We believe that this guide is as good a document as can be produced at this time. It has all the benefits of the accumulated experience of the Department of Veterans' Affairs. I do not think Senator Macklin has produced any evidence to show that our early experiences in these matters have revealed any defects. The only way for us to discover whether the guide has any defects or deficiencies whatsoever, and if so where they are, is for it to be used and to be monitored carefully. I repeat the commitment that I made in that respect: Early next year a monitoring committee will be set up which will be representative of the veteran community and, I hope, will be in a position to give us the sort of advice that will confirm our view. I hope that the guide and the Act will operate in the interests of the veteran community.

Careful evaluation of the guide in operation is essential. Senator Macklin is aware of this. I said to him, in response to a question in April this year, that I would establish a committee to report on the first 12 months operation of the veterans' entitlement legislation and, in particular, on any aspects of that operation which are of concern to the ex-service community. I am happy to repeat that undertaking: I will set up such a committee; membership will include representatives from the ex-service community; that committee will report to the Parliament in the Budget sitting of 1987; and the Government will respond to that report as soon as possible thereafter. Those were the commitments that I made when we were discussing various aspects of the legislation in April and May this year, and those commitments remain unequivocal. There will be an evaluation and the ex-service community will be involved. There will be a report to Parliament.

The Veterans' Entitlements Bill, as amended, was subsequently agreed to by the Senate and it is now law. I understood at that time that Senator Macklin was happy with my response. I do not think anything has changed. There is no evidence before me, the veteran community or the Senate that suggests there has been any substantial change to that situation. The draft guide was available and has been published. Only superficial changes have been made. The existing entitlements for veterans receiving disability pensions are protected by the veterans' entitlements legislation. Where the pension rate, assessed under the guide, is less than the rate being paid to the veterans under the previous system, the veterans' existing rate will nevertheless continue in payment.

A pension can be reduced under the new guide only if there has been an improvement in a veteran's medical condition or if the previous pension assessment was based on false or misleading information. That is part of our responsibility to provide public accountability. Therefore I believe the move to disallow the guide has no constructive value; indeed, disallowance would have an adverse, disruptive and greatly detrimental effect on veterans' claims and pension assessments. I doubt that many veterans, least of all those in the leadership of the veterans organisations, support the proposal. I urge support for rejection of disallowance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I am sorry that the disallowance motion I have moved will not be carried. I listened to the statements of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt). Basically, all he was saying was that disallowance would cause a great deal of difficulty-the Yes Minister type of response. Yes, we know there would be administrative difficulties; nobody is denying that. What I am saying is that the guide to the assessments of rates of veterans' pensions is not written in conformity with the Veterans' Entitlements Act, and I do not believe it is necessary to use the types of premises that the Minister used. For example, when talking about consistency he said that veterans in different States with exactly the same disability were receiving different pensions. I reject the notion of exactly the same disability because the whole thrust of my argument is that disability has to be seen in relation to the particular veteran. The Minister has already pointed out the methods we have used previously on which to base the guide. I believe a variety of methods and a variety of guides could possibly be in conformity with the Act.

SPEECH.PARA: The last matter I wish to raise on this guide is very important and is a result of a question I asked the Minister on 22 August as to whether the Minister had indeed approved of the guide, as is required by section 29, sub-sections (3) and (7), of the Veterans' Entitlements Act. This was the Minister's response:

Although the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 stipulates the guide must be approved by the Minister, there is no requirement in that legislation that an indication of such approval should appear in the printed document.

Again, this is an answer which would be worthy of Sir Humphrey Appleby. As I understand it, the answer says in effect that a Minister may secretly comply with his statutory obligations and it is not necessary for it to be known that he has complied with them. When the guide was tabled surely the Senate was entitled to know whether it had been approved by the Minister in accordance with the Act. Persons in receipt of the guide are entitled to know whether it is an approved document and not simply a draft, as we have seen previously, or a proposal issued by somebody else.

It seems to me that if the Minister's answer is to be taken seriously it would mean that regulations, ordinances and other instruments having the force of law could be published without any indication on them that they are made in accordance with the relevant statute. I ask honourable senators to think what might occur as a result. Fairly obviously, this would cause enormous confusion in the courts. Indeed, I believe this guide may cause such confusion. Surely some proof other than the document itself would be required to show that the document was an instrument made in accordance with the Act; otherwise the relevant provisions of the Evidence Act would be defeated.

I think the way out of the situation obviously would have been for the Department of Veterans' Affairs to admit that it had actually made a mistake and forgot to include the Minister's instrument of approval, instead of saying, as it has, that it is technically legal even though obviously improper. It is a worry that if this situation is allowed to continue in this area or other areas an enormous amount of confusion will result. I hope that in future any alterations made to the guide, or a resubmittance of the guide, with regard to the Veterans' Entitlements Act will carry an indication that the Minister, in conformity with section 29 (3) and (7) of the Act, has actually approved of the guide.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Macklin's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN INSTITUTE OF SPORT BILL 1986AUSTRALIAN INSTITUTE OF SPORT (CONSEQUENTIAL PROVISIONS) BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 8 October, on motion by Senator Button:
That the Bills be now read a second time.
upon which Senator Collard had moved by way of amendment in respect of the Australian Institute of Sport Bill 1986:

Leave out all words after `That', insert: `the Senate is of the opinion that this Bill should not be proceeded with as it does nothing more than add to the burgeoning number of statutory authorities already in existence when the functions of the proposed Institute of Sport could well be performed by an existing body'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of this legislation is to turn the Australian Institute of Sport from a company limited by guarantee into yet another statutory body. This is part of the continuing attempt by this Government to move into the wholesale bureaucratisation of sport. As the shadow Minister, Mr White, has said in the other place, this is an attempt by the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown) to continue the creation of unnecessary statutory bodies throughout his portfolio. In a few minutes I will come to some analysis of exactly what is happening in the Sport, Recreation and Tourism portfolio as far as that is concerned. In the second reading debate in the other place on 22 May, Mr White said:

SPEECH.PARA: It has also become clear that most people associated with sport in Australia, within the Institute, the Australian Sports Commission and the sporting world generally, do not see the necessity for yet another statutory corporation within the world of sport.

That is a point with which I agree. In 1983 one advisory board-the Sports Advisory Council-assisted the Commonwealth Government by making recommendations about the allocation of support for sport. In 1983 there was one board which had nine members; in 1986 there is a 20-member Australian Sports Commission. All the members are paid annual fees ranging from $5,000 to $17,000 each. There is a board of management at the Australian Institute of Sport and there are numerous other bodies in this area, including the board of the Sports Aid Foundation. While Commonwealth funding for sport has approximately doubled from 1983-84 to 1986-87, senior staff costs in the administration of Commonwealth sports programs have virtually quadrupled. That is something to which a degree of attention needs to be directed by this Government. As I said previously, this is part of an ongoing increase in these bodies but, more to the point, a considerable degree of confusion is growing as to the location of responsibilities within the Department of Sport, Recreation and Tourism, the Australian Institute of Sport and the Sports Commission. In dealing with sport and the support of sport at the moment one has to deal with the Department of Sport, Recreation and Tourism, the Australian Institute of Sport and the Sports Commission.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the Sports Aid Foundation.

—As Senator Sheil said, now also there is the Sports Aid Foundation. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard tables taken from the estimates submitted by the Department of Sport, Recreation and Tourism on the staff profiles of the Department, the Institute and the Sports Commission.
