TALK.START.PARA: —Those tables indicate, for instance, that in the Department there is an average staffing level of 355.9; in the Australian Institute of Sport the ASL is 164 and in the Sports Commission it is 22. It is almost impossible to work out how the lines of demarcation and responsibilities interrelate in these three arms of the Government as far as this portfolio is concerned. It is very difficult for people to know which part of the bureaucracy they have to deal with.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said, there is the question of increasing patronage within Mr Brown's Department. Just recently I had the opportunity to congratulate Mr Brown on having made the one hundredth appointment to positions of patronage within his portfolio. Within his portfolio he has the Australian Institute of Sport, the National Committee on Sport and Recreation for the Disabled, the Australian Tourist Commission, the Tourist Advisory Council, the Australian Sports Commission, the National Australia Day Council, the Working Group on Women in Sport and the Sports Aid Foundation. If one adds all of those up, one will see that he has just completed making the one hundredth appointment to positions of patronage within his Department, and there appears to be absolutely no end to the new bodies that will be created, to the further proliferation of all of these statutory bodies, corporations, institutes, commissions and all the rest of it which are being used by Mr Brown largely to politicise the approach to sport and to sports administration in Australia and by and large to try to make himself a hero to all of these organisations by padding out unnecessarily their membership.

For instance, why does the Australian Sports Commission need some 20 people on it? Frankly, when one looks at some of the members of that Commission, worthy individuals though they may be and worthy sportsmen and sportswomen though they may be on the basis of their past records, there is absolutely nothing to indicate that they contribute anything to the way in which the Commission operates or to the functions which the Commission is supposed to undertake.

Nevertheless, as far as the Institute is concerned, there are a large number of unanswered questions, some of which I hope the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) will address in her reply. The first question deals with the continuing problem of the financial management of the Australian Institute of Sport and the unsatisfactory nature of the responses given by the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism to the criticisms contained in the Price Waterhouse report. This matter, of course, goes back to last year. Mr Brown, when tackled by the shadow Minister in the other place on a number of occasions about the financial mismanagement of the Australian Institute of Sport, said:
I am not aware of any financial shortcomings at the Australian Institute of Sport. I have not been made aware of any in the past.

Mr Brown went on to describe the affairs of the Australian Institute of Sport by saying that everything will be found to be `in apple pie order'. The apple pie certainly got scrambled up fairly quickly when the Price Waterhouse report came down because that report indicated that there were major problems with the financial administration of the Institute. Mr Brown was forced to recant some of his remarks. The Sydney Morning Herald, in its editorial on 30 November 1985 under the heading `Mr Brown pinned for a fall', indicated the extent to which Mr Brown had simply failed to comprehend the financial problems which were involved as far as the Institute was concerned. To date we have not had satisfactory explanations; we have not had satisfactory responses on the criticisms of the financial management, practices and controls of the Australian Institute of Sport.

The second point I raise is one which involves continuing police investigation into matters concerning the Institute. It seems to me absolutely extraordinary to read details of how the police, for various reasons, have had to raid not only the Institute of Sport looking for particular papers but also a number of private homes looking for papers which deal with contracts over the Institute's acquisition of boats. This matter was examined in some superficial detail by Senate Estimates Committee D in its hearings on 29 September. I understand that a report by the police will shortly be in the hands, presumably, of the Director of Public Prosecutions who in due course, one supposes, will advise either the Attorney-General's Department or the Minister directly. Hopefully-I think the indications are in this direction-nothing further will proceed from those police investigations. Nevertheless, it seems that before the Parliament goes ahead and establishes the Institute as an independent statutory authority it ought to be a little more convinced in its own mind of the Institute's capacity to manage its affairs. I do not know the last occasion on which the police had to raid a Commonwealth authority. I presume that the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation raid was the last such police raid, although I cannot recall exactly. It seems to me to be a quite extraordinary series of events.

In the last couple of weeks we have had the resignation from the Institute of its controversial, to say the least, Executive Director, Dr John Cheffers. Dr Cheffers has indicated that the cause of his resignation was some disagreement with the Board. Fair enough; if the Executive Director and the Board cannot get on, somebody has to go. Nevertheless, Dr Cheffers has indicated that he fears the legislation changing the Institute from a corporation to a statutory authority will mean `a lot more red tape'. I agree with that. Once again there will be a lot more red tape. Once again this is an attempt to establish in Canberra a bureaucratic presence in the area of sport. I can certainly assure the Senate that the policies which the Opposition is developing on sport are such that when it is elected to government at the next election the Australian Institute of Sport will not find itself in the sort of privileged statutory body position which it currently seeks to enjoy. When we are in government that Institute will be substantially changed. It will be substantially brought back under the control which ought to be exercised in terms of its relationship with both the Minister and the Australian Sports Commission. I can assure honourable senators that the easy street or gravy train approach adopted by some of the bureaucrats of the Australian Institute of Sport will be extremely short-lived.

Dr Cheffers's resignation, presumably, has some financial implications for the Commonwealth. There is a contract, after all. In the Estimates Committee hearing on 29 September I sought from the Institute some details of the financial arrangements which may have been involved in Dr Cheffers's contract being bought out, wound up or whatever happened to it. I have been assured that the matter will be taken up with the Chairman. Let me say-I propose to have this matter reported equally when Senate Estimates Committee D reports to the Senate-that when Senate committees ask what the financial implications are for institutes such as this, it is simply unacceptable to be told: `We will take it up with the Chairman'. The facts are there; the organisations know what they are. When organisations are not prepared to give the facts, when Senate Estimates committees are told `I will take it up with the Chairman' or `I will ask Sir Humphrey'-or Bernard or whoever it happens to be at the time-`whether he minds if I tell you what you are entitled to know, seeing that you will have to pay the money', that is not a satisfactory response. The Chairman and representatives of the Institute had better have pretty prompt answers for the Senate Estimates Committee if they expect to get appropriations dealt with in an expeditious fashion when they come before the Senate.

I had wanted to take up a number of matters about particular sports but I do not intend to take the time of the Senate today to do so other than to draw attention to one matter which gives me some concern and which was a matter of some discussion in the Estimates Committee. I refer to the continuing non-decision about support for cycling in particular. Australian cyclists have been of outstanding quality in recent years. It has been one of the much-neglected sports in which Australians have excelled. There are a number of questions, including the comments made some time ago by Charlie Walsh, the national cycling coach, concerning promises made in September 1984 about adequate support for cycling which, to this date-two years down the track, if I may use that expression-have not yet been satisfactorily responded to as far as the Government is concerned.

A number of matters arise about coaching. Letters from coaches, including those who are directly associated with the Institute, were sent to the former shadow Minister, Mr Blunt. One of the national coaches wrote that he was extremely concerned about the way in which the bureaucracy within the AIS had grown in proportion to the people who matter-that is the athletes and coaches-and about the ever increasing amount of money required to service administration to the detriment of coaching and competitive programs. Some significant answers have to be given about that matter. We do not believe that it has been handled in an entirely satisfactory fashion in terms of the relationship between the cost of administration and the money flowing through to the direct support of athletes or to the support of their coaches.

The Institute, nevertheless, has been one of the great achievements of the Fraser Government. Mr Ellicott, in announcing on 25 January 1980 the formal opening of what he called at that stage the National Sports Training Institute, indicated that one of its purposes was to help in the development of elite sports men and women. I believe that the Institute has a wider role; that is, it is not simply a matter of elite sports assistance. The necessity to decentralise and to involve increasing numbers of Australians in access to sporting activities is important. Nevertheless, I believe that there is complete justification for concentration upon significant areas of elite achievement. I agree that, in exactly the same way as centres of excellence are important in terms of education and research, and in exactly the same way as the flagship companies in the arts are important and need fostering and special assistance, elite sports men and women ought to have some recognition.

Nevertheless, I do find that there is a real problem in attempting permanently to tie the achievements or otherwise of the Institute to the fairly crude measure of what one might call the `gold medals index'-that is, to try to demonstrate that X number of gold medals were won in certain events. Let us compare, for instance, the Commonwealth Games medal tally in Brisbane in 1982 with that in Edinburgh in 1986. There was a difference of one gold medal between our medal tally in Brisbane and our tally in Edinburgh. In Brisbane, Australia finished second to England in the medal tally, but in Edinburgh it came third behind England and Canada. Those comments which occasionally are made in the Press are not particularly effective ways of attempting to measure results. It is a pity to see, for instance, in Time magazine that the report of the success of Australian sports comes under the heading `A tepid triumph'. I think that occurs because there is too much concentration on, as I say, this gold medal index approach.

I am far more impressed by the fact that an analysis of determinants of Olympic performance undertaken by Graeme Caughley, a Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation officer, which was published in Search-that is the journal of the Australian and New Zealand Association for the Advancement of Science-in October-November 1984 indicated, and I quote the opening sentence of the summary:
The comparison of the performance of the top 25 countries at the 1984 Olympics indicates that medal score is predicted closely by countries' gross domestic product.

In fact, it is important to understand that support for sport is far wider than simply attempts to focus upon elite undertakings or to measure results by crude medal tally. There is always a great deal of myth as far as sport is concerned, one of the most significant being the myth of amateurism at the Olympic level. That is one of the great and enduring myths of our time. Indeed, a very excellent book was written by the American classical historian, David Young, which was published in Chicago in 1984, entitled the Olympic Myth of Greek Amateur Athletics. One of the things that we need to do, in looking at the question of sport, is to get away from some of the persistent myths about it.

I raise a couple of matters which I think need to be addressed in the wider context of support for sport-that is, the role of big business in sport, the role of commercialism and sponsorship in sport, the question of private ownership of sporting teams, and, frankly, in certain areas, the involvement of what one might call people of less than maximum integrity in the operation of sporting teams and sporting organisations. Richard Cashman, the Senior Lecturer in History at the University of New South Wales, prepared an article for a recent edition of the `Current Affairs Bulletin', entitled `Sport, Big Business and the Spectator'.

I think it is true that, in the light of Mr Packer and his cricket, and the fact that sporting events are now, by and large, tied to sponsors' names-there is the Fosters Cup, the Winfield Cup, the Rothmans Medal and all the rest-we need to be conscious of the changes taking place in sporting arrangements because of the increase in the money which is involved. For instance, who would have thought some years ago that a surfer of the status of Tom Carroll could earn an income of $250,000 in 1986? Of course, that amount does not include all of the bits and pieces that go with sponsorship. Who would have thought that Australian golfers of the calibre of Greg Norman would probably be able to pass the $1m mark in terms of prizemoney and earnings? The last figure I saw regarding Martina Navratilova's income from playing professional tennis was that it had already exceeded the $16m mark in the course of her career. I believe that people who are charged with the administration of sport, and governments and Ministers who are charged with the funding of sporting activities in Australia, must be very aware of the potentially corrupting influence of large sums of money. I will not go into the question of the private ownership of sporting teams. That seems to me to be something which, again, is a new development in Australia, although it is commonplace in the United States. From time to time I think it has not been handled in an entirely satisfactory fashion.

The last point I make is simply to enter a plea in terms of one of the most disadvantaged groups of sports men and women in Australia-that is, the people who are involved in rifle shooting, and sporting shooting in particular, who are about to lose their rifle range in Sydney, the Anzac Rifle Range at Malabar, as a result of the Government's decision to sell the land. There will be an opportunity to deal with that matter when Estimates committee reports are considered. I do not intend to try to deal with it at this stage in terms of its relationship with the Australian Institute of Sport. Nevertheless, the Opposition has made its view on this matter quite clear. It voted against the legislation in the House of Representatives and indicated exactly what it thought ought to be the position of the Australian Institute of Sport. When the coalition parties are elected to government at the next general election, the mess that this Government has made, including the mess which the Australian Institute of Sport has become, will be sorted out once and for all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —A number of general points have been made during the debate on the Australian Institute of Sport Bill 1986 and the Australian Institute of Sport (Consequential Provisions) Bill 1986. I do not propose to respond at length because my colleague the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown) has done so adequately in the House of Representatives. I point out, in response to Senator Puplick's concern that there is a growing bureaucracy in the area of Federal involvement in sport, that of course there is a dramatically increased involvement by our Government in sporting matters which necessitates some increase in the bureaucracy, although we consider it to be of a quite modest dimension. Sporting policies, recreation policies and services to the community have increased dramatically as a result of our Government's much greater support for these activities. The Department now has recreation and fitness responsibilities as well as sporting responsibilities.

SPEECH.PARA: Increased numbers of sports are now pursued at the Australian Institute of Sport. There are decentralised programs and, of course, the Institute is now responsible for its own facilities, whereas previously the Department of Territories had responsibility for them. The Australian Sports Commission is a new initiative with new programs. I refer, for example, to Aussie Sports, the sports science research program and the Australian Sports Aid Foundation, which will increase private sector funding for sport-something which I thought even Senator Puplick would endorse. Senator Puplick drew attention to the average staffing level of the Department. The ASL of the Department is 355. I point out for the record that only 36 of that number deal with sport. So, in the view of the Government, this new move, designed to give independence to the Institute of Sport, will result in improved operations. There have been some difficulties in the past. I do not propose to reargue all of those. We believe that the legislation before the Senate will lead to an improvement in the administration of the Federal Government's very important involvement in sporting activities in the nation. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

Page 2, sub-clause 6 (1), sub-paragraph (a) (ii), after `coaches', insert `, umpires, referees or officials essential to the conduct of sport'.

Both these amendments deal with the scope of the Australian Institute of Sport and they are very simple. The first deals with the fact that the Institute must be involved not only in the development of sportsmen and sportswomen within Australia but also in the process of recognising talent and the athletes it wants to recruit. We believe that that recognition must be carried out through some type of joint venture with the States or with the major national sporting bodies. It is important that the task of recognition and development of talent be included in the Bill. However, we do not see the Institute carrying this out without the aid and concurrence of a large number of other organisations.

The second amendment recognises that sport cannot be carried out effectively by the participants without the skills of a number of other people, such as umpires, referees and other officials, who are essential to the conduct of sport. Excellence in these officials is extremely important if we are to make certain that Australian sportsmen and sportswomen are to perform at their best and if we are to host successfully international competitions in sport. This second amendment seeks to add umpires, referees or officials essential to the conduct of sport, as people who are concerned in the process and of whom the Institute must take note. I commend the amendments to the Committee.

`12. (1) The Board shall develop, prepare in written form, and revise in accordance with sub-section (2), a strategic plan setting out the manner in which it is proposed that the functions of the Institute will be performed.

This changes the Government's plan, which basically is that there will be a three-year plan and a three-year review. We want an annual review of the process as part of the agreement that statutory bodies be reviewed much more closely. I commend that amendment to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let us pause for a moment on sub-clause (2), in addition to which this amendment is proposed. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Chairperson may be referred to as the Chairman or the Chairwoman, and the Deputy Chairperson may be referred to as the Deputy Chairman or the Deputy Chairwoman, as the case requires.

We are to have in addition to this extraordinarily stupid sub-clause the amendment which has just been moved. This amendment concerns the composition of the Board. Sub-clause (1) provides for the Board to consist of a chairperson, a deputy chairperson, the director and not fewer than seven nor more than eleven other members. We then have the extraordinary sub-clause (2), which provides that a chairperson is a human being who may be male or female. I know that on the day after the presentation of the report on human embryo experimentation in Australia all sorts of possibilities may have been opened up and that a chairperson at some stage in the future may be neither a chairman nor a chairwoman, `as the case requires'. Nevertheless, we have put this extraordinary clause into the legislation-one of several like clauses which are dribbling their way through Commonwealth statutes at the moment-providing that the chairperson may be referred to as the chairman or the chairwoman and the deputy chairperson as the deputy chairman or deputy chairwoman, as the case requires. The words `as the case requires' may well mean that on one day the chairperson will be referred to as the chairman and that if he appears in drag the second day he will be referred to as the chairwoman, that being `as the case requires'. It may well be that the chairperson or deputy chairperson is of a sufficient case himself that he does not know whether he wants to be referred to as a chairman or a chairwoman, in which case, presumably, he could simply be referred to as chairperson or, as is becoming extraordinarily fashionable these days, the chair.

TALK.START.PARA: —Chaircase.

—Or chaircase. I suppose we ought to put that into this legislation, followed by the words `as the person requires'. This amendment draws attention to the nonsense of sub-clause (2) and of the way in which this Government is going about putting its so-called affirmative action into legislation. The sub-clause which the Democrats seek to add reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Appointments to the Board shall be such that the members of the Board consist, as far as it practicable, of equal numbers of men and women.

Presumably, that means that, given the fact that the Board may consist of between seven and 14 persons, when the numbers are even the ration of men to women must also be equal. Let us consider what the High Court of Australia, for instance, has said about electoral determinations. The words `as far as is practicable' mean that when one can get a result which is a whole number one is required to go to that whole number. So if the Board consists of 10 members, there must be five men and five women, because that represents, as far as is practicable, equal numbers of men and women. When the Board consists of 10, 12 or 14 members there must be exact equality. When it consists of 11 or 13 members, presumably in the absence of a fraction, unless one of the members is prepared to be both chairman and chairwomen as the case requires--

TALK.START.PARA: —Five men, five women and one Democrat.
—Indeed. That would certainly solve the problem as far as this clause is concerned. Nevertheless, the clause departs absolutely from the principle of appointment on the basis of merit.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition will not be supporting the provisions of proposed new sub-clause (6a), particularly when one bears in mind that the case may well arise where all 14 members ought to be women, in which case the provision will be a monstrous piece of discrimination against women which should not be tolerated under any circumstances. Nevertheless, to depart from the principle of merit, as the Democrat amendment does, is unacceptable. The phrase `as far as is practicable' means a strict ratio. That phrase has been interpreted judicially as meaning that where it is possible for the numbers to be five-all, six-all or seven-all, that must be adhered to and there must not be a 7:5 or 6:5 situation or whatever the ratio may happen to be. As far as the membership of the Board is concerned, the extraordinarily ridiculous sub-clause (2), which allows one to refer to chairpersons as chairmen or chairwomen as the case requires, is an indication of how absolutely stupid this Government has become on the whole question of putting affirmative action into legislation in a way which is totally unnecessary.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am just wondering whether the Minister can answer a simple question: How much is all this nonsense costing us in all the legislation in which these alterations are to be made?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot answer a question that is phrased in that way. If Senator Walters would like to rephrase her question properly I will have a go at answering it.
—I will rephrase it. Will the Minister tell me how much it is costing in Public Service time to alter the legislation by renaming chairpersons, et cetera?
—Desex the legislation.
—It is commonly called `desexing legislation'.
—I do not think the question is within the scope of this legislation.
—As I understand it, alterations have been made in this legislation and, therefore, it is within the scope of this legislation.
—I do not really understand the question that Senator Walters is asking. If she is asking a question in relation to the preparation of this Bill, perhaps she could try to ask it in a meaningful way.

—I do not believe that the Minister is as dumb as that. I think she is just being difficult. I do not expect her to tell me off the top of her head how much it is costing to alter all the legislation that the Government is-

—On a point of order, Mr Chairman: I suggest that Senator Walters might care to withdraw the phrase that she used regarding the Minister. I do not believe that that is parliamentary, and it should not be allowed.
—If I am made to withdraw it, it will mean the opposite. Don't be silly.
—I take it that Senator Coleman is referring to the words `not as dumb as that'.
—Yes.

—Mr Chairman, I said that I do not think she is as dumb as that. If I withdraw that it will mean that maybe she is. I do not see how I can withdraw it. I said that I do not think she is as dumb as that.
—Order! I think the purpose of the remark is clear. Will you withdraw the implication that she might be dumb?
—I just said that I did not think she was. How else do I withdraw it? As I have said, I do not think she is.
—Order! I do not want to bandy over semantics with you, Senator. Just withdraw it and get it over with.

—I do not either, Mr Chairman, and that is why I said that I do not believe the Minister is dumb. I withdraw my statement that I do not think the Minister is as dumb as that. I have asked the Minister whether she would, please, find out for me the cost of altering legislation to desex the terminology in all the Bills that are coming before us.

—Senator Walters's question is really more appropriate for Estimates committees. She will have an opportunity to ask that question when the estimates of the Parliamentary Counsel come before the Senate.
—I thank the Minister. I would be most obliged if the Minister would ensure that the Department gets that message.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Progress reported.
Motion (by Senator Ryan) proposed:
That the Committee have leave to sit at a later hour this day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLARD
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak briefly to the motion moved by the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan). This is a most unusual situation. A relatively small Bill which we opposed at the second reading stage is now before the chamber. The Australian Democrats, under the guidance of their unguided missile with the fuse well lit, are wandering around here with some amendments which are based on semantics and which do not amount to much. Suddenly, because some proposed deal that Senator Vigor had not done did not come to fruition, he made the very bald statement that he and the Australian Democrats would vote against the Australian Institute of Sport Bill 1986 at the third reading stage. The other Democrats have come into the chamber and had their little conclave. They are not sure in which direction their unguided missile is taking them. So that they can have a chance to caucus or to have their conclave or whatever the Australian Democrats have, they now want a little more time. It is a most unusual proceeding. It is one of the many occasions when this Senate is held up because of the Democrats not knowing in which direction they are going.

SPEECH.PARA: I have no wish to delay this legislation. I would like it to go the way of all bad legislation. We would be prepared to vote against its third reading if that would get rid of it. Our case has been put adequately by the many speakers in the debate. This is another case of the Democrats not knowing where they are going or what they are doing. They do not know who will keep whom honest in this chamber. We are stuck with them; they are here. They do not know what they are doing. Until they find out what they are going to do we have to accept the motion moved by the Minister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the sequence of events which Senator Collard outlined as the way in which we have been brought to this situation he managed to miss out a couple of the smaller but more interesting reflections on the way in which the Australian Democrats handle legislation in this place. Honourable senators will recall that when Senator Vigor moved his first series of amendments the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) indicated that they would not be supported, whereupon the matter was put to the chamber and it was decided on the voices. There was one lone voice which said yes. What happened? The Chairman asked whether there would be a call for a division. Senator Vigor looked around him at the yards of empty red leather to try to find a second poor benighted Australian Democrat who would support him in the call for a division. There was none. So we had an exercise in thumping the desk by Senator Vigor, whereupon he rushed off to the telephone. The next thing we knew Senator Macklin came rushing in here all of a twitter, trying to consult. Senator Macklin got on the phone and Senator Haines came rushing in all in a twitter.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Vigor said that, having been betrayed, the Democrats proposed to vote against the third reading of the Australian Institute of Sport Bill. There was the usual sort of telephone box conversation of the Australian Democrats working out their immediate response to this significant piece of Commonwealth legislation. Senator Vigor, the butcher of Australian Capital Territory self-government, was determined that this matter be taken along, that he ought to reflect in the Senate the enormous degree of support he has for his position as No. 3 on the Australian Democrats ticket in South Australia and try to establish why he should move to the Australian Capital Territory to be re-elected to the Senate. In the meantime, negotiations started with the Minister for Education. She was in a state of total panic at that stage about the potential loss of this legislation at the third reading stage. After all, it is not her legislation; she does not know very much about it and does not give much of a continental about the whole thing anyway. Suddenly there was a great furore that a piece of legislation entrusted to her delicate care may well be sliding away at the third reading stage. So there was this enormous `What can we do, David?' type of situation.

Despite all the huffing and puffing of the Democrats that they were going to vote against the third reading to keep the Government to its deal, what did we find? Once again we proved the proposition that the Australian Democrats could not be bought on a piece of legislation; they can only be rented by the hour. A shabby deal was done between the Minister and Senator Vigor to get some handle on the thing. The proposal was to report progress and seek leave to sit again. In the meantime, what will happen is that this terrible misunderstanding will be sorted out, the Government will come back and say that it did not understand and that perhaps the words really do not matter that much, and the Government will give way to the Democrats. The Democrats will wave their arms and say that they have substantially amended this legislation and kept the so and so's honest. Mr Acting Deputy President, I note that the Clerk has already been referring to you. I shall be more discreet in my use of parliamentary language in these matters, so I will not use the appropriate Democrats phrase.

It is important to understand exactly how we have been brought to this situation. One day last week I think Senator Vigor set a new record in that 18 per cent of the total Hansard was attributable to him. If I continue in this way I will undoubtedly have the opportunity to emulate him. Nevertheless, the point needs to be made in regard to this legislation and the way in which the Democrats are prepared at any stage to enter into any sort of deal, to abandon any sort of principle, to make any sort of threat and to withdraw it the moment that their bluff is called, to go to water the moment the Government raises the pressure on them. We have seen once again that, far from being a party which contributes anything to this place, to the organisation of this place or to the advancement of legislation in this place, the Australian Democrats certainly cannot be bought but as sure as eggs they can be rented by the hour.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some points need to be answered in what Senator Puplick has said because they are totally off the point. What the Australian Democrats have been doing is actually trying to make certain that the legislation that goes through this Parliament is good legislation. The Australian Democrats have discussed the Australian Institute of Sport Bill in our Party room. We had various options open to us because we do not have the numbers in this place to make amendments to legislation that we feel are particularly important in standing up for our principles or to defeat bad legislation. We believe that the legislation is passable with the amendments we put. That is what I said at the second reading stage.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Puplick implied that the fact that we have asked for the Committee to report progress and for the debate to be adjourned on this matter in some way shows a weakness. I believe it is a strength of the Democrats that we are prepared to talk to people-even to Senator Puplick-in private to try to get better legislation for this country. That is actually what we are currently doing, rather than shooting from the hip, as Senator Puplick would have us do, and rejecting legislation through some type of pique. I support the adjournment of this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not the motion. The motion is for resumption.
—I support the motion for resumption of the debate later.
—If we agree to this motion, what undertaking can we have from the Australian Democrats that whatever deal, sordid or otherwise, they do with the Australian Labor Party, they will stick to this time?
—Quite clearly I cannot give you any undertaking. You will have to talk to the Australian Democrats.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have very great sympathy for Senator Vigor because the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) in the past has done exactly the same thing to me. If she now lets the Australian Democrats down, as she did me at the last minute on a similar occasion when she had agreed unequivocally to an amendment for which I had sought her support, all I can say to Senator Vigor is that he should take the action that is permitted in this place and vote with us on the third reading.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Ryan) agreed to:
That, unless otherwise ordered, till 2 p.m. this day, matters of public interest may be discussed by senators, provided that no senator shall speak for more than 15 minutes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have gone rather suddenly into the matters of public interest debate. Senator Haines was to have spoken first on the matter I shall raise but I will make the comments that I wish to make and Senator Haines can follow me. Honourable senators will realise, when I make my remarks, why I thought it more appropriate that Senator Haines should go first. The day prior to the bringing in of the Budget this year saw the resignation of Senator Don Chipp from the Senate and there has not been an appropriate time since then in which to place on the record the appreciation that members of my Party have for the work that Senator Chipp has done, both in the Parliament and in political life in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I owe my involvement in political life to Don Chipp. I was driving to see some of my students when I heard on the radio his speech of resignation from the Liberal Party of Australia, when he was a member of the House of Representatives. I wrote a letter to him commending the types of sentiments that he expressed in that speech, in particular the need for open debate in Australia, the need for less rigid party structures, the need for members of parliament as a matter of priority to address their own consciences when matters come before these chambers, and a range of other issues that he felt ought to be raised as a result of his experience in the House of Representatives and in public life as a back bencher and as a Minister of long standing.

A few days after I wrote to him he rang me up and asked for my assistance in helping to organise a meeting in the Brisbane city hall, a meeting that I chaired and that was followed by the founding of the Queensland division of the Australian Democrats. A lot of the members of the Party had a similar experience. Upon my election to the Senate in 1980 the Democrats gained the balance of power in the Senate for the first time. Obviously I had a lot more involvement with Don Chipp then and when I took my seat in the middle of 1981 it became a day to day involvement, as all senators are involved with one another in their particular party structures.

To me, Don Chipp had always seemed to be a person who always showed his emotions-I had only seen him from afar, on television and so on-and I could not help wondering whether or not it was really him. I learnt very quickly that the types of things that Don Chipp said publicly he felt privately. He was a person who had the utmost personal integrity-and still does-a person who, having finally worked through all of the problems that political parties face, had come to the realisation that he was able to offer more to Australia by remaining rigidly true to his own views and beliefs and by always addressing whether or not the things he was called upon to say, do or vote on were in the best interests of this country.

Soon after taking up my seat Don Chipp had a reasonably lengthy absence from the chamber as a result of heart trouble and at that stage we missed greatly his guidance and advice. It was a very fast learning curve for all of us and for me in particular since I had never been involved previously in any other political party and had only viewed politics from afar. As Don Chipp was recuperating, he was always available to offer advice, and over the years that we have been associated he has offered me an enormous amount of advice. We have not always agreed on everything, as is obvious from some votes in the chamber, but we were always able to discuss matters in a way that I think he was always hopeful that we might eventually bring to political life; that is, we marshalled our arguments and discussed matters in a rational and reasonable way, and if we finally could not convince one another of our respective arguments, we would agree to disagree in such a way as not to leave rancour or ill will.

I am appreciative of all that he has offered me, both on a personal level and on a political level, and I must admit that over the years I gained a growing admiration for him. It is not often that one works closely with a person and goes from a position of having some admiration for that person to a position of having very high admiration for him. Normally one finds that foibles, idiosyncracies and problems tend to lessen a person in one's eyes. It was the very opposite for me in terms of Don Chipp. I think he has a lot more to offer Australian political life. I think that he will, not in an active party political sense but by his judgment, his understanding and his willingness to be always involved in the issues that affect this country, make some further contribution. I wish to have my comments placed on the record because I think that when a person with 25 years of service in this place stands down it is appropriate that some such comments from his colleagues be entered in the record of the place to which he gave so much.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the ways in which politics differs from other forms of business and industry is that in other areas of employment when people leave they are given a gold watch and a speech is made about how wonderful they are and what a great deal of use they have been to the particular organisation. Politicians usually have to wait until they die before somebody says something nice about them. We decided that Don's health is such that that is going to be a long time coming and that it might be a nice idea, since he had been here and in another place for the last 25 years, to say something about him now. Whether one agreed or disagreed with Don Chipp, whether one liked him or disliked him, it was impossible to dismiss as irrelevant the contribution that he made to Australian politics over the last 25 years both when he was a member of the Liberal Party of Australia and for the nearly 10 years that he spent as leader of the Australian Democrats.

SPEECH.PARA: Politics is, in more ways than the one I have just mentioned, a rather strange business and there is a tendency for it to have a rather dehumanising effect on people who are involved in it. They have a tendency to get divorced from reality, to live in the rather artificial atmosphere of Canberra, to become prisoners, if you like, of their own party's hierarchal system and to allow the adversarial nature of Australian politics to divorce them from the Australian people as a whole. In doing that they very much lose touch with what ordinary people want and expect of politicians, politics and government in particular.

I did not know Don Chipp when he was a member of the Liberal Party, so I do not know whether at that stage of his life he actually fell into the trap of being divorced from the people he was elected to represent or the people his party was supposed to represent. I do know that towards the last years of his time as a member of the Liberal Party he became disillusioned with a number of aspects of it. If he did not fall into that trap in the 15 or so years he was a member of the Liberal Party it was quite remarkable. However, in the time I knew him if he had fallen into that trap he had become, if you like, a born again human because he certainly was not divorced from the reality that is Australia, nor was he divorced from the issues that were important to many Australian people.

There is no doubt at all in my mind or in the minds of very many people that Don Chipp cared very deeply about ordinary people, especially young people, and that he was deeply concerned about the quality of life that those people face, both now and in the future. Indeed, his concern for the future of this planet as a whole is something of which I do not need to speak now because it was one of the facets of Don that was very well known and well accepted in the community. He embraced the issues of peace, a future nuclear free world and the preservation and protection of our environment with considerable enthusiasm. Because he was Leader of the Democrats and because those were the issues that he was most intimately concerned with, from time to time he gave the impression that those were the only issues that the Party was involved in. They were not, of course. Don was outraged and very concerned about a number of other issues, including the fact that in Australia we had hundreds of thousands of children living below the poverty line, that some students are having difficulty getting access to the education they need and that people in a post-retirement position were having difficulty with health care, access to appropriate accommodation and other services. His concerns were catholic, in the usual sense of that word, embracing quite a large number of issues and a large number of people.

From time to time, of course, he ruffled a few feathers with some of his more outspoken comments, for example, his rather forthright comments when the Senate was debating, I think, a condolence motion on the death of Mr Brezhnev. I recall that his comments about it being outrageous to express sympathy for or concern about the death of a man who had what Don Chipp said was the blood of millions on his hands certainly caused some feathers to be ruffled not only here but also in at least one embassy that has a base on Australian soil.

In all of this he kept intact a rather wacky sense of humour and managed to survive a normally politically disastrous inability to remember people's names. It is very important for a politician to know who he or she is talking to. People like to be remembered; they like it when one says `Hello, Joe', `Josephine', `Andrew' or `Andrea' and remembers the last time one spoke to them, the names of their spouses and children and the jobs they do. Some politicians are very good at that. Don was woeful at it. Not only could he not remember the names of a lot of people he met casually, socially or in departments and so on, he also had difficulty remembering not only the names of his colleagues, but also the names of his wife and children.

I recall a spectacular instance in his Melbourne office when his wife had called in to see him and she had left after talking to him. He suddenly remembered something he had meant to tell her and did not. He went pounding out of his door down the corridor calling, `George, George', at the top of his voice, forgetting for a moment that he was, in fact, talking to his wife and not to his principal private secretary, whose name happened to be George; although, indeed, it could have been the first name that entered his head. Those of us who were his colleagues and on his staff remember regular instances where he would talk to his wife on the phone, as most of us try to do to keep in touch with our families. He managed to get out of forgetting her name by calling her `Love' or `Darling' during the conversation, but when it got around to the time when he had to ask after the health of the children he got himself into some difficulties. So he always made sure there was a staff member or another colleague in the room with him and when he got around to asking after his elder child, Juliet, who is still under four, he would make hand signals to his staff, moving his hand up and down at about the height that Juliet's head would be if she were in the room. The person would obediently say `Juliet', so that he could say to Idun: `How is Juliet?'. When it got to talking about the baby he would rock his arms from side to side and the staff, or whoever was there, would come up with the name that he had lost.

The other occasion that springs to mind is when he got himself into a bit of a flap because I was supposed to be in here in the chamber and was not at the time. Using the little phones that we have here he rang his staff office and said, `Get me, get me, get me'-and then in an increasing panic-`What is the name of our woman senator from South Australia?'. They realised who he was talking about, rang me and down I trotted. But he managed to do this with the greatest good humour. Nobody that I know of particularly objected to it. In fact, we turned it into a joke and in order to help him to remember who his staff were, rechristened everybody `Marion' on the grounds that that was a good unisex name and somebody at least would answer when he stuck his head out the door and called out for a staff member.

His other most notable quirk was his total incapacity to cope with technology in the form of telephones. Those of us who are here in the chamber will know the sort of array of buttons and things that we have on our telephones; devices that give you the capacity to talk without picking the telephone up, to talk to more than one person at a time, to do all sorts of extraordinary things that most of us really do not want to do anyway. Don would sit there at the phone, push buttons at random and say, `Speak to me somebody', in the hope that sooner or later he would get through to somebody and get an answer. On one memorable occasion, he managed to cut off Paul Keating, who was talking to him from his car phone in Sydney. He then blamed ASIO or Telecom as a consequence.

He was a man of, as they say, many parts who cared deeply and seriously about a lot of serious issues, but who had the sort of endearing human qualities and foibles that make even politicians remain somehow attached to the real world and somehow very human indeed. Without in any way wanting to reflect on the value of my colleague Senator Janet Powell, who has replaced Don Chipp as senator for Victoria, I would have to say that we will indeed miss Don Chipp very much. We will miss the dramatic changes that he added to this chamber from time to time. We will miss his experience and his wisdom in the Party room and we will miss, indeed, his own unique and very valuable expressions of concern for the people of Australia. I believe that this chamber is the poorer without him and can only say that the colleagues that he has left here to carry the can, so to speak, will do the best to live up to the standard that he has established for us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to pay my tribute to Don Chipp. I think he was probably the reason I got into politics. In a book in 1972 I wrote `Buy a politician, sell a politician but never be one'. I lived up to that for a long time until the early 1980s when we were embroiled in a fight in Tasmania to stop the people of the Hydro-Electric Commission from damming the Franklin. As we can see now, it is completely unnecessary for them to have done so. They could not justify their demand predictions. At any rate, we were in there having this fight and it became obvious that the best way to scare a politician is through the ballot box. So I decided to stand for office in Tasmania.

SPEECH.PARA: Rather than stand as an independent, I thought that it would be better if I tried to go in as a member of a party. At that time the Australian Democrats, of course, had no representatives in Tasmania but I was aware of the Party. I researched its policies. I found that, in fact, its policies on the environment, on caring for the future, were exactly the same as mine and Don Chipp, of course, was central in framing those policies. So I became an Australian Democrat candidate and ultimately the first Australian Democrat to be elected to a lower House in Australia.

Throughout this time Don Chipp would come through Tasmania and give me advice and support, which I appreciated, but I never really got to know the man until he decided that he would like to take a look at the Franklin River himself. So we organised a raft trip for him down the lower section of the Franklin River, going in at Mount McCall. We had with us Geraldine Brooks, from the Sydney Morning Herald; Don Chipp and his wife, Idun; and some people from the Tasmanian National Parks and Wildlife Service and also people from the Wilderness Society.

I was a bit curious to see how he would react, because I knew him only as a politician. I did not realise that in his youth he had been a very good athlete and still tried to keep himself in shape. So we appeared at the top of the Mount McCall haulway-which is about a 1,000-foot descent into the Franklin River-and Don Chipp, the politician, was still very much in charge. He was organising who was going to go where and when, who was going to sleep with whom and how we were going to protect the morals of Geraldine Brooks from the depravations of the hirsute Wilderness Society people.

We proceeded to go down this very steep slope. The Hydro-Electric Commission had put in fixed ropes on this slope and when Don Chipp was about halfway down one of the fixed ropes it broke; if fact, Don fell a number of feet. He did not complain. He fell hard; he hit hard but he did not complain at the time. We went on; we got down to the Franklin River, we blew up the rafts, we floated down the first day and never a complaint came from Don except that it was cold and miserable, and we all remarked on that. We fixed our camp on the first night and it turned out that neither Don Chipp nor Idun had ever slept under canvas before. This was their first outing.

Unfortunately, where I pitched a tent for them-it was on a very narrow ledge and it was pouring down rain-turned out to be in a watercourse. I did not sleep in it. I slept in another tent which remained dry all night. The Chipps almost drowned, they claimed. I remember in the middle of the night the Don Chipp voice which has reverberated around these chambers so often, saying: `Darling, did you wake me up to tell me that you were miserable?'. Of course, their sleeping bags were soaked and they were in very bad shape by morning. We proceeded down the Franklin and he did learn to love the river. Idun certainly did, as well. It was not until several days later we learned that, in fact, he had broken his wrist on the fall on the Hydro's fixed rope and, in fact, had been paddling down the river for days with a broken wrist without saying anything to anybody about it. I think that is a sign of the guts and determination which Don Chipp has shown throughout his life.

He did really become very moved by the Franklin and spoke often about it in subsequent years. Many people thought he was overplaying it-playing it for the emotional appeal that he might make to greenie groups, or whatever-but he did have a strong passion for the Franklin River. I think it is time that the nation recognised the role that Don Chipp and the Australian Democrats of that time played in the salvation of the Franklin River because it was the Democrat initiative that set up the Senate Select Committee on South West Tasmania, the Committee that actually looked into the requirements for the dam.

It was the first time that we in the wilderness movement had had a chance actually to talk to an impartial body, a Senate select committee. The Democrats brought in a Bill for the conservation of land in Australia. It became the World Heritage Properties Protection Act. This was actually an Australian Democrat Bill which was brought in and passed by the Senate in the dying days of the Fraser Government. It was later picked up by the Hawke Government and pushed through. This was the Bill which was the basis for the ultimate salvation of the Franklin. So often the things that happen in this chamber are forgotten by historians-there is so much that goes on-and then certainly by the people themselves; but I think it is time that Australians realised the great role that Don Chipp played in the most important conservation battle that Australia has ever seen.

Don Chipp, I feel, is a person who will be grievously missed in this chamber. He looked to the future; he felt for the future, he felt for children. He wanted to ensure that the future would be a fit time for his kids and all kids to live and all I can say is that I hope that I can in some small way follow in his footsteps and make sure that his hopes for a better future come true.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise, too, for the second time in my short time in this chamber, to pay tribute to the former Leader of the Australian Democrats, Don Chipp. Members of this place may remember that in my maiden speech, just a couple of short weeks ago, I did just that. I did it with great heart and with enormous personal feeling because I believe that Don Chipp has made a major contribution to this Parliament, to the country through his contribution to this Parliament, and in particular-dare I say it-I believe has changed the face of Australian politics by his particularly significant role in the establishment, development and continuation of the Australian Democrats as a significant party on the Australian political scene.

SPEECH.PARA: In my maiden speech I paid tribute to that contribution. For many people out in the community the Australian Democrats were for a very long time-for some, the Democrats continued to be-Don's Party. That was always a short-sighted view; nevertheless, it was perhaps understandable that a figure so strong, so experienced and so passionate on the political scene, should dominate in a new party, a small party and a developing party. While all that was going on, there was this contribution to the new party, one which was significantly different from other political parties and in which it was very important that all members were able and encouraged to participate. Don Chipp played his part in the encouragement of that participation by all other people within the Party to the extent that it has always been a matter of pride to members of the Australian Democrats that all of us have had an equal say; we have had equal value within the Party, as indeed had Don Chipp, our Leader.

Like other senators who have spoken today, and in particular Senator Macklin and Senator Sanders, my own personal involvement in politics is directly as a result of Don Chipp's actions. In resigning from the Liberal Party and in making the points which Don made at that time, and which Senator Macklin outlined, he attracted me as a person who had been interested in politics and current affairs, and who certainly had an enormous interest in the future of this nation. As a mother of four children he attracted me to what seemed to be the likely development of something different in Australian politics. So I made a decision which perhaps too few Australians make, to join a political party. That was the message that Don often had.

I recall his saying at many a public meeting that people should join political parties particularly when he was speaking with young people. He always urged them not to be apathetic, to recognise that this is a democracy that we live in, that we all have the opportunity to participate and that we should participate through the political process. He always said that he was never fussy which party they joined but that, of course, his preference would be that they would join him in the Australian Democrats. I think it was to his credit that he was out there urging people, particularly young people, to take a positive role, not to be apathetic and not to be destructive but to work through the political system for the improvement of this country and for the future.

So it was that having taken the step to become a member of a political party, we were embroiled very quickly in our first Federal election and subsequently many more elections. In Victoria at one stage last year, total Federal and State elections had been almost on an annual basis in the first eight years of this Party's existence. I very quickly got into the whirl of things and subsequently found myself in this place. During that time I obviously spent a lot of time on the campaign trail with Don Chipp. As a Victorian, this happened perhaps more often than it did for some of my colleagues in other States, before I actually came into this chamber. Of course, had I not had to wait, I would have had the benefit of close contact here that they have had and that is a matter of regret to me. I would have enjoyed serving in this Parliament with Don Chipp, rather than after Don Chipp.

During this time he was always very supportive personally and very helpful personally. I would like particularly to place on record the fact that when I as a budding politician, a new candidate, was touring with him in country centres from one end of Victoria to another, at a public meeting where he would be getting all the questions he would always throw some of them in my direction-I have seen him doing this with other candidates-in order that people should have an opportunity to get to know their local candidate better, that they should look beyond Don Chipp and see other Australian Democrats in the arena. As a Victorian, too, and as a former Democrats State President in Victoria, I would like to put on record the fact that it was often difficult for the Democrats in Victoria having to share Don Chipp as parliamentary Leader with the rest of the country. It was, in fact, something which we felt was to our loss because very often our own State senator was not available to us due to his role as the Leader of the Party. We managed, we coped, but we would have liked to have seen more of him in the years that he was leading the Party.

Nevertheless, he did give his all to the Party in our State. The fact that he was a national figure perhaps was brought home most closely to us when, indeed, he did resign and of course there was a sense in which he had to be replaced in the Senate in two ways: Firstly, as the Leader of the Party and, secondly, within Victoria as a Victorian senator. It became rather confusing at one stage, or most of the way through that process, and I think even more confusing since the two people who have replaced him in those roles both happen to be female and both happen to have names which start with Jan. I have had quite a series of experiences in interviews in which the interviewer has begun: `Now that you have become Leader of the Australian Democrats'-and so on. One of the things I always had to do was then explain that Don Chipp had not been just the Leader of the Australian Democrats but, indeed, a senator for Victoria.

Perhaps most notable in my mind about Don Chipp, particularly in the time that I have been associated with him, was the increasing concern and passion that he showed and expressed over time with those issues with which he became so closely associated in the years that he was the Australian Democrats Leader. I remember the passion, indeed, the compassion, which he brought to the issues of major concern to him and to the Australian Democrats-the nuclear issue, the environmental issue that Senator Sanders has referred to, the issues of quality of life, the issues of a better world for all our children. I believe quite firmly that we need more passion, more compassion, in politics and in this place. I identify with his sense of urgency in these areas, very strongly, as a woman, because my motivation in getting into politics was very much the same: The sense that we need to keep these issues very high up on the agenda. We need to spend a lot of time and a lot of energy making sure that they are in the forefront.

I think it is an important model for us all that here was a politician, an individual who, while moving on in life and getting older-as we all do-did not become more conventional, more constrained, more restrained, in the way that we tend to think people will do as they age. I think it is enormously encouraging to have before us an example of someone who was prepared to continue to be in many ways a radical, to really display that sort of passionate concern which is much more associated with youthful people than with people who are of mature years. I think that is the sort of model which is encouraging to young people and it is certainly encouraging to have witnessed it in the political scene.

I am often asked how I feel in filling Don Chipp's shoes. I do not believe that is my role. I do not believe that anyone will ever be able to do that. I have come here to sit in the seat that he has sat in as a Victorian senator. I am very proud to do that because he preceded me; I am proud to do that because I do that as a representative of the Party which he was so instrumental in forming and in nurturing through its first decade. He will be missed; he will be missed by me personally in a political sense and, as I said, I feel I am very unfortunate not to have served in this place with him as Leader.

He will be missed by this Parliament and he will be missed generally in the political scene. As one of my colleagues has said, I believe he is an individual who has a great deal yet to contribute to the Australian society. I conclude by welcoming the opportunity that we have been given today to place on record our very strong personal feelings and the recognition of the contribution that Don Chipp has made.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) is present as I want to refer to a report which I understand has been sent to her. It may well be that with the volume of papers across her desk it is a matter that she has not yet had an opportunity to study. It is a report on the printing industry training requirements in the Australian Capital Territory and regional New South Wales. It comes about subsequent to a report which was prepared in 1983 by the National Printing Industry Training Council as a major project to identify the needs of the printing industry training facilities throughout Australia. It did not include the Australian Capital Territory.

SPEECH.PARA: There are a number of aspects of the printing industry which are significant; relatively Canberra has a smaller number of students, but proportionately much higher cost plant and equipment are needed to train them and for that reason a pro rata share of the available funding of resources is not either adequate or appropriate. The situation at present at the Canberra College of Technical and Further Education is that quite soon final year students will need to go to Sydney for their final year of training. That in itself is a considerable additional cost to the student or to somebody who is to be trained. I would not like to think that printing was not available to students in Canberra because of the run-down of the standard of equipment at our school. Of course, the fact is that it provides training for the printing industry, not just in the Australian Capital Territory but also in regional New South Wales.

It is a good report; it is comprehensive, and it deals with all aspects of the training of people for the printing industry. It goes into detail of costs of training and costs of capital equipment. The summary in the document refers particularly to some quite urgent needs for expenditure. They are quite expensive, but they have been identified under the heading of `Summary', as follows:

In the interim the following alternatives will be investigated . . . that the allocation of time on Australian Capital Territory industry based equipment as and when required and available, and the utilisation of high technology equipment by trade students only at interstate equipment supply centres of State training institutions.

As I said, that in itself involves an additional cost to students if they have to go interstate to complete their courses. There is another section under the heading `Conclusions', and it too needs to be examined. The Council refers to the high capital cost of new equipment. It says:

The Australian Capital Territory should be self- sufficient in terms of acquiring the necessary equipment to satisfy both basic and advanced training levels. There have been significant technological changes in the printing industry. To continue to train students on outdated equipment is probably just about in the same category as not training them at all. They need to keep up with the type of equipment that is used. This Committee refers to the funding inequities that have existed previously which must be addressed by the development and apportioning of the appropriate funding, precommitted over defined time periods.

There are other matters in the paragraph I have referred to as conclusions which I would wish to draw to the Minister's attention. In the cooking school at the Canberra College of Technical and Further Education there are needs to enable the school more efficiently to meet the demands which are being made upon it. The same applies in the area of plumbing training. The point is that these are all areas where young people can in fact get jobs when they have been properly trained. I want to say not so much that I think it is a question of more money, but that we should be very sure that we have our priorities right, and that we get the right money into the areas where young people can get training and get jobs.

Although the general level of unemployment is much lower in Canberra than in other parts of this country, the youth unemployment which does exist here is at a high level. So it is important for training in these areas where jobs become available that a high priority of expenditure in the area needs to be given. The committee which prepared this report also went on to a section of recommendations about adequate funding, adequate staffing levels and the necessary building modifications. I merely wish to say to the Minister that amongst the many reports that have come to her, I commend this report to her, and I hope that she will be able to see that the needs in the area of technical training will be of the very highest level so that young people in this Territory will not be disadvantaged in any way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to address what I consider to be a very serious deficiency in the Government's international approach, and that is to the question of exports. In recent days, in the name of alleged economic stringency, the decision has been taken to close the Australian Embassy in Peru. At the present time, we have four operative embassies in Argentina, Brazil, Venezuela and Chile. There are three trade commissions-in Argentina, Brazil and Venezuela. Our trade with South America is such that we have a massive trade imbalance, of the order of $100m. Our exports total less than $300m; our imports are in excess of $400m. With Brazil in particular, we have exports totalling $98m, whereas we import something of the order of $245m.

SPEECH.PARA: There are remarkable business opportunities in South America. By and large, the continent has returned to democratic rule. The attitude adopted by most South American countries is such that there are very many trade opportunities for Australia; yet what the Government is proposing to do at the present time is to severely limit the opportunities for exporters in that region.

It is not just the symbolism that derives from the closure of Peru, which in a sense is one of our smaller trading partners. Our exports to Peru are of the order of $14.2m, our imports are $4.9m. So that is not quite the same order of magnitude as Brazil. But it is highly insulting, for example, to think that now persons requiring visas and other consulate treatment must attend on the embassies in Buenos Aires or Santiago. Chile, I would have thought, is one country where there would be a great reluctance for Australians to be actively involved or for anyone else on that continent to be actively involved, given the gross denial of human rights in that region, its very restrictive and repressive treatment of its citizens. To expect that Peruvian citizens will now have to approach the embassy in Chile is a gross insult to those citizens. But more importantly on the trading front, now that we are vacating the field we will be leaving New Zealand to run riot.

In many ways it can be said that New Zealand is well ahead of Australia in terms of trade and economic reform. We have seen in recent times its taxation reform measures which have resulted in the almost painless introduction of a goods and services tax, in marked contrast to the inability of the Government in this country to move towards option C or anything like it and to have effectively thrown in the towel because it was all too hard. New Zealand is embarking on a significant program of corporatisation, which is undoubtedly a first measure in the step towards wider privatisation. It is being done by a Labor government, it is being done in recognition of the need to have a much more efficient and productive economy. Its industrial relations scene is undergoing marked transformation and in many ways New Zealanders are getting their economy into shape when we are neglecting the same opportunities.

So it is in trade, and from now on, no doubt, New Zealanders will be rubbing their hands with glee because of the increased opportunities on the South American continent. In terms of the amount of export assistance that the Government gives, again it is very depressing to think that in the name of economic stringency the opportunity has been taken to impose very severe restrictions on the level of incentive and assistance provided to private sector exporters. In the Budget the total assistance to export industries is down by $56.9m, a reduction of some 19 per cent. I presume the Government would say that that has been the rough equivalent effect of last year's devaluation and therefore it is on a par. What it does not do, of course, is to recognise that there is an increasing need to encourage exports to remedy the massive current account deficit of $14.3 billion and, given that in the previous financial year we were able to increase the total assistance to export industries, there seems no reason at all why exports should have suffered in this manner this year.

What has happened in the Budget is that export and trade promotion has been increased by precisely the amount of the overall decrease and the massive slash has been in the area of export market development schemes. Whilst one can argue that it is necessary for exporters to come up with schemes that will be able to stand on their own merits without government assistance, the fact remains that in an imperfect world there are very many other countries which are prepared to provide quite significant degrees of assistance. Certainly in the area of private sector assistance, it would be my view that there are a number of opportunities for the Government to assist in trading in the South American continent. But even if one accepts the proposition that industry should be required to bear its own expenses, and as we know the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has repeatedly ruled out the reintro- duction of entertainment expenses for overseas export drives, the fact remains that the very least that could have been done by the Government was to ensure that our diplomatic representation was maintained and, hopefully, expanded; but the opposite is the case.

We are now being faced with the very demeaning and demoralising sight of the goods and chattels of our Peruvian Embassy being put up for public auction. Presumably they will sell for a pittance, but the demonstration effect of that one would have thought to be highly insulting to the Peruvians and a marked insult to those who have worked in the Embassy. It might have been understandable if the Embassy had simply been scaled down, but what is going to happen is that a local national will be retained to keep an eye on trade at the very lowest level; otherwise the Embassy will be completely closed down. There will be no charge-d'affaires or any other diplomatic representative in attendance and, of course, the re-opening expenses if and when we were prepared to restore the relationship would be much greater than they would be if we had simply scaled down.

This, of course, is compounded by the news from Brazil where it now appears that all staff of the Australian Embassy in Brazil have asked to be withdrawn because of the massive reductions in allowances and expenses. One mission member is reported to have said that his $15,000 allowance has been slashed to $5,000. But perhaps the greatest insult of all is this: Staff calculations are that the Australian Ambassador in Brasilia will now get less than half the take-home salary of the British or Swedish counsellor and will earn less than a stenographer at the Swedish Embassy. You really cannot have a more degrading situation than that.

TALK.START.PARA: —We truly are a banana republic.

—We can hardly afford the skins, let alone to go on supporting the activities of our own diplomats. If that is a prelude to the threatened strike within the Department of Foreign Affairs and perhaps large scale resignations, it will be simply a matter that the Government would easily have foreseen but has deliberately embarked upon again in the name of cost cutting. All I can say is that it strikes me that this is an entirely short-sighted and counter-productive measure. It goes against all that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and others have been saying. It is in defiance of the export drive which has just been launched. It is perhaps consistent with the Buy Australia campaign because it is an inward-looking, autarkic approach to economics rather than any attempt to get out there and promote exports, to get out there and ensure that we have diplomatic representatives and trade counsellors who are looking for increased opportunities.

SPEECH.PARA: Almost every other nation in the world is out there fighting. Even in terms of our overseas aid program there are very many opportunities for that to complement our trade initiatives but, by and large, we have neglected those opportunities. We see that the Japanese are proposing to double their total level of development assistance by 1990. Brazil, in particular, has made massive intrusions into trade on the African continent as a result of its outward looking aid program.

So in many ways I think one can say that the Government's approach to international affairs, the approach to balancing the current account is simply myopic, short-sighted and ultimately counter-productive. It is a matter of great regret to me that these facts are not self-evident, that the Government was not able simply to scale down diplomatic representation if that was the requirement; but to have gone the way it has and to have embarked on a program of squeezing embassies around the world until they squeal has undoubtedly resulted in the outcry from Brazil.
