It has not yet provoked any similar response from Peru, but no doubt if the diplomats there were asked their opinion they would certainly agree that it is about the last thing that the Australian current account requires at the present time. All I can say in conclusion is that if the Government is serious in its desire to expand trade to South America, it will again reconsider the position of the Australian Embassy in Peru. If it really wants to get trade going again in that region, it will immediately re-open it.
Sitting suspended from 1.25 to 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. The Minister will recall that, in answer to my question on Tuesday, he was at great pains to separate the principle of the fringe benefits tax from problems of administration. Since then the Prime Minister has said that changes will be made to some of the substance of the tax, as well as to the way in which it is being applied. Is the Minister aware that on the Carleton-Walsh Report last night the Prime Minister specifically ruled out exemptions from the tax for school fees, cars, low interest loans, hostess allowances and the use of credit cards? How will the Government decide what is to be changed and what is to remain within the reach of the Act? In other words, what criteria or principle will be applied to determine the changes of substance which are to be made?
—Those questions are a matter for the review which has been announced. When that review completes its deliberations, everybody will be told the answers.

—I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Leader of the Government in the Senate for his mercifully brief answer. Is he saying, then, that there is no principle which has been decided by a meeting of Ministers, a Cabinet group or any other group, to determine the limits of this review?
—I refer to the answer I have already given. It is pretty clear, and when the review is completed the answers will be clear.

—Has the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Health been drawn to recent negative statements by the Queensland Minister for Health and Environment, Mr Brian Austin, detailing his Government's refusal to participate in the national preventive education program on the control of the acquired immune deficiency syndrome virus? What impact will this failure to co-operate have on the Federal Government's national program to educate at-risk groups about AIDS? Can any steps be taken to make the Queensland Government more responsible about this very serious health issue?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the statements made by Mr Austin, as has my colleague the Minister for Health, Dr Blewett. The point that must be made about this problem that we face in this country is that, by and large, State governments and the Federal Government are co-operating in an effort to alleviate the effects of AIDS and to reduce the spread of AIDS. The important point is that it is not a political issue, other than that political action and political co-operation are needed. It is not, despite what people such as the Reverend Fred Nile would believe, primarily a moral or a State issue; it is a public health issue.
—Not retribution.

—Like Senator Baume, I do not believe it is a matter of retribution. I do not believe it is a modern equivalent of the black plague put down on us from on high; nor do I or my colleague Dr Blewett believe that we can cope with this problem sensibly by ignoring the facts about it, hoping, therefore, that the whole problem will go away.

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Austin's statement, which has been condemned by newspapers and commentators throughout the country, seems to be contrary to the co-operative spirit that we have in this country in the fight against AIDS. In, I think, May last year the Health Ministers Conference endorsed a national health strategy to cope with this problem. The various communities affected, in particular the gay community, have worked very hard, not only to prevent the unnecessary spread of the disease but also to provide support groups for those unfortunate individuals who progress to the last stages of AIDS and die. The Health Ministers Conference agreed that having information and education programs for at-risk groups was a sensible way to go about it, and that they should be developed in conjunction with those target groups so that the right information is given out.

I know that a significant number of senators and members on both sides of the Parliament have expressed concern that the Queensland Government has decided, because of its rigid attitude in this area, to refuse to send out the education pamphlets and has refused to take part in this education campaign, on the spurious grounds that such a campaign would encourage what it sees as deviant behaviour. This is very unfortunate. I think that those senators and members-as well as the many medical practitioners throughout the country-who are concerned about this program and have indicated that they will write to Mr Austin should do so in an endeavour to change the Queensland Government's attitude to this very real problem.

Senator Peter Baume, in writing a report some years ago on welfare problems, used this quote from Browning at the start of the report: `Ignorance is not innocence, but sin'. The public espousal of ignorance in this area is a sin. It will inhibit considerably our capacity to limit the extent of this disease. It is important that we do so because it seems unlikely that either a cure or an effective vaccine will be available in the near future. I am not saying that it will not be available at all, but it will not be available in the near future. It seems that it is a fair way off. In those circumstances, the best weapon we have in trying to contain the disease is through preventive education and through people taking preventative action. I think it is most unfortunate that a Minister such as Mr Austin should take the view that our education program should be limited by his rather narrow view of the world. I think we should do all we can to bring Queensland into line with the rest of the country in this regard.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer to the fact that the Government announced its fringe benefits tax 13 months ago and then took eight months to have the legislation drafted and put through Parliament. Is the Minister aware that last night on a television program the Prime Minister said he thought that some of the changes to the tax would involve legislation?
—Last week you said it was rushed and in haste.

—Is the Government seriously asking the people of Australia to believe that it can rectify all the administrative problems and make changes to legislation in less than three weeks before the first payments are due? Will the Government agree to either defer the payment date or ask the Commissioner of Taxation to grant a general extension of time to relieve taxpayers of the impossible task of making assessments and submitting returns when the rules are about to change?

—I am reminded that we have been charged with rushing this legislation through the Parliament. On this occasion the charge is delay in presenting the legislation. As I said to Senator Chaney earlier, a review will be conducted. I do not know whether that review will lead to any proposed changes in legislation. That remains to be seen.
—What about the changes-

—I said I do not know whether that review will lead to any changes in the legislation. That remains to be seen. Honourable senators opposite can wait patiently and, when the review is completed, decisions will be announced. With regard to instructions to the Taxation Commissioner, as I understand it, the Taxation Commissioner already has a wide range of discretions in respect of the implementation of any tax measure, and particularly in respect of time for payment and so on. Whether it is appropriate at the end of the review for the Taxation Commissioner to exercise that discretion will be decided in the course of the review.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. The Minister obviously did not understand the point that I made. I will read him a transcript from the Carleton interview. Mr Richard Carleton asked:

QUESTION.PARA: Are the changes you contemplate likely to involve legislation or will they get through in another way?
I think there will be some that will involve legislation, some statutory rules, and some in administration.

My question quite clearly was: In view of the fact that the Prime Minister anticipates that there will be legislative changes, will the Minister address the consequences of the Prime Minister's statement?

TALK.START.PARA: —I can hear the honourable senator's question; I do not know whether he can read it intelligently. The Prime Minister did not say that there would be legislative changes necessarily. I repeat what I said earlier: One awaits the outcome of the review to decide that question. That will be done.
—You wouldn't have a clue, would you.
—Honourable senators opposite should not get too excited-they who are committed to abolishing, root and branch--
—Lock, stock and barrel.

—Lock, stock and barrel-I suppose that is a better appellation for people such as them. Root and branch was what they did in Government with the tax legislation-or the first part, anyway. The fact of the matter is that honourable senators opposite who are committed to abolishing the whole legislation are-
—You don't know what you are doing, do you.

—I really do not know what they are doing because their actions are quite contrary to the principles enunciated by their tentative leader and by shadow Ministers. If honourable senators opposite want to sort that out in that way by an abrogation of principle, they can persist with that policy; but it is not a matter which concerns us particularly, or the people of Australia, I suspect.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. Has the decision of the Government to allow gambling and other related activities on Australian National trains operating in South Australia, Western Australia and the Northern Territory been taken after due consultation with the State and Territory governments concerned? Will the Minister indicate a possible timetable for legislative changes and indicate the specific arrangements for parliamentary scrutiny to be included in the legislation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been some publicity about the proposals of the national Government to permit some improvements in the leisure facilities on routes serviced by Australian National. The Government therefore proposes to amend the Australian National Railways Commission Act 1983 in the autumn session of 1987 to enable Australian National to provide a broader range of services and entertainment, including gambling, for its passengers using those services in Western Australia, South Australia and the Northern Territory. The Government has taken these steps to provide some leisure outlets because of the long distances involved and so that the objectives of Australian National and the Commonwealth can be realised. The passenger services conducted by Australian National currently lose about $30m a year. The amendments are part of an overall strategy worked out by the Commonwealth to improve the viability of track and passenger services and thereby reduce the contribution of Commonwealth funds to the maintenance of those services.

ANSWER.PARA: It is true that the gambling proposal attracted some media attention, but it is only part of the wider package designed by Australian National to make the passenger services more attractive. The suggested facilities-I understand that consultations are taking place with the States so that there is agreement on these matters-will include video and sound booths for hire, card tables, a hair salon, as well as bingo, keno and poker machines. So passengers will have quite a range of leisure activities available to them.

The Government has set itself a 60 per cent cost recovery target for Australian National passenger services by 1988-89. I stress that gambling activities will be available only to Australian National passengers. It is hoped that as a result of these proposals there will be a much reduced call on taxpayers' funds in real terms. The Government has set itself this objective. Already the Government's attempts to improve the services have resulted in a reduction of Commonwealth funding for Australian National of some 50 per cent since 1982-83. We propose to take steps to see that that is reduced even further by 1988-89.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. I draw the Minister's attention to the fact that the USS Paul F. Foster, which arrived in Melbourne today, and the HMS Amazon, which docked in Geelong today, are both nuclear armed. I refer also to the 18 September statement by the Victorian Premier, Mr Cain, in which he refused to accept responsibility for dealing with nuclear weapons accidents in Victorian ports and explicitly handed that responsibility to the Commonwealth. I ask the Minister: First, does the Federal Government accept responsibility for dealing with a nuclear weapons accident in Geelong or Melbourne; secondly, are Federal authorities now monitoring radioactivity levels to detect any release of radioactive material; and thirdly, what emergency procedures have been implemented to cope with such a release?

—I was given some notice of this question-I am not sure exactly when, but it was not very long before Question Time. I have not been able to get any response from the Minister for Defence; so, effectively, I will have to take it on notice.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. Recently the South Australian Attorney-General published some figures on inadequate court sentences under section 99 of the Justices Act. Those figures show that almost one-third of the people convicted received no penalty at all, a further 39 per cent received fines averaging a little more than $100, and only three people were imprisoned. Given that the Family Law Act has provisions for injunctions to protect women in domestic violence situations, can the Minister say whether the results under the Federal legislation are the same? Can he say how many injunctions are sought in each State and Territory; how many of these are repeat applications; how many of these applicants have lapsed; what penalties are imposed on the offenders; is there any evaluation of the outcome of injunctions; and is the Minister satisfied with the situation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a note about this which is about five pages long. It must have been written by a lawyer. If the Senate is agreeable, I will seek to incorporate all of it. However, I can give some of the highlights. For the 1985 calendar year there were 4,265 applications for injunctive orders. The Family Law Council report for 1984-85 disclosed the following numbers of applications for injunctions since 1 January 1980: In 1980, 4,688; 1981, 4,848; 1982, 5,019; 1983, 4,790; and 1984, 4,501. To examine all the relevant files to extract the information sought would be a lengthy task requiring the cessation of almost all clerical work in every registry for a lengthy period or the provision of substantial additional resources. To virtually close the registries is impractical, and the Government is not prepared to make the additional resources available. There is a good deal more information about penalties and so on which I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

The Registries of the Family Court of Australia are to be computerised within the next 18 months and details of this nature should then be readily available from Registries in each State and the Australian Capital Territory.
The penalties that can be imposed for contravention of an injunction are contained in sub-section 114 (4) of the Act as follows-

``114 (4) [Penalties for non-compliance] If a court having jurisdiction under this Act is satisfied that a person has knowingly and without reasonable cause contravened or failed to comply with an injunction or order under this section, that court may-
(a) order that person to pay a fine not exceeding $1,000;

(b) require that person to enter into a recognizance, with or without sureties, in such reasonable amount as the court thinks fit, that he will comply with the injunction or order, or order him to be imprisoned until he enters into such a recognizance or until the expiration of 3 months, whichever first occurs;
(c) order that person to deliver up to the court such documents as the court thinks fit; and
(d) make such other orders as the court considers necessary to enforce compliance with the injunction or order.''

In addition, a person may be dealt with for contempt constituted by wilful disobedience of an injunction. A person in contempt may be punished by committal to prison, a fine or the giving of security for good behaviour.

An internal management survey of the 353 injunctive orders sought in the Brisbane Registry of the Family Court between October 1980 and March 1981 was completed by a Court Counsellor in 1981. The recommendations in the report centred on greater use of counselling facilities and the elimination of delays in hearing such applications. So far as is possible, the recommendations have been implemented in each Registry.

Criminal laws on domestic violence, similar to s.99 of the Justices Act (S.A.), now exist in NSW, Queensland, Victoria, WA and the ACT. The operation of these laws is specifically preserved by s.114ab of the Family Law Act. A person cannot take proceedings for an injunction of the Family Law Act where action has been taken under these State and Territory criminal laws. The Attorney-General considers that these criminal procedures are a more appropriate method of providing strict measures to deal with domestic violence than the civil procedures in the Family Law Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. The Minister will be aware that the Prime Minister said on the Willesee program yesterday that the Government will `listen to what others have got to say' about the fringe benefits tax and make changes to some areas of substance and administration by the end of the month. Exactly who will conduct the promised review, when will it begin and will it be a full and open inquiry to which members of the public will be invited, or able to make submissions?

—The review will be conducted under the auspices of the departments of Prime Minister and Cabinet and Treasury. I am not able to say precisely who will be invited but I will seek that information for the honourable senator and provide him with an answer as soon as possible.

—Has the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Communications been drawn to an article in yesterday's Australian Financial Review titled `New Right communication plan may start Opposition row'? If so, can the Minister provide an assessment of Andrew Hay's policy prescriptions for the communications portfolio?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the article in yesterday's Australian Financial Review, which reports another foray into a different area of policy making by one of the numerous extra-parliamentary pretenders to leadership of the Liberal Party, to wit, Mr Hay. He said, amongst other things, that the Department of Communications should be abolished and, I presume, replaced by a ministry for propaganda and public enlightenment, in accordance with the precedent set by an historical figure who shared a number of views with Mr Hay.

ANSWER.PARA: The other thing Mr Hay proposed and said that the Liberal Party ought immediately to adopt as policy-that ultimatum having been issued, I assume it very soon will be adopted as policy by the Liberal Party-is that private sector cream skimming ought to be introduced for Telecom Australia, Australia Post and the Overseas Telecommunications Commission. What that means, of course, is that all the innately profitable areas in which those three public bodies provide services should be sold off to some of Mr Hay's friends or somebody else who is influential in the Liberal Party. Of course, that would then prevent Australia Post and Telecom from providing services in those areas of the country where the provision of services is innately unprofitable, and that is virtually every part of Australia other than the major cities. I would be interested to know what the National Party thinks about that ultimatum Mr Hay has now delivered to the Liberal Party. Mr Hay also said that the powers of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal should be curtailed in the areas of advertising and programming content, including children's programming and Australian content. I assume that under Mr Hay's proposal anything anybody wants telecast would be telecast. He also suggested that the Department of Communications should be abolished, as I mentioned previously.

However, even though Mr Hay's position in the political spectrum is becoming increasingly well known, there should be no thought that his speech represents only the delusions of one rather peripheral figure. On the contrary, it is an open secret around the Parliament and in other places that many of the ideas in Mr Hay's speech have been spoken of within the offices of the honourable member for Bennelong and the honourable member for Mackellar. One can only suspect that Mr Hay's speech, in its content and its timing, has been cynically contrived to sink the draft policy on communications of the honourable member for Goldstein which is in marked opposition to almost every line in Mr Hay's speech. That is one of the many conflicts within the Liberal Party. For as long as the honourable member for Bennelong remains Leader-I do not expect that he will be Leader for much longer-Mr Hay's views will triumph and the honourable member for Goldstein will be overruled.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Firstly, does the Minister welcome the Australian Council of Trade Unions' acceptance of the need to move away from full wage indexation towards a more flexible system of wage determination? Secondly, does he share Mr Simon Crean's enthusiasm for a campaign to link business investment and industry policy to any new approach to wage fixation? Thirdly, does he see any merit in suggestions for legislative moves by the Government to pressure employers to lift investment in the domestic economy? Fourthly, does he agree that the Budget prediction of a one per cent decline in private fixed capital investment and the continued reluctance of business to embark on substantial investment projects are indicative of a lack of confidence in the health of the economy and the unlikely prospect of moderation in the price increases of all factors of production rather than mere ideological intransigence?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable senator asked whether I welcomed the ACTU move to depart from full wage indexation as announced by Mr Crean, as I understand it. That announcement is consistent with Government policy, which was announced in the Budget. The Government made it quite clear in the Budget context that it would seek a 2 per cent discount in the next national wage case, and the statement made by Mr Crean is consistent with that.

ANSWER.PARA: I was next asked about the linkage between investment and wage policy changes. That is something which perhaps can be talked about between the parties. I think the fundamental determinant of investment in respect of wages is a degree of predictability and continuity in the wage environment, something that business has had since this Government came to office and is likely to have in the future. I think that is the most important element of that link.

I was also asked whether there was a proposal about legislation to encourage or pressure people to invest. I would have doubts about the efficacy of such legislation. I was then asked about the Budget prediction of a one per cent decline in fixed capital investment. I believe that to have been for a variety of reasons which the Budget itself sought in part to address. The Government has made no secret of the fact that we expected a decline in the growth rate which this country has experienced for the last two or three years and that, accompanied by relatively high interest rates, which has been a matter of considerable discussion in the Senate over time, I think is a factor which has militated against a stronger investment performance.

I must say that, in the context of Senator Alston's question, I would divine the mood of the business community generally as being considerably more optimistic in the last two or three weeks than it has been for some time. I believe that optimism will be sustained as the Budget strategy increasingly takes effect.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Education. On 22 September the Minister advised that Mr Errol West, her chief adviser on Aboriginal education, had gone to the Northern Territory to discuss the handover of Kormilda College to the Presbyterian Church. I ask: Has Mr West submitted a report on his visit? If so, will the Minister indicate Mr West's assessment of the appropriateness of that move?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have a written report from Mr West but we did have some discussions about developments in the Northern Territory with regard to Kormilda College. In brief, the situation is not resolved. The original proposal of the Northern Territory Government to hand over the administration of the college to the Presbyterian Church seems to have fallen through. The responsible Northern Territory Minister, Mr Manzie, is discussing with the Aboriginal community and other groups the possibility of some sort of Aboriginal administration of the college. If that is the case, the Commonwealth would be delighted to co-operate. The college was established by the Commonwealth some years ago as a boarding and educational facility for remote area Aboriginal students and it would be against the Commonwealth's intention for the college to operate in such a way that Aboriginal students could get no benefit from it.

ANSWER.PARA: There has been no final outcome of the discussions. I express on the record my hope that there will be improvements in the operation of Kormilda College and that they will be such as to encourage the participation of the young Aboriginal people for whom it was intended.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Leader of the Government in the Senate to the Government's promised tax cuts which, as outlined, will be introduced in July 1987. I ask: First, will the Government give an unequivocal assurance that these tax cuts will be implemented in full on that date; and, secondly, will the Government also give an assurance that these tax cuts will not be either diminished or offset by increased indirect taxes in either a mini-Budget or in the 1987-88 Budget?
—The revenue mix in any Budget is determined by the Government, not by me.
—What a shame.

—I think so too. From time to time governments make decisions about mixes in the revenue, and this Government is no exception. Maybe this Government will, maybe it will not; it depends on the circumstances.
—Like abandoning the unintended consequences.
—Dopey, why don't you go back to sleep?
—Order! I ask the Minister to withdraw that remark.
—I beg your pardon, Mr President, I withdraw. Insofar as Senator Sir John Carrick's question about the tax cuts is concerned, yes, they will be delivered in December this year and July next year.

—Has the Minister for Finance received a reply to his letters to the Queensland Premier regarding the possible abuse of funds under the natural disaster relief arrangements? In particular, has he received any advice on the $145,000 advanced to Mr Michael Behan and the $168,250 claimed by Mr Ken Morris? If the Minister has not received any reply on these matters from the Queensland Premier, what further action is he contemplating?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Black's question referred to possible abuse of funds under the NDRA. I do not think that is strong enough because at least in the case of Mr Behan it seems to me that there is not a possibility of there having been abuse; there is a clear case that there was abuse in Queensland's administration of the NDRA. Commonwealth funds, which are supposed to be administered according to guidelines which I issued last year, were paid to Mr Behan-who was a National Party candidate and is presently a National Party employee-despite the recommendation from the Rural Adjustment Board and the Agricultural Bank in Queensland that Mr Behan's application should not be approved and that Mr Behan was non-viable. I do not think it is a question of possibility of abuse; there is a very clear and documented case of abuse in that instance. In the other specific case, involving Mr Morris, the evidence is less clear simply because the evidence is not available.
—You have got your left eye closed.

—In answer to the rest of Senator Black's question I have not had any formal reply from the Premier to the two letters I have written, one concerning Mr Behan and the other concerning Mr Morris, but there have been some garbled responses in the media which indicate that he has no intention of replying. May I say how astounded I am that Senator Chaney seems determined to protect the corruption of the Queensland State Government when the President of the Liberal Party in Brisbane is describing the State Government in those very terms. He accurately describes the Queensland State Government as corrupt. The President of the Liberal Party in Queensland says that, yet Senator Chaney tries to protect the Queensland State Government in the Senate. It is no surprise to me that the Premier has indicated that he will not reply, because an inadequate reply would be likely to implicate other key figures in the Queensland branch of the National Party.

ANSWER.PARA: On the second occasion on which I wrote to the Premier, concerning Mr Morris, I offered to make representations to the Special Minister of State to provide Federal Police assistance for investigations into any cases where NDRA funds may have been obtained by fraud. I would expect the last thing that the Premier of Queensland would want would be for the Australian Federal Police to go up to Queensland ferreting out the facts about the Queensland State Government's administration of NDRA money. So I do not expect that I will be asked by the Premier to approach Mr Young for Federal Police assistance to ferret out the facts. The problem is that the Commonwealth is not responsible for the administration of individual loans under NDRA. It is self-evident that if the Queensland Government had nothing to hide, it would be meeting my request to supply more information about individual loans which have been granted.

Finally, Senator Black asked what I intend to do. At this stage I have not decided, but I may be taking a recommendation to Cabinet in the next couple of weeks, assuming we do not get a satisfactory reply from Queensland. I do not expect to get a satisfactory reply from Queensland given the coded messages, or garbled messages, that seem to have been coming from the Premier. If no replies are received in the next couple of weeks I will have to consider taking the matter to Cabinet for decision.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask the Minister to table the paper from which he quoted in answering that question.
—The Minister has tabled the document.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: FREMANTLE GAS AND COKE CO. LTD

TALK.START.PARA: —In the light of the answer from the Minister for Finance on the situation in Queensland, has he yet directed his attention to the situation in Western Australia? Has he seen the call for an inquiry into the State Government's involvement in the sale of Fremantle Gas and Coke Co. Ltd? Does he intend to examine that matter in the way he has examined the matters in Queensland? Will he turn his great concerns about proper public and financial administration to those States which have Labor governments; in particular, the State of Western Australia and that matter which has been drawn to his attention on an earlier occasion?

—I do not have any intention of so doing and there are two very good reasons for that. The first, of course, is that there is not the slightest suggestion, let alone any evidence, that the Premier of Western Australia has received a $400,000 sling from a media magnate in anticipation of favours about to be granted, nor is there the slightest suggestion that the Premier's son had $5m of taxpayers' money spent on building a dam.

—I raise a point of order, Mr President. The Minister's last comment is undoubtedly in breach of the Standing Orders. Since occasionally the Minister deals with matters which are given some protection by Standing Orders I think we should take advantage of that and he should be asked to withdraw.
—Under standing order 418, I ask the Minister to withdraw the imputation in his comment.

—Very well, Mr President, I withdraw the imputation. The facts speak for themselves. The other even more fundamental reason is that although Senator Chaney sees some irregularity in the Western Australian Government's administration and disposal or purchase of property in Western Australia, it is not using Federal money. Queensland, under the NDRA, is.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. What measures are provided by the Government to assist and encourage Australian exporters of manufactured goods and services?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday the Minister for Trade announced a new export drive. In launching this new export drive he referred to a number of matters currently under investigation and a number of proposals being implemented by the Government in respect of export activity. Prior to that announcement, a number of initiatives were already in place aimed at increasing Australia's export of manufactured goods and services. The establishment of the Australian Trade Commissioner Service in January 1986 led to the integration of a broad range of trade and trade support functions into one operating entity with a strong commercial orientation. The Executive Director of Austrade, Mr Lindsay MacAlister, who has a strong commercial background, is implementing those things which were announced at the time of its establishment.

ANSWER.PARA: Total financial assistance to export industries for 1986-87 is estimated to be about $243m, which includes $92m for the export market development grants scheme. A high technology exporters scheme is to be established under the new initiatives to provide grants for overseas market development to firms producing high technology products. The sum of $2m has been allocated to the publicity and promotional activities associated with the national export drive aimed at improving export investment, production and marketing. Austrade is also developing some specifically directed assistance for promotion of particular products into selected markets.

A number of strategies have also been developed in relation to particular markets, notably the China action plan. Similar plans are being developed in relation to particular geographical areas, including the Middle East, Europe, North America and Japan. Extensive market support is also available under the Australia-New Zealand closer economic relations trade agreement.

The Prime Minister also announced on 17 September that there would be a special sub-committee of Cabinet to oversee a series of reviews on the effect of domestic policies on trade competitiveness. That initiative is being taken in recognition of the particular priority which should be given in the present circumstances to removing outmoded, ineffective or misconceived policies which are inhibiting the development of internationally competitive industries. A series of reports will be brought forward to the sub-committee for consideration and topics covered will include domestic and international transport, export controls, export inspection, foreign investment and tariff and tax induced input cost burdens. These market strategies to which I refer involve a targeted approach to export development designed to assist Australian firms to develop commercial opportunities or to capitalise on potentially large markets.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. In light of the review of the fringe benefits tax by the Prime Minister and the fact that the Australian Taxation Office has not yet been told how the review will be handled, when it will be finished and who will have the final say in the cleaning up of the tax, what advice does the Minister give to those who will be travelling in the next fortnight and so will be unable to make out their fringe benefits tax forms later than this week?
—I do not know what Senator Walters is referring to when she says that the Taxation Office has not been told. That statement is just silly. I refute it as a matter of fact.
—It wasn't silly on Tuesday.
—Of course not. The announcement was made on Tuesday. I am asked what advice I would give to somebody travelling this month. I advise people travelling this month to obey the law, whatever it may be.
—I ask a supplementary question. Can the Minister tell me what the law is?
—Order! The honourable senator is not entitled to seek a legal opinion at Question Time.

—I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Communications whether his attention has been drawn to the National Party of Australia advertisements in Queensland using television footage of Australian rugby league skipper Wally Lewis-a confirmed supporter, I might say, of the Australian Labor Party-in its advertising on television in the run-up to the 1 November State election. I also ask: In view of Wally Lewis's subsequent objections to this, what protections are available to individuals against such gross intrusions on personal liberties by the Bjelke-Petersen Government and the National Party Administration in Queensland?

—I am advised by the Minister for Communications that virtually all advertisements which appear on commercial television are submitted to the Commercial Acceptance Division of the Federation of Australian Commercial Television Stations for accreditation. On this occasion the advertisement in question was submitted to the CAD and conforms with the provisions of both the Broadcasting Act and the Electoral Act. As such, the advertisement was approved by FACTS for screening. As far as I am aware, no formal complaint has been lodged with the Minister for Communications or the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal concerning the advertisement. It would seem, however, from that advice that as far as the Broadcasting Act and the Electoral Act are concerned the advertisement in question does not breach the law. If that is the case-I heard Mr Lewis's protests on AM this morning about the unauthorised use of his name in association with the Queensland campaign and movie footage of him receiving a cup from the Premier; Mr Lewis is understandably very annoyed at having had, albeit in a subliminal way, his political affiliations misrepresented in the way that they have been-nothing can be done under the Electoral Act or the Broadcasting Act. The only thing I can suggest is that Mr Lewis should seek advice as to whether he has an action for libel. Personally, I cannot imagine anything more libellous than to have been associated by anybody with the National Party Government of Queensland.
—He might get $400,000.
—I was just about to say that. With a bit of luck, Mr Lewis might get the $400,000 from Mr Bjelke-Petersen which he in turn extorted from Alan Bond.
—Order! I ask the Minister to withdraw that imputation.
—I withdraw the word `extorted' and refer to the sum that he received from Mr Bond.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Education. Is it the Government's intended or unintended outcome that the fringe benefits tax places new tax penalties on education institutions? I cite three examples: First, resident tutors and teachers who are provided with accommodation in tertiary colleges and schools; secondly, discounted or free tuition for the children of staff of independent schools; and, thirdly, meals provided to school staff at school functions.
—Those and associated matters are under review.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Health aware that the Australian Medical Association has issued posters stating that due to the deferral of doctors' fee increases `patients such as health card holders, who in the past have received service without cost, may find they now have to pay something out of their own pockets'? Is there any justification for this statement? In what circumstances would health card holders need to pay part of the cost of treatment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have--
—Doctor bashing, is it?

—Yes, doctor bashing! Any criticism in this place of any medical practitioner anywhere is doctor bashing, according to Senator Baume. The AMA has produced posters indicating that medical practitioners would be justified, in its view, in imposing on health card holders extra charges for medical treatment. I think that is a pity. The AMA has reversed its long-standing policy of asking its members to direct bill pensioners and other health card recipients. It advises doctors in notifications to them to charge in accordance with their circumstances and the patient's circumstances.

ANSWER.PARA: No group is more jealous of its position in the community than the colleagues of Senator Peter Baume, Senator Crowley and I in the medical profession. They object very strongly when anyone suggests that anyone outside the medical profession who has been trained medically should have any capacity or ability to take over their role in the diagnosis and treatment of medical disorders. Yet they are advising members of their Association to assess their patients' financial circumstances. Doctors are apparently supposed to say to their patients: `How much do you have in the bank? How much are you earning? How much do you have invested?' As a result, the doctor, the medical practitioner, who has no training in this area at all, is apparently to judge how much he or she should charge that patient. I suggest that it is very strange that a profession that, for so long, has so jealously guarded the monopoly that it believes it should have in another area should want to intrude into that area for which it has had no training.

I think it is a pity that the Australian Medical Association has resiled from its long-standing policy in this area of direct billing pensioner card recipients and other health card recipients in this country. The AMA's action follows the Government's deferral of schedule fee increases from 1 October 1986 to 1 November 1986 as part of the Budget strategy of restraint with equity-restraint across the board. I also remind honourable senators that no one in this community more than the medical profession wanders around the place demanding that we cut government expenditure, that people should pull in their belts and that the Government stop spending money in the way it has been and stop providing the services it has been. But as soon as the medical profession or representatives of the medical profession are asked to pull in their belts a little for a couple of months we get this ridiculous reply.

The Government has no constitutional power to control doctors' fees. Everyone in this place knows that and the medical profession knows that. I know that the AMA initially was supportive of the deferral of medical fee increases and the AMA representative at the time said that most doctors would not increase their charges. In fact, they will not increase their charges. Most medical practitioners will continue to provide these services without extra charge to the disadvantaged patients that they are serving. I think we must be reminded that doctors are amongst the highest paid groups in the country. They are a privileged professional group. They set their own fees without restraint. Their fees are heavily subsidised by the taxpayer through the Commonwealth Government and, as such, I believe they should be prepared to delay the fee increases in the way that they have been asked to do so.

It is my experience that what has happened in this case, as in any other, is that the medical practitioners who are out working with patients and dealing with patients are too busy to attend AMA meetings, that the people who have the time and the capacity to become officers and spokespersons for the Australian Medical Association are those well-established, wealthy and conservative medical practitioners and that when they come out with requests such as this for their colleagues to penalise people who are amongst the most disadvantaged members of the community most of them do not do it. To calm Senator Peter Baume's and Senator Walter's anxiety about this area, most medical practitioners in this country treat their disadvantaged patients reasonably. They do not charge them more in this regard and they do respect the fact that, for a long time, medical practitioners in this country have not charged people who have received those cards. They will ignore the cries of the greedy minority who have more concern for their profits, their Mercedes and their fancy houses in Vaucluse, Sandy Bay, Toorak, Newstead, or wherever it may be. I think people will be treated decently, as they were in the past.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women. I refer the Minister to a report in yesterday's Canberra Times which states that a meeting this week between the Office of the Status of Women and Australian Capital Territory employer and union representatives was told that Australian Capital Territory women would have jobs open to them if restrictive clauses in wage and conditions awards were lifted. I draw the Minister's attention to one example of such a clause, which states:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . women are not required to do `any cleaning work in male conveniences or lavatories, climb ladders for the purpose of cleaning far walls, windows or blinds'.

I ask the Minister: How will the removal of such a clause increase the status of women? What criteria will the forthcoming national tripartite conference on legislation and award restrictions to women's employment use to assess the appropriateness of retaining or removing such clauses?

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not seen the newspaper report to which Senator Vanstone refers so I cannot comment on it or any claims made in it or about it. However, the Government has a long-standing commitment to hold a tripartite conference on State regulations and elements in State awards which prevent women undertaking employment. The general criterion would be that women should not be prevented from undertaking employment which they are willing and able to do.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NUCLEAR POWERED OR ARMED VESSELS: VISITS TO AUSTRALIA

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask the Minister representing the Minister for Defence the same question that I asked yesterday concerning the inquiry of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence relating to the accidental release of radiation from visiting nuclear powered or armed vessels in Australian ports and waters. Bearing in mind that, between 1971 and 1976, nuclear powered warships were banned from Australian ports at the request of the Liberal McMahon Government pending an environmental impact study, the results of which are still secret, and bearing in mind the recent sinking of a Soviet nuclear submarine, should not the Government now impose a ban on the visits of nuclear armed and nuclear powered warships until the Senate inquiry is completed and until adequate port safety plans to cope with possible accidents have been drawn up and exercises conducted in every Australian port likely to be visited by nuclear warships?

—We seem to be in a time warp here. We have the same question as that asked yesterday and I am going to give the same answer. If honourable senators want to know what it is, I suggest they should look up yesterday's Hansard. I will try to get a reply from the Minister for Defence.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Education. I refer to the proposal by Mr Alan Bond to establish a private educational institution on the Gold Coast in Queensland with full fee paying students. I ask the Minister: Will such students be able to receive the tertiary education assistance scheme allowance if they conform with the current eligibility criteria? Do the current States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Acts enable the Queensland State Government to redirect Commonwealth funds to such a private institution? If so, does the Government intend to amend the Acts to prevent such payments?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government's policy on proposed private institutions is that we do not support them. By that we mean that we will not provide any funding for them, including funding for students attending them. So any such institution that starts up must be very clear that it is starting up entirely under its own auspices and that it cannot, as has been the practice with so many private institutions in this country in the past, start off claiming to be private and self-funding and then very shortly come with its hand out for a public subsidy. No public subsidy of any kind will be forthcoming.

ANSWER.PARA: Having said that, I should point out too that the Government has no particular constitutional responsibility in this area. The States have the legislative capacity to name institutions as universities and to establish Acts under which they can operate and so forth, but that legislative action does not have any consequence for Commonwealth funding. The Commonwealth will fund public institutions, such as those that it currently funds, and it will not fund private institutions. It is also already a guideline for Commonwealth-funded institutions in respect of their capacity to take full fee paying private students that public funds going to public institutions are not to be used for the purposes of creating opportunities for private students. Those students must come in again on a completely full cost basis and not draw off any of the funds that are intended for the public purposes set out in the Tertiary Education Commission's States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Acts.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Treasurer aware that recently the first anniversary occurred of the Government's crackdown on taxpayer subsidised lunches, the so-called free lunch? Does the Minister have any up to date information on employment in the restaurant and hospitality industry? If so, do the figures support or undermine the range of Opposition claims about the impact of the Government's tax reform package on the Australian economy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the last part of Senator Maguire's question is a very unequivocal yes, the facts do undermine the assertions and claims that were made by various people in the Opposition. The latest Australian Bureau of Statistics publication relevant to this question, for those who might want to look it up, is catalogued No. 6203.0. The subdivision which covers restaurants is designated `Restaurants, hotels and clubs'. Upon request the ABS is able to provide separate data for clubs on the one hand and restaurants and hotels on the other but no finer subdivision of the data is available. For restaurants and hotels, total employment in August 1985 was 176,000. Twelve months later, in August 1986, it was 188,600-an increase of 12,600, or 7.2 per cent. Because I am comparing August 1985 figures with August 1986 figures there can be no question of that increase being the result of seasonal influences. A number of people in the Opposition made such a claim when trying to dismiss the facts revealed by previous ABS publications.

ANSWER.PARA: It is possible that the greater part of the 12,600 employment increase has been in the accommodation area rather than in the food and drink area but it is very difficult to see how these figures could be compatible with the sort of gloom and doom mongering put about last year by spokespersons lobbying for the continuation of the taxpayer-subsidised boozy lunch. It would appear that where a restaurant meal was an essential adjunct to business activity it is still being consumed. Where it was a prized social activity disguised as a business lunch that prized social activity is still going ahead even without the massive subsidy from the taxpayer. The lunches that have been knocked off are those which were based on a misallocation of resources brought about by a distortion in the tax system. No one should cry over them. In short, predictions about employment consequences of the termination of the tax subsidised boozy lunch made by Senator Michael Baume are about as reliable a guide to reality as a Patrick Partners prospectus was. Senator Messner's predictions are about as reliable a guide to reality as his predictions about the effects of wine taxes last year or in 1984.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 7 October, Senator Sheil asked me a question without notice relating to a statement in the journal Computing Australia in relation to the offsets program of the Government. I have obtained an answer for Senator Sheil which is as follows: My Department, through its responsibility for the administration of the civil element of the offsets program, is keen to ensure that overseas suppliers to the Australian Government and its agencies approach their offsets commitments in a positive and constructive manner. In fact, the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce has an excellent working relationship with most of the firms involved in the offsets program. The recent considerable publicity on offsets achievements is evidence of this. Honourable senators will probably recall an article on the front of the Australian Financial Review last week. Nevertheless, the Government stands by its policy statement of 15 January which clearly states that companies with an unsatisfactory offsets performance will face more stringent conditions in tendering for Government business. The article to which the honourable senator referred makes it clear the companies concerned were identified by industry sources and not by my Department. I believe it is in the public interest for senior officers of my Department to explain Government policy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Mr President, I have been misrepresented and wish to make a brief personal explanation. I have in my hand a transcript put out by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard). It is a transcript of the `doorstop' by the Leader of the Opposition this morning. I will not go into all the obfuscations; only a couple of sentences are really relevant. He said of the statements by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) yesterday on fringe benefit taxation:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Kerin won't buy into it because he said the matter hasn't been discussed in Cabinet; Senator Walsh says there has been a full ministry meeting . . .

The important word is `full'. I said no such thing. The Hansard record shows that I said `a ministerial meeting'. What I believe I said, and I am having the tape on this checked, was `a meeting of Ministers'. Either way, it certainly was not a full ministerial meeting, as Mr Howard asserted, and therefore there is no inconsistency between what Mr Kerin is alleged to have said and what I said.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report and Text of Ministerial Statement

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 17 September, on motion by Senator Reid:
That the Senate take note of the paper.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: SERVICE AND BUSINESS REVIEW AND OUTLOOK

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 17 September, on motion by Senator Vigor:
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The service and business review and outlook paper of Australia Post is a useful document for the Parliament to have. It gives an idea of the performance in the last financial year, and the expectations for this year, of an organisation that is extremely important to the whole of Australia. We find, for instance, that 90 per cent of postmarked standard articles were delivered on time in 1985-86.

SPEECH.PARA: In New South Wales and the Australian Capital Territory the performance has improved dramatically since last year's major dispute over rostering. Now, more mail sorting and management people are on duty when they are really needed. Two hundred more people have been employed and the performance has improved remarkably. I congratulate Australia Post on this success.

My understanding is that the percentage figures for next day delivery are now in the middle to high nineties. I congratulate all those whose efforts have helped to achieve this. I hope that the new approach will continue to work in the future.

In the divisional and State offices many people want to achieve further improvements but unfortunately are stifled by the bureaucracy at headquarters. Yesterday I mentioned the problem of the indexing machines being in storage for over two years while headquarters waited to negotiate with the unions. Industrial relations matters are very difficult if the channels of communication are blocked and there is an atmosphere of total mistrust. Greater effort will have to go into forward planning and talks with unions about the phasing in of new technology. These matters are never easy but they become virtually impossible if things are done on the run and after the event.

The attitude of Australia Post to automation and technology will come up for further scrutiny despite the abandonment of the efficiency audit by the Auditor-General's Office dealing with automation of counter services. I mentioned yesterday that some of the arrangements in the tendering process for the purchase of counter services terminals need a lot more explanation. In particular, it is disturbing to hear that conversations between Australia Post officials and private sector principals were apparently known in detail to Commonwealth banking officers the following day. I shall certainly be examining just how Australia Post is going about the computerisation of all its information systems. It is essential that the choices made are forward looking and do not tie the organisation to ineffective and obsolescent equipment. Our computer software industry is sufficiently adept to provide Australia Post with everything it should ever want, providing that that industry gets enough notice. If we go about it sensibly, we can also develop export markets through the buying of Australian software and Australian products by institutions such as Australia Post.

One other point that emerged from the abandonment of the audit report related to the siting of post offices. Obviously facilities should be available where people need them and will make extensive use of them. However, Australia Post red tape does not always allow that to happen. For instance, in some parts of the country there is a rule that there must be 75 shops or professional suites in a shopping complex before it qualifies for a post office. There is another rule about agencies being too close to each other. The combination of these rules has prevented the Macquarie Fair complex in the Mount Hutton area of the Lake Macquarie region from getting a post office, despite the fact that it is the hub of the community. I believe that Australia Post needs to look at these types of bureaucratic rules and solve some of these problems. I shall be following up the rationale for the various rules about the siting of post offices to see what sort of economic analysis lies behind them. We should be making more inquiries about the principles involved in decision-making within Australia Post and also within similar statutory bodies within Australia in order to save vast amounts of money for the Government and for the people of Australia.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 17 September, on motion by Senator Vigor:
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise again to talk about a very effective body-Telecom Australia-but one which needs a few directions, particularly in the area of its directories. The Government is doing the same thing to Telecom as it is doing to the Overseas Telecommunications Commission-it is bleeding back $98m in loan repayments when Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development experts say that we need to spend more on development and if we want to develop a communications industry in Australia Telecom is the hub of our telecommunications industry.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that we should take a lead from the French-not just provide them with uranium, as the Government seems to want to do-in the area of telecommunications. They have an excellent system of directories in which every person who has a telephone has in fact a computer phone. This means that directory assistance is never required. French people who have telephones are becoming computer literate and French industry is being supported because the terminals used are produced in France.

I believe that we have a sufficient market to develop cheap terminals and develop our own computer industry if Telecom would simply look at the cost of operating its directory as a computer-operated directory and using the telephone network to access data bases, which could contain not only telephone information but also information about government and local government operations. All of this could be provided through the telephone service and make Australia a country in which people are informed about what is happening in the community. If we use Telecom in this imaginative way I believe that we can develop Australia's consciousness of computing, we can develop Australia's consciousness of the new techniques of communication, and justify moving over to fibre optic networks, et cetera.

It is about time that Telecom revised its charging policy. Large corporations tie up lines all day at local call rates and use cheap rates for computer access. This is just ripping off the country. If a charge per minute were introduced in cities and towns so that country people could make calls at a similar or the same charge per minute as city people, I believe that would result in almost the same cost of providing services. The usage may be different, but the advent of optic fibre systems, which can carry a lot more telephone calls per cable, would make it possible to offer country people real service at the same price city people have to pay. If all calls were on a time charge basis and if all calls were the same price, it would be of real advantage to Australia. One way of bringing Australia together is actually to use the advantages of our telecommunications systems and services.

I recommend that Telecom move into some of these exciting areas and that the Government encourage Telecom by not ripping all its profits off it and by allowing it to reinvest some of its profits into socially useful functions such as developing our industry, training our people in computing and providing a service to everybody, whether they live out in the country or in the city.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: POPULATION MONITORING AND FORECASTING: INTERGOVERNMENTAL ISSUES, CONCERNS AND OPTIONS

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Advisory Council for Inter-Government Relations Report

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 17 September, on motion by Senator Vigor:
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Advisory Council for Inter-government Relations is once again proving its importance to the people of Australia by taking up issues which very closely affect the well-being of people. I refer particularly to local government. Local government lacks proper access to Commonwealth controlled services. As a result of the lack of consultation between the Commonwealth and local government, unnecessary hardship is created. Many of the decisions of the Commonwealth Government directly affect people at local levels. Yet until the establishment of the Advisory Council for Inter-government Relations, there was little communication between these two disparate levels of government. They came together only at such things as the Australian Constitutional Convention, where local government was represented, but that has been abolished by the Government and replaced by the Constitutional Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: This report deals in particular with measuring population changes at local and regional levels. Constitutionally the Commonwealth Government has a responsibility for census and statistics. Financial restraints mean that a full population census is only undertaken every five years. The full census does give accurate information about population at the local level. However, local government currently has little input into the process of deciding on other information to be obtained through the census process. It is vital for local government planning to know about the types of people living in particular areas. This is so that local government can plan ahead for services needed in the future. The ACIR recommends that local government should have representation on the Commonwealth-State statistical co-ordinating committee, to co-ordinate population monitoring activities and State and local government population forecasting data requirements.

Since a census is only held every five years, population movements are estimated in the intervening years by `intelligent' or `informed' guesses. This is known as population forecasting. The outcome of these guesses is vitally important to local government since its income from State and Commonwealth grants is assessed on a population basis. Yet the forecasts are currently subject to enormous errors, as the movement of people on a local scale bears little relation to overall State population movements. Currently there is no procedure for taking local effects into account in assessing population in the intervening years. The closure of a factory, a downturn in prices for a particular commodity or the opening of a popular educational or recreational facility will have large effects on local population changes. Economic swings rarely affect a State equally. Regional and local factors have a much more marked effect in certain areas than on a State overall. Current arrangements for collecting national data are too inflexible to detect, let alone take into account, changing situations at regional and local levels.

The report describes how the inaccurate prediction of growth for the Fairfield City Council in New South Wales led to the Council losing around $135,000 in funds from Commonwealth and State grants between the census years 1976 and 1981. The population was underestimated by 6,000 people out of a total of 132,000 people. Even more wrong was the prediction that the population in the Penrith City Council area would grow from 79,000 in 1976 to between 98,000 and 131,000 by the year 2001. In fact, by 1981 the population had already grown by 30,000-a 38 per cent increase in only five years. It is extremely important that these statistics be available. This report illustrates the cost effectiveness of ACIR in facilitating the collection of the best possible type of statistics about people so that services can be provided in a timely and efficient way. It also recommends changes so that the cost of collecting this information can be minimised while its usefulness is maximised. I commend this report and the ACIR to the Senate. However, the Government appears to want to close it down. Anything that appears to be effective and efficient the Government seems to want to close down.
Debate (on motion by Senator Sheil) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 17 September, on motion by Senator Vigor:
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are dealing with papers that were presented about three weeks ago. I commend the report of the Export Finance and Insurance Corporation to the Senate. This is the final report of EFIC in its original corporate structure. It marks the transition between EFIC as an independent statutory body and the new Austrade. It also marks the separation of the Department of Trade advisory services to government from the active trade promotion and support role now incorporated and merged into Austrade. At this stage I reaffirm my support for this logical, efficient and appropriate division which the enlightened Department of Trade undertook. It is always worth giving a few bouquets.

SPEECH.PARA: It is always a mistake to expect Public Service personnel to perform efficiently in the market-place. The need for accountability and constant preoccupation with rules and regulations, which is apparently part and parcel of a democratically responsible Public Service, imposes far too great a restraint on risk taking, quick responses to market demands and positive action. There are a number of other Public Service departments whose requirement to fulfil multiple disparate roles severely hampers their capacity to perform any of them effectively. In particular, I refer to the Department of Science, in which I have a special interest as Australian Democrats spokesman for science. The Department of Science has a hotchpotch of advisory, research, technical services and industrial roles which it is quite inappropriate to lump together under the administrative control of a single Public Service umbrella. However, I digress.

TALK.START.PARA: —Frequently, if I might say so.

—I hope that the Minister has at least noted my point about the Department of Science. EFIC has performed, and will continue to perform under its new umbrella. It provides a vital service of insurance, guarantee and finance to support Australian exporters in trading on the exposed markets of the world. It has carried out this function through a period of change in international currency relativities and banking practices and through a period of disastrous collapse of world commodity prices. That EFIC has done so at a considerable profit while offering exporters a real service is, I believe, a testimony to the expertise and the management in that organisation.

SPEECH.PARA: EFIC paid nearly $16m into general revenue in the last full year it traded and another $5.7m in its last six months of trading. I point out that this is extra revenue raised from our exporters. Under the new Austrade arrangement this revenue will be used to fund services to exporters provided by other divisions of Austrade, and I believe that this is right.

At this time I also pay tribute to Australia's exporters, that intrepid group of entrepreneurs who have carved out a niche for their products and who, together with the Australian consumers, pay a heavy price for the protection of Australia's non-exporting industries. The protection given to import substitution development in the past, the encouragement of overseas corporations to manufacture in Australia rather than to import their products, cost Australia dearly. Those sectors which pay are our exporters, our consumers and our unemployed. That is a disadvantage to our community. The reason for inviting highly protected manufacturing enterprises into Australia was ostensibly to develop our own manufacturing capability, our own technology base and our own defence base. However, the outcome has been to sell off our indigenous manufacturing enterprises to foreign owners; to come to depend on licensing of imported technology which is often outdated and restricted to local markets, while neglecting our indigenous industrial research and development; and to buy more and more of our defence requirements in preference to supporting local industry, thus leaving us exposed to any blockade of our international lines of supply.

We now face an economic depression of massive proportions with rampant unemployment-in a country where resources are plenty the population is small. These are the consequences of ill-understood protective practices and a flooding diarrhoea of foreign capital forcing up our dollar and holding down our exports. I commend our intrepid exporters for their will to export and for their determination, which holds Australia barely afloat. I commend this report to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: ADVANCE TO THE MINISTER FOR FINANCE 1985-86

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 16 September, on motion by Senator Vigor:
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The statement of expenditure for the Advance to the Minister for Finance 1985-86 is a very important paper. Moneys paid from the Advance to the Minister for Finance can indicate a variety of things. Estimates can prove inadequate because of increased work loads, unexpected salary jumps or other unanticipated factors. They can prove inadequate because project management is not up to scratch. The statements of expenditure from the Advance to the Minister for Finance for the period April to August disclose some interesting information.

SPEECH.PARA: Further government waste is still in the pipeline and I would like to bring this to the notice of honourable senators. I believe that is inexcusable in view of the Budget cuts which have not been thought through properly. Some of those ill-considered cuts have affected regional and rural Australia and could have been spared. For example, the closure of the six regional offices of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs will disadvantage many people without introducing efficiencies in the Department. The closure of nine education centres, including the Port Pirie, Benalla, Tablelands and Warwick centres in regional areas, is a disgrace. It indicates a step away from equality of opportunity. It is entirely avoidable by the Government keeping a tighter watch on waste. For instance, in the April and May expenditure statements $240,000 was set aside for `expenses relating to planning for the establishment of a national identification system involving the issue of a card to be known as the Australia Card'. This amount is on top of the previous sums spent. I note that $35.5m will be allocated to this project this year, of which $4.3m is being thrown into the planning expenses area. This really is extraordinarily extravagant. I hope that some of these activities will be useful when we get improved tax file procedures and banking transaction reporting, instead of the current proposed system, which appears to be simply an attack on civil liberties.

Another example of waste appears in the June statement of expenditure. An amount of $232,000 was set aside for the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry which was established to investigate the activities of His Honour Mr Justice Murphy. This was quite a disgraceful attempt by the Government to pass the buck and have some heat taken off it. The implications for civil liberties and for those in high office who do not tug the forelock to vested economic interests are quite grave. The Australian Democrats were alone in opposing the establishment of the Commission.

The July and August statements contain $6,177,000 as compensation to persons affected by the social security conspiracy case. The payments arise, quite rightly, from the recommendation of the Hon. Dame Roma Mitchell, who conducted an inquiry into those prosecutions. The whole episode is one of shame for Australian law enforcement personnel. People were subjected to quite insensitive and even abusive actions because of their nationality. Conspiracy charges were gradually withdrawn. A magistrate suggested that charges be laid against a former policeman who was involved in running the case. The media were cajoled into treating those charged as though they were guilty. Many innocent people suffered further great personal injury, and we are now paying out $6,177,000 for that mistake. I hope that this type of episode from the Fraser era never recurs in this country.

I turn briefly to the April allocation to the Antarctic Division of the Department of Science and the May allocation to funding under the community development employment program within the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. I believe that these are both worthy programs. The Antarctic Division allocation dealt with ships that were stuck in ice because of special conditions. The CDEP is a very worthy cause. I believe that it would be even more effective if we could get more trained personnel into the area of community development employment programs in Aboriginal communities. Indeed, that area has been seriously neglected by this Government and previous Governments. I recommend to the Senate that we should examine these allocations much more closely.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 24 September, on motion by Senator Reid:
That the Senate take note of the paper.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: FRINGE BENEFITS AND CAPITAL GAINS TAXES

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-

(a) notes that the new fringe benefits and capital gains taxes are administrative nightmares, impose on business a massive paper burden, contains inequities and inconsistencies, and should be repealed;
(b) calls on the Federal Government to introduce legislation to remove all anomalies and problems confronting:
(i) isolated local councils,
(ii) mining operations,
(iii) other businesses operating in remote areas and overseas destinations,
(iv) the elderly and infirm,
(v) non-profit-making organisations, and
(vi) small businesses;

(c) calls upon the Government to make plain its intention to deal with anomalies and apparently unintended effects of the Income Tax Assessment (Capital Gains) Act, particularly sections 160zzs, 160zzt and 160zl and to amend the legislation to give proper effect to shareholders' rights; and
(d) notes with concern that the Commissioner of Taxation has issued a ruling known as IT No. 2121 which:

(i) appears to catch those family arrangements which have been legitimately established with the purpose of providing limited liability to family assets such as the family home or to provide a `going concern' legal entity for the contractors' business; and
