(ii) in many cases has been employed by the Commissioner of Taxation to penalise contractors whose circumstances do not warrant such heavy-handed treatment.

It would appear that at last the eyes of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) have been opened to the disastrous consequences of the fringe benefits tax, three weeks before that tax is due to be paid. It seems inconceivable that, after all the submissions and pleading by concerned groups and individuals on this matter, the Prime Minister has only just acknowledged the monumental difficulties associated with this iniquitous tax. After all, it is not surprising, seeing that he remained unaware of Australia's calamitous trade difficulties until last year, when it was too late. In the same way as he and his senior spokesmen have sought to blame the trade difficulties on corrupt markets instead of on their own ineptitude and mismanagement, they are now seeking to blame the extraordinary community unrest and confusion about the fringe benefits tax on corrupt tax cheats.

This tax was aimed allegedly at stopping some pretty highly paid executives from manipulating the system-for example, by having their children's school fees paid or by having other taxes paid by their company. But this has become a monster which has reached down to the lowest rungs of the social ladder. What will we hear today? The Government will concentrate on talking about people at the top level. But it is at the bottom level that this tax is biting so hard. The Government has been seen to be in error at this level. This fringe benefits tax is not only damaging farmers, miners, small businessmen, old ladies, the infirm, the Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, the Youth Hostels Association of Australia, residential colleges, and so on; it is also affecting sporting and social clubs, and, according to the Department of Defence, it is even affecting the moving of the family pet. In fact, the Defence Department originally said that it would have to fork out $115.6m. But even the Defence Department could not get it right; it was out by $40m. If even government departments cannot understand this tax, how can the ordinary small businessman understand it? Whichever way one looks at it, it is an awful lot of money that could be spent on flying an F18 or running a battleship.

Air-conditioning allowances for personnel in tropical areas and free water supply for residents on the Woomera base are caught by this fringe benefits tax. We hope that these are all unintended consequences. The Government estimated that only about 15 per cent of farmers would be affected by the fringe benefits tax. Actually, we have found that four out of 10 are now affected in a major way. If an employer is good enough and humanitarian enough to send a bowl of fruit to a sick employee, this attracts a fringe benefits tax. How sick can the Government get when it taxes this sort of thing?

The compliance provisions of this legislation need to be looked at. The Government has seen the light in relation to the fringe benefits tax. I now call upon the Government to look at the anomalies and inconsistencies in relation to the capital gains tax. It should not wait until three weeks before 30 June, when the returns in relation to the capital gains tax are due. It should act now. It should use all of the combined resources that will look at the inequities of the fringe benefits tax and apply their minds to this area. The message has not got through. The Government still has blinkered vision in relation to the capital gains tax. We can only hope that the Prime Minister is not kite flying and that he will be genuine.

A few years ago our beloved Prime Minister enunciated nine principles. They were universally accepted because they were right. We acknowledge that they were right. Nobody disputed them. When they were paraded across the country the applause came from every sector of the community. However, that applause and that anticipation of a better future quickly degenerated into a slow hand clap when the fringe benefits tax was announced. The cheers of ordinary, middle class people turned to anger, dismay and confusion. I am not referring to the top executives who have been paraded around this country; I am referring to the ordinary people who travel by train and carry their lunches in brown paper parcels, the lower levels of society if one wants to be class conscious. All of these people had to come to terms with the effects of this iniquitous tax.

The fringe benefits tax offended four of those nine grand principles. One of those principles was that the tax system had to be simpler and fairer so that it could be easily understood. But what has happened? It has become an administrative nightmare. It is full of anomalies and inconsistencies. It has led to tremendous confusion throughout the community. In no way, for example, would I support any scheme which allowed executives, professional people and the self-employed to receive a major part of their income as a tax fiddle while the majority of the people were taxed at source. But what has the Labor Party done? It has legitimised the payment of fringe benefits to the top executives. It has legitimised that payment at last and it is supposed to be the party which is in favour of the working class, the lower levels. What has this fringe benefits tax done that it does not realise the consequences of its legislation?

TALK.START.PARA: —Give us an example of that. Put your money where your mouth is.

—I will give the honourable senator an example. Any top executive earning over $35,000 a year is now in a position to convert part of his salary to fringe benefits. He can legitimately convert $50,000, $100,000 or $200,000, if the company is big enough, in terms of maintaining a car, support for his wife and family, his children's education expenses, home loans and those sorts of things. The company pays at the rate at 49c in the dollar. They are some examples for Senator Robertson. But what about the middle level executives? They have missed out. What about the lower paid persons? What about the lassie who goes home after work at 8 o'clock in a taxi paid for by her company? She will not be able to do this in future because a fringe benefits tax will have to be paid. These people have been cashed out.

SPEECH.PARA: Principle No. 5 says that the tax must be paid according to a person's ability to pay. This principle was applauded. However, the fringe benefits tax does not recognise this principle. It is not a tax on profitability; it is a tax on expenses. Many people in the community do not have a large enough income to pay these additional taxes as such because they are being screwed by this unconcerned Government. Farmers in the outback who offer cheap housing to secure labour in isolated areas and whose incomes are well below the poverty line have to pay this unjust tax in accordance with a market-related rent. How can one arrive at a market-related rent when one is 50 miles out in the bush and there are only half a dozen sub-standard houses there, all empty? Senator Robertson knows that this is a lot of rubbish.

Non-profit organisations have to pay fringe benefits tax on the meals they provide to their workers-the people who work in soup kitchens and charities. A fringe benefits tax has to be paid by these charitable organisations on the value of the soup and meals that their workers receive. How unjust can one get! This tax will apply to youth hostel organisations which provide meals and entertainment, residential colleges which are attached to universities and so on. The list is just so long. It also applies to the cost of providing live-in accommodation at night to people who look after the elderly in need of nursing attention and invalids. A tax has to be paid on accommodation provided overnight to people who look after the sick and the infirm. How cruel can one get? People who do not have the capacity to pay are to be taxed 49c in the dollar for providing this accommodation. I want honourable senators opposite to tell me what is fair about an employer having to pay a tax which is really for the benefit of the employee. What about the situation in which an air-conditioner is installed in a car in accordance with the provisions of a salesmen's award in New South Wales? In such a case the employer has to pay a fringe benefits tax.

Principle No. 8 sets out that any reform must provide the best possible climate for investment, growth and employment. But look at what has happened in relation to overseas contractors. Because of pressure in this instance, the Government had to back down. But it did not back down in a humble way. It said: `That is a technical amendment. We never intended to cover these sorts of consequences'. We are heading towards a situation of administrative change rather than legislative change. Very few people really knew what would be the impact of what has been happening. We have had off the cuff answers. We are told that any reform package must have widespread community support. What a laugh! The Australian Bureau of Statistics says that something like 58.9 per cent of the work- force receives a fringe benefit of some kind.

If the boos and the jeers at the Victorian Football League grand final in Melbourne and the rugby league grand final in Sydney did nothing else, they certainly delivered a message to the Prime Minister that his actions no longer have the support of the majority of Australians. Maybe this was the instigator that at last has changed the Prime Minister's mind. The fringe benefits tax was initially devised to eliminate privileged perks. The tax has been a monumental disaster. It is inequitable, discriminatory and an administrative nightmare. The compliance provisions themselves, with all of the anomalies and inequities, really make it a bad law. It is a bad law because it is unjust. It taxes the provider of the benefits instead of the person who receives them. It is complex, inefficient and increases unemployment. It is a tax on employment. It is inequitable because it destroys the incentive to invest. Even the Confederation of Australian Industry estimates that over $2 billion in revenue will be collected. This is seven times the estimate of the Government. How wrong can the Government be? How far out can it get?

TALK.START.PARA: —Who is wrong this time.

—The Government is going to correct it. New Zealand has it right. It does not tax non-profit organisations. They are exempt. There is a relatively simple tax over there. We have followed every burrow down the line to get the maximum tax from everybody we can. The tax is complex and mountains of paper work are involved. Let me give an example which borders on the ridiculous. The Bowater-Scott Ltd paper organisation has a problem in relation to its 800 employees when they buy stock which is manufactured by the company. Under the FBT, every toilet roll sold below the trade price attracts a fringe benefits tax which the Bowater company is liable to pay where the value per employee exceeds $200 a year. Every time an employee purchases a cheap toilet roll his name is entered on a computer in order to determine the company's tax liability. What a farce! What a waste of resources in this country! This tax is inefficient and complex. An additional 590 people have been employed to administer this tax. Morale in the Australian Taxation Office is at an all time low. People at the top levels are leaving because of the complications of not only the fringe benefits tax but also the capital gains tax. The fringe benefits tax will also increase inflation.

SPEECH.PARA: Export industries are affected in a major way by this tax. I call on the Government to exempt export industries from any major fringe benefits tax. It will reduce employment opportunities because it is a tax on employment. People who have a negative or zero income are going to be taxed on this income. The tax destroys incentive, growth and development. Rather, we should be trying to stimulate investment, productivity and employment. As I said, we have to encourage export industries.

The tax is full of absurdities. The annual children's Christmas party, service awards, presentation dinners and gifts to people in safety organisations, such as volunteer firemen, are all subject to fringe benefits tax as far as the employer is concerned. If an employer takes the company utility home in case he is called out to an emergency, the employer is going to be taxed. Safety incentive and award schemes are subject to fringe benefits tax. If an employee is granted a loan and later disappears, fringe benefits tax has to be paid until the loan is repaid or written off. Firms that provide off-street parking to their employees are subject to fringe benefits tax. Let us look at the sorts of ridiculous situations that apply in the Department of Defence. The removal of a pet, air-conditioning allowances, water supply at Woomera, child reunion travel, library services, free access to a library of a community nature, relief trust fund allocations, compulsory sporting fees where members of the defence forces require registration, local affiliation, umpiring fees and so on are all subject to this iniquitous fringe benefits tax.

Let me say just a few brief words on the capital gains tax because my time is limited and we have a long list of speakers. This tax will also raise a lot more than has been estimated. In fact, the top level meeting which was recently held between the top executives of the Law Council of Australia and the Taxation Office to sort out the problem broke up in utter confusion because no common ground for discussion could be found. We find the inequities for unit trust holders still unresolved. There are tremendous problems in this area. I therefore call upon the Government to repeal this iniquitous tax and certainly to remove all the anomalies by legislative force rather than by administrative action. We call upon the Government, therefore, to introduce legislation to remove the anomalies and all the problems, especially those confronting isolated local councils, mining operations, businesses operating in remote areas and overseas destinations, the elderly, the infirm, non-profit making organisations and small business.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —One would think this is a government in the last stages of decline. Day by day we see a stumbling, bumbling government having to undo its decisions. The people of Canberra recently succeeded in changing the Government's will when it broke its promise to the mortgagors of the Australian Capital Territory. We are now seeing the Government having to take back all the words which have spoken by its members over the last six months or so and having to look again at this dreadful tax. This is a government in retreat. It is interesting that this Government is not listening to the people. This is not a question of consensus or discussion. The Government had plenty of opportunities for consensus and discussion before this tax was introduced, but it was deaf to all entreaties. It is interesting that the only way this tax seems finally to have been brought up for review is because the nervous nellies of the various factions went to breakfast with the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and persuaded him that they were in trouble. Because of that it looks as though we might at least get a review of this iniquitous tax.

SPEECH.PARA: There was another necessary criterion and that was that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) had to be sent out of the country. This Government seems to lurch from crisis to crisis when either the Prime Minister or the Treasurer is out of the country. When they are separated we usually see some sort of drama in relation to the financial management of this nation.

TALK.START.PARA: —He's trying to teach the Americans.

—Is that what he is up to? I thought he was out buying clocks as a hedge against inflation and a downturn in the economy. I have said that the Government was given plenty of advice. It is interesting to note who gave it that advice and what sort of advice it got. The Government is now talking about unforeseen circumstances and the unintended results of this tax. It really is a case of `they told you so but you would not listen'.

SPEECH.PARA: The Tasmanian Advocate of 6 June this year reported:

The Federal Government's new fringe benefits tax could see the loss of more than 300 jobs in the Tasmanian motor vehicle industry, according to the President of the Australian Automobile Dealers' Association (Mr Grahame Woodward, of Hobart).

Tasmanian statistics are usually not far behind the national trend, and if this is any indication the State could see average reductions of personnel from 10-20 p.c. as surveys in Sydney and Melbourne have shown.

Mr Woodward was not alone in that belief. The industry told the Government that the slump in new car sales in Tasmania was continuing, with the latest figures confirming that the industry had suffered a 29 per cent drop in April from the same period last year, and that Tasmanian new car dealers had largely blamed the slump on the uncertainty surrounding the Federal Government's fringe benefits tax.

The Senate will recall that during Question Time on Tuesday I asked Senator Button about the situation relating to the fringe benefits tax and the car industry. I asked was it not a fact that the one important thing the Government could do to help the industry would be to remove the fringe benefits tax. He said that as far as he understood the situation, the August sales and registration figures for motor vehicles in industry terms suggested a bottoming out of the decline in motor vehicle sales, and that it had also been reported to him that the figures for September showed some slight improvement on what was anticipated. I do not know who was anticipating it, but I would like to tell the Senate what the situation has been in my State over the last nine months in relation to passenger car registrations-the very area that is affected by fear of what the fringe benefits tax will do and what it is already doing.

From April 1985 to April 1986 there was a decline of 29 per cent in new registrations; in May there was a decline of 25 per cent; in June there was a decline of 23 per cent; in July there was a decline of 22 per cent; and in August, as Senator Button should recall, there was a decline of 28 per cent. If that is bottoming out, it has gone up to bottom! The September figures will show another 28 per cent decline compared with last year. I do not know where the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) is getting his advice from, but I suggest he change his source. The figure for new passenger vehicle registrations in Tasmania for the nine-month period from January to September 1986 it was 6,550-a decline of 25 per cent over last year. In fact, Mr John Nettleford, the Vice-President of the Australian Automobile Dealers Association in Tasmania said:

The fringe benefits tax has been disastrous for our industry. Members have all been putting people off. It has caused widespread ill-feeling inside and outside the industry. Another member told me: Our business has collapsed around our ears-the fringe benefits tax has done it.
The miners also told the Government what was going to happen. They said in May that the fringe benefits tax was a folly. The Australian Mining Industry Council said:

The new tax impost represents more than five per cent of profits for the industry in 1984-85. To recover this, the iron ore industry will need to sell about five million additional tonnes of iron ore-equivalent to finding a new market equal to our Korean exports.
The fringe benefits tax is a tax on mining employment in remote areas.
At a time when the Government and unions are looking for additional industry investment, to impose an additional tax of this magnitude is folly and the Government should reconsider its decision.

The Government was told that in May. Two separate mining companies on the west coast of Tasmania are up to $500,000 and $1m. The industry is on its knees. Even the reduction in the rate of the dollar has not helped in terms of their being able to sell their products overseas because of the low price for their minerals. Yet regardless of their profits, they are required to pay half a million dollars and $1m in these two separate cases for benefits that are supplied to their workforce. These are not rorts. They can in no way be described as fat cat tax perks.

The accountants told the Government in April or May this year, when debate on this matter began, that the tax would mean that there would be more work for employers, more work for Government members, and more work for the lawyers of this nation. The Government did not listen. The Australian Parents Council told the Government in May what the tax was going to do to the boarding schools of the nation. The matter of isolated children is very much a motherhood thing with the Government, but when it comes down to it, the Government simply does not allow for the high costs of providing proper care for the children from isolated areas when they have to stay in boarding schools or hostels in town. The schools and hostels who care for these children will now have a liability for fringe benefits tax. Schools will have to assess their liability for the fringe benefits tax for those occasions on which teachers attend school functions as part of their job. The Australian Parents Council said in May:
To impose such administrative burdens and taxes on non-government schools would divert scarce resources away from teaching children.

The Government cannot say it did not know. The Returned Services League of Australia told the Government in May that public spirited citizens would be less willing to help when an even greater proportion of their donations was absorbed by the administrative costs of a voluntary organisation, through the extra clerical work needed by the fringe benefits tax legislation and, of course, through having to pay taxes where none existed before. The RSL was concerned that the fringe benefits tax would add to the destructive processes that have made it increasingly difficult in the past decade for charitable organisations to continue their work. The RSL believed that in applying the new fringe benefits tax to welfare and charitable bodies, the Government would be adding to its own social welfare bill. Inevitably it would have to provide additional services to compensate for those previously provided by non-government bodies.
The Australian Chamber of Manufactures told the Government in May what it was doing. It wrote to the Prime Minister and said:

The Australian Chamber of Manufactures, representing some 6,200 member companies spread across the whole spectrum of manufacturing industry, is implacably opposed to the proposed fringe benefits taxes.

The proposed fringe benefits taxes introduce a nightmare into administration. The returns which have to be provided to the Taxation Office, the log books that have to be kept in vehicles and the sheer effort of keeping track of all the detail will strain the viability of many businesses. Large companies may be better placed to deal with this onslaught, but small business cannot afford or cope with the administration burden.

Any rational individual, weighing up the need for manufacturers to make an improved contribution to higher levels of activity, both domestically and externally, must conclude that this is not the time to levy further imposts on business . . . Government prefers to exploit industry as a milking cow to fund uncontrolled public expenditure rather than take hard political and economic decisions needed to enable industry to perform more effectively as the engine for balanced economic growth.

It makes a mockery of the attempts of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, to help with problems of inefficiency in private enterprise. I have here a Press release from Senator Button dated 29 September in which he says:

The experience of leading overseas countries which have competitive economic environments that reward innovation, confirms that the competitiveness of their individual firms and industries can be significantly undermined by lags in the application of new management techniques and technologies.

He does not mention how they can be significantly undermined by taxes on a business which is making little or no money at all. The Government has been told over and over-we know that the Premiers have all been trying to tell the Government-what it is up to. Mr Burke said that he could not see value in a tax that did nothing but raise the cost of services provided by State and local governments. He said that the iron ore industry alone would have to find an extra $25m to cover the fringe benefits tax. He was presenting a submission which said that the State Government would lose because of the impact of the tax on the ability of mining companies to pay State royalties based on their profits. This Government has been told by everybody, but it simply will not listen. We all knew what the end result would be. What does Australia say now? The Advocate in Tasmania states:

That the tax has intruded Big Brother-like is evident from its burgeoning impact on employee housing, to give one example. It's all very well for the PM to say such-and-such was never intended. It is happening, as many amazed Australians have learnt; moreover, fresh areas to be milked seem to surface daily. If the tax cannot properly discriminate, it will have to go. The Government almost certainly will if it doesn't.

I conclude by drawing attention to the Minister's second reading speech in which he claimed that the loss of unit sales due to the tax will fall within tolerable limits for the industry. How hard-hearted and cruel that statement is. He said that the design of the tax is directed at making the operation of the tax as readily manageable as possible for employers. How hollow that is now. He finally concluded by saying that it represented another major step towards completing the Government's tax reform program. If that is a tax reform program, God help Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating Senator Watson's motion on the fringe benefits tax. Senator Watson has put up, I hope, an honest view. However, it has been difficult for those on this side to find too many honest views in the Liberal Party on the fringe benefits tax. I do remember one person with an honest view. His name is John Valder, the Federal President of the Liberal Party. I quote what he said earlier this year:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . to reverse the whole disease . . . of fringe benefits . . . I've got to say I think that is a fair and just thing in this country . . . The longer we leave doing it, the harder it is going to be . . . electorally . . . They are not easy to do so I have said many times . . . let the Labor Party get on with implementing the more necessary, but perhaps less popular parts of our policy-
note the words `our policy', possessive pronoun and all-
and let's hope they get them into place and promptly lose office.

Now that is an honest view from the Liberal Party. At least John Valder knew what his Party was about. After we look at John Valder, the President, I suppose we have to look at the parliamentary leadership to find out what it thinks on the question of fringe benefits. That is where honesty gets harder and harder to find. We have the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, doing back flips every day. What we really have from the Liberal Party is a secret tax, because it will not tell anyone what it will do. All John Howard can say is: `We want to leave all the options on the table. I am not going to let you know'. In the Sydney Morning Herald of 30 May 1986 there is an article by Milton Cockburn headed `Libs about-face on fringe benefits tax'. There have been a lot more about-faces since. Mr Howard, the day before, had pledged to repeal the fringe benefits tax. The article stated that until the day before Mr Howard had said that no decision could be made until the Opposition announced its tax policy. That statement was made nearly five months ago. We all breathlessly await the announcement of the Opposition's tax policy. But the reason we do not have that announcement is that the Opposition knows it has to keep the money raised from the fringe benefits tax. Therefore it will keep the tax on. In a sleight of hand it is saying: `We will abolish the tax but we will stop tax evasion'. John Howard has pretty well discovered that tax evasion is a bad idea. However I remember, somewhere in the dark recesses of my mind, a person called Costigan, the royal commissioner, describing the growth during the Fraser years of tax avoidance. He said that that industry grew at a rate faster than the heady days of the Victorian gold rush. That is what the Opposition wants to return to. It wants to get rid of any equity. This motion backs up that view. It wants to throw this fringe benefits tax out the window and let the majority support the perks of the minority. That has always been what the Liberal Party is about, it just cannot hack fairness. It is not part of its nature or its name.

If we go back to the remarks of John Howard we will see how they have changed regularly. We also have to look at Jim Carlton, who has also had a few things to say. On 20 August on radio station 4BC he told Haydn Sargent that the coalition would `feel justified in being tougher on taxing those sorts of fringe benefits'. They were Carlton's words on 20 August. That is why my search for honesty has to continue. Every time one of the Opposition's senior spokesmen makes a statement on this issue he contradicts the last one to have made a statement. At the National Press Club on 27 August 1986, a week after he had made his statement on 4BC, Mr Carlton said:
We'd be back with the old law which in fact imposed a tax on the employee for a benefit received.

That actually is true because the Opposition, in government, did just that, but in practically every case those benefits were never declared and therefore huge amounts of tax simply were never collected. I turn to the Australian Financial Review. The duplicity of this lot opposite is chronicled in many places. `Key Liberals continue to move out in front of Howard', said the Financial Review in Greg Earl's article on 29 September this year. Sir William Knox, a Queensland Liberal-I think-said that a Federal Liberal Government would abolish Labor's FBT. `But', he said, `housing and other perks will still be taxable'. That is, of course, what most of them say. The Opposition will not tell us how it will tax fringe benefits or how much it will tax them. In the end it is another sleight of hand. Mr Wilson Tuckey is normally known for dropping buckets on innocent people in the other place and is capable of saying anything. On 27 September 1986 he decided not to bucket Keating; he decided to bucket Howard. I would never want to misquote Wilson Tuckey; that would be a dangerous business and I lack the courage. He said:
The fringe benefits tax is to stay.

He said that they would maintain the FBT specifically for cars, housing and education. I am told that this person is a front bencher in Senator Watson's Party. I have been given this information on reliable authority. I know that he is kept in the background and is let out of the cage only on occasions, but obviously he escaped that morning. Howard, it is said, would abolish the tax lock, stock and barrel-but not Tuckey. He said that he would maintain it for cars, housing and education. Carlton and Sinclair said on 25 September that the coalition would tax fringe benefits under the original anti-avoidance provisions. So all we get is a continuing chronological list of events which contradict each other day after day.

Then there is the 30 September 1986 edition of the Age. If there were no problem in the Liberal Party about fringe benefits, if Opposition members were all of one mind, why would the headline to Michelle Gratton's article in the Age read: `Howard orders team to toe fringe tax line'? John Howard had read the riot act. Ralph Hunt did not hear it. He went on to say: `We are going to have a fringe benefits tax'. So we now have six different spokesmen with six different lines. I find it very hard in this search for honesty to find a scrap of it. I do not find it in Senator Watson's motion. John Howard was reported in Mike Steketee's article in the Sydney Morning Herald on 30 September as having said:
I have a fairly good idea of what I think is tax avoidance.
That was an idea he never came to grips with in his seven years as Treasurer. I want to try to give him and Senator Watson an idea of why the fringe benefits tax will be retained.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ask your boss.

—I speak to my boss, as Senator Walters puts it, a bit more often than she does. I have a rough idea of what he is thinking. Senator Walters has no idea of what her Leader is thinking because he is not game to think anything until he has asked Carlton, Tuckey, Sinclair and Hunt for their views-and they are all different. If honourable members opposite need to know what a fringe benefits tax is, I will give them an example.
—Was it a decent breakfast?

—The breakfast was nice. The sausages were well cooked and the eggs were soft. If one considers equity in the tax system one must consider the development that has occurred in 10 years, particularly the development that occurred during the last Liberal reign, when tax avoidance ran wild. Under the equity of the former Government's system an employee may have earned $45,000, but let us look at what executives were doing for themselves. An executive on $45,000 may also have been given a representative allowance of $3,000; superannuation of $6,000; a motor vehicle lease, even on a Toyota, of $5,800; a subsidy for motor vehicle maintenance, running costs, registration, et cetera of $1,900; a hostess allowance, because the wife has to work hard on occasions, of $4,000-good pay that; a home telephone subsidy of $300; a low interest loan of $8,500; a school fees subsidy of $3,000-it is very important to look after the kids; and $3,000 for holiday travel, because there is no reason why an executive should ever pay for his own holidays. They have to be funded by the taxpayer. That package amounts to $78,850. That is a lot of money, but only $45,000 is in the form of salary. If an employee received only salary he or she would have had to be paid $115,000 to get the same reward.

SPEECH.PARA: Under the previous Government tax was avoided daily by citizens all over the country. They could do it not only with that Government's permission but also, if one is to judge by some of the statements made today by Senator Watson and Senator Newman, with its encouragement. This Labor Party Government will not cop that sort of thing because if we allow it to go on, those who do not get fringe benefits-the vast majority of Australians-will have to continue to subsidise the perks I have just read out. If one takes a wide definition of fringe benefits, finally Senator Newman got something right. It took her a while, but she got there. A great many Australians at least enjoy the fringe benefit of getting some sort of discount on goods purchased where they work. That is true. But that is a tiny fringe benefit. It amounts to virtually nothing for shop assistants and brewery employees. What we are talking about is not that sort of small perk. We are talking about the perks I have just read out. This Government will continue to defend that principle because it is right.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is your greed that went wrong. That is where you went wrong.

—When it comes to greed, we could all take lessons from Senator Watson and his Party. But fortunately, because we have the interests of the majority uppermost in our minds, we are not going to. We are going to make sure that there is some equity in this system. This, I must confess, is not easy because the one thing the Opposition is right about, which the Government has acknowledged, is that there is too much paperwork. There is too much of an administrative burden. That is why we are conducting a review. The tax was introduced on 1 July, only three months ago.
—You hadn't thought it through.

—In three months the Government, being the sort of government that is capable of listening to the people, and fortunately being the sort of government that does not have to listen to Senator Walters--
—What about the capital gains tax?

—I have often asked Senator Watson in this place to be patient. We will get to capital gains. There is plenty of time. He should relax and take three deep breaths. We will get there. After the tax has been operating for three months the Government has been prepared to say `We will review it' and to look at what the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) called `unintended consequences' and at the administrative burden about which small business has been complaining. I for one applaud the Government for doing so. It is timely. This Government is not going to insist on sticking to every comma and cross on a `t' just because we introduced the tax in the first place. If an error is made the Government is prepared to review it. That is what is happening now.

SPEECH.PARA: The growth of fringe benefits over 10 years has continued to place an added burden on Australians who work in occupations where fringe benefits are not available. That is an unavoidable and absolute consequence of the growth of fringe benefits. Honourable senators opposite cannot deny it. The reality is that most Australian cannot get their children's school fees at expensive schools paid. They cannot get subsidised travel overseas and do not have subsidised Mercedes in the garage. They are not able to get those sorts of benefits. They have to put up with paying tax every week. Senator Walters, who is trying to interject, would not know too much about paying tax. Most Australians are not able to afford expensive accountants in the way that she can. They have to front up every Thursday or Friday, look at their pay packets and see how much they have paid out. If this Government allowed fringe benefits to grow, ordinary Australians would have to keep paying more. We will not allow that.

Honourable senators opposite do not have a concern for ordinary Australians, only for those at the top of the tree. That is where we differ. It is a fundamental difference. If it is the case, as I am certain, that it is a small and very select section of the community which enjoys the kinds of fringe benefits an example of which I gave earlier and if we are to bring about any tax equity at all, we have to do something about those benefits. That is what we have started to do. The Australian Bureau of Statistics-I referred to this earlier in commenting on one of the things that Senator Newman said-said in 1983 that 42 per cent of employees received no fringe benefits. Are honourable senators opposite disputing the Bureau of Statistics figures?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes.
—They are, are they?
—That 58 per cent get a fringe benefit?

—Senator Watson would know, would he? Has he done a survey in Tasmania or read the Advocate? The Bureau of Statistics went a bit further. It went right around Australia to get its information. It had a good look and found that 42 per cent of employees receive no fringe benefits at all. Of those who did receive fringe benefits, 77 per cent-that is, three-quarters of the rest-were getting only the kinds of benefits I mentioned earlier. If they were shop assistants they were perhaps getting small discounts up to a certain amount each month on goods they could purchase. That is by far the most common fringe benefit. If personal income tax is to remain progressive for those who predominantly derive their income from wages and salaries, we will have to make certain that those in the upper brackets cannot make the system less and less progressive for their own benefit by taking their salary package in a form in which they can avoid paying tax.

SPEECH.PARA: We have stopped the rort. At the end of the day we have to accept that there will be some pain for having stopped it. I accept that no one applauds a government that takes something off the people, but for the Government to make it a fair system in the end, it was the only way for it to go. We will make it a fair system. Just to back that up, for those who have been affected by the fringe benefits tax, for those whose employers will not pay the tax, two very significant tax cuts are coming up in December and July. Those tax cuts will finally get around to addressing the John Howard 60c tax rate. John Howard brought that rate in. Honourable senators opposite were in government when it was decided to tax those on high incomes at that high rate. This Government is setting about reducing that rate and getting it down to a top rate of 49c by next July. That is something that a Labor government is delivering for higher income earners, having already delivered very significant tax cuts during 1984 and 1985 for lower income earners.

Obviously there are problems in any tax system. The reality is that all governments-this one or even previous ones-are prepared to keep taxation under review. All that this Government has done in the last few days with its announcement about the review is to say: `On this particular very new tax that has been operating for only three months we are prepared to have a look at those areas it is going into where we are worried that it is having consequences that were never intended'. Having had a look around Australia and having talked to as many people as I can, it is obvious to me that the question of log books has been one of the main grievances. Obviously they will be up for review by the Government during the next few weeks. We are not saying that this review will take for ever. The date on which it is to commence is only a few weeks hence and we will get there pretty quickly. By the end of that very short period, I trust that we will be able to announce that we have addressed those problems that have been raised that do no affect the principle of the fringe benefits tax, because that principle is something that we are going to effect.

There will be a minimal impact on revenue. We will not simply give back the free lunch. Seventy-five per cent of people have been paying for the 25 per cent who have been having the free lunch. That will not come back. I am very sorry for honourable senators opposite, but those days have gone forever and they will have to start paying for themselves. I know that it will be a shock and an effort for honourable senators opposite, but it will start happening. Fortunately, we are going to ensure that the application of the tax to cars will be retained as well. We will ensure that all the mates of honourable senators opposite will pay up for their cars too. It is terrible, is it not! It really shocks honourable senators opposite that everyone will have to pay and they will not be subsidised by ordinary Australians. We will bring that subsidisation to an end.
I turn again to the Australian Financial Review, which is part of the Fairfax network. I would like just to go through what it says about fringe benefits.

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't believe it.
—I believe it with great passion. The Australian Financial Review of 12 August 1986 stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Non-cash benefits are already taxable. The problem is that employees almost never declare them.
That has been the problem all the way through. The Australian Financial Review, from the Fairfax stable, conceded:
The fringe benefits tax is a method of reducing tax evasion, part of a broad tax reform aimed at producing more equity and fewer rorts--

It is not a matter of what I believe or what I say. If we go to a paper such as the Australian Financial Review-one could say that it is a fairly classy journal-we see that it is saying the same things, because it realises that the days of the rort are over. The problem is that the days of honourable senators opposite are over as well. They are living in an old Australia-one that has gone. The editorial continued:
and improving incentive for effort by getting the top marginal income tax rate down below 50 per cent.

That is something that this Government has done. Honourable senators opposite always talk about incentive, but they put the rate up to 60c. What we are doing, without the necessity of moving a motion such as that moved by Senator Watson, is getting rid of the previous Government's high tax rates. That is something that honourable senators opposite could not do; they could only talk about it. They are very big on rhetoric and very slow on action.

TALK.START.PARA: —Wait until you see our rates.

—The difficulty we have is that we are all hanging by the neck waiting to see the Opposition's rate. Every day we say to John Howard: `Come and tell us what your tax policy is'. What does he say every day? He says: `I'm sorry, we're not ready yet'. The problem with the Liberal Party is that it has not been ready in a decade to tell us about its tax policy, and it will not now. John Howard has squibbed it every time. I listened to him on radio yesterday morning in Sydney again squibbing, unable to admit what his real tax policy is; that is, after Wilson Tuckey has told him what it is allowed to be. We all await with glee the day when we can get up in this chamber and debate the Opposition's policies. However, I suspect that it will never tell us, because when the crunch comes it has neither the brains nor the guts--
—We will bring taxes down, not put them up like you are.

—The problem is that the Opposition, when in government, did not do that. During the years of the Government in which the honourable senator once served, before the people in his Victorian electorate threw him out, tax avoidance grew and grew. I have already quoted what Mr Costigan said. He said that tax avoidance grew at a rate similar to that in the heady days of the Victorian gold rush. The contribution of the Liberal Party to the tax debate was to encourage tax avoidance. It was the only industry that grew in the seven years of the former Government. This Government has brought it to an end. It has stopped it dead in its tracks. Honourable senators opposite just could not get to it, and the reason is that all their mates were in the rort. That was the problem. This Government, representing the majority of Australians who just could not get into that category, did something about it. It stood up and stopped it.
—It made a mess of it.

—The honourable senator said that it made a mess of stopping tax avoidance. We have saved a couple of hundred million dollars. I know that honourable senators opposite would like to go back to those days, but we have stopped all the schemes and all the rorts that grew like Topsy under the previous Administration. I turn now to the Melbourne Age. If people opposite do not believe me they will find it much harder to knock over what the Australian Financial Review said-and now we come to the Age. The Age editorial of 12 August stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The fringe benefits tax debate involves two separate issues-one economic, the other political.
It is right so far; even Senator Short would not disagree with that. It went on to state:
. . . a tax on fringe benefits is sensible, fair and necessary.
This is the editorial of the Age, not the socialist workers paper. The editorial continued:
It offers a way of closing loopholes through which millions of dollars of taxation revenue were slipping each year.
That is precisely our argument and that is precisely what we have done. The editorial continued:
The money obtained by closing these loopholes could be used to finance tax cuts, including substantial cuts for high income earners.
That is what we have done. Those tax cuts will be implemented in December and in July-John Howard's 60c rate goes for ever. The Age editorial also stated:
. . . an employer could choose to avoid the cost and paper work . . . by giving his senior staff compensatory wage rises . . .
That is good advice for employers! The editorial continued:
. . . fringe benefits are simply forms of income and should be taxed accordingly . . .
That is what the editorial of the Age said. It also said:
Unless tax scales are readjusted as promised-and indexed-the FBT will rightly be seen as another selective penalty against effort and initiative.

We are readjusting them. Three months ago we introduced a new tax which is a great departure from days previous. The new piece of legislation undoubtedly was complex. Following the introduction of that legislation we then got the bureaucrats at work to see what sort of administration it should have. The Government is saying that, after three months of operation-which is a reasonable period to see how it is going-it has looked at that administrative burden and said that it will cut some of it out. Obviously, if one looks at some of the more bizarre examples of areas into which the tax has gone one sees that they too will go. There will not be an effect to revenue as they were never a factor in the Government's figures. The reason they were not is that, as the Prime Minister has said, they are unintended consequences.

TALK.START.PARA: —How did the Government do its calculations?

—Properly, as usual. It has taken the Government several months to look at this new piece of tax legislation to find out how it is working and to clear it up. I might say that all we are doing is clearing it up around the edges, because we are sticking to the principle of the tax-a tax that this Government supports absolutely.
—What about--

—I have waited for three and a half years to come into this chamber and hear the honourable senator make sense. I hope I do not have to wait another three and a half years and that Senator Walters will give us a big shock by saying something sensible soon. That would make us all feel better. Successive governments considered that the resources needed to police fringe benefits under section 26 (e) of the Income Tax Assessment Act were too great. Indeed, the previous Government rejected changes to that section. This Government has acknowledged that the problem exists. It will not reject changes. It will not stick to every single tiny detail of the administration of the tax. We will look at the details and where there are problems we will get rid of them. This Government, as usual, will act quickly.

SPEECH.PARA: In the minutes left to me I shall refer to the scope of the review. The principle and integrity of the fringe benefits tax are not at issue; they are not to be reviewed. We will examine the tax for the impact mentioned earlier and look at some relevant amendments and administrative corrections. We expect any of the changes to be made to have a minimal impact on revenue yield because the areas affected are areas in which the Government did not intend the tax to have an effect. I turn to the review process. The Government will conduct the review in a very short period-over only the next few weeks. A wide range of material will be made available to the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why can we not get those answers from Ministers? Why do we have to get them from a back bencher like you?

—I concede to Senator Messner that I am a back bencher-a humble back bencher doing his best. On the question of whether the instalment date will be changed, the first instalment is due on 28 October. That is the big day.
—For some.

—Some of Senator Walters's mates will not pay because they have been avoiding tax for years. I am trying to get people to pay up when they should. The Government intends to complete the review process in time to announce any changes before 28 October. It is open to the Commissioner of Taxation under the current law to extend the time for payment if those affected by changes can demonstrate to the Commissioner that they had genuine difficulty in assessing their liability to pay. So paying by 28 October is not a problem for individuals who are suffering hardship or particular difficulties. The Commissioner has already stated that tax will not be payable in cases in which it is decided to remove the fringe benefits tax liability under current legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: The reality is that this review will be conducted very quickly. We will look at the unintended consequences of the legislation and at the administrative burden. Where small business is being unnecessarily disadvantaged by that burden we will act. We have made concessions before; we will make them again. Tax policy, even after this review, will continue to be under constant review, as it has been under every government since Federation. This Government will keep working at it. We listen to the Australian people and we give them what they want-good, sound government which at least has enough principle to accept the political risk involved in taking a benefit from those who are rorting the tax system.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to congratulate Senator Watson on bringing forward this motion today to put into proper perspective the disaster of the fringe benefits tax, the capital gains tax and the other actions which the Government has taken since September last year. Let me pick up just a few of the points that have come from Senator Richardson. He gave us answers about what this review is all about but no Minister has been prepared to answer on it in this place or in the House of Representatives in the last few days. We cannot get any clear answers from them as to what is intended. Yet Senator Richardson is able to speak on behalf of the Government, apparently, and tell us all about it. Who is running this Government? Is it a Hawke Government or a Richardson government? It sounds very much like a Richardson government. Most of the points that Senator Richardson raised were raised by us at the outset last May, in the initial debates on this legislation. Apparently it has taken the Government five months to wake up to the things that we were drawing attention to in this very Senate chamber during the debates on the legislation in May. Only now is it starting to address these issues. What kind of government, so-called, is it? It is supposed to be peopled by geniuses, but government members clearly do not understand what is wrong with this legislation and they have not right from the start.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at what Senator Richardson called abuses. He describes disabled people in need of home help who have to employ somebody to look after them at home as abusing the taxation system; consequently they will have to pay the fringe benefits tax. Companies which give gold watches to their employees after 25 years service or on retirement are apparently abusing the tax system and consequently have to pay fringe benefits tax. The Government goes on and on with these kinds of stupidities under this legislation. I will not reiterate them. Senator Watson did a great job in exposing the weaknesses of the legislation.

It is not just the Opposition which sees the stupidities in this legislation. Mr Acting Deputy President, you may have seen a Press release which came today from the Real Estate Institute of Australia. It refers to the administrative work load associated with this tax. It refers to the log books that have to be kept for motor cars. I shall quote a small piece:
But the log book at present is the only way to claim full entitlements to business deductions.
That is absolutely right, notwithstanding that Keating always gets it wrong. The Press release continues:
The need to spend at least half an hour a week making log book entries is an embuggerance we can well do without.

That is a firm statement which deserves to be written into the record. The Real Estate Institute of Australia understands the point which this Government has only just woken up to after five months of review.

Labor voters apparently are well aware of these stupidities as well. In the Daily Telegraph this morning is the result of an exclusive poll taken of voters throughout Australia on the Federal Government's fringe benefits tax. A total of 69 per cent of Labor voters say that the fringe benefits tax ought to be substantially modified or dropped altogether. Yet-this really makes the point-78 per cent of that same group of Labor voters, when asked `Have you been directly affected by the fringe benefits tax?' answered: `No'. So although nearly 80 per cent are not affected by the tax, they plainly see, by a margin of 69 per cent to 31 per cent, that it is such a stupidity that it ought to go. That makes the point absolutely clear that the Government's own constituency knows that this is the most stupid tax that has ever been introduced and should be repealed lock, stock and barrel.

Let us deal with this furphy of what Mr John Howard is supposed to have done or not done in regard to income tax avoidance. The man who crushed the tax avoidance industry of the 1970s was none other than the Treasurer of Australia at that time, John Howard, the now Leader of the Liberal Party in Canberra.

TALK.START.PARA: —Five years of intertia until he was flushed out by Costigan.

—Senator Walsh well knows that the legislation that destroyed the tax avoidance industry was introduced in 1980, the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act. It absolutely wiped out the industry in 1980 and Senator Walsh knows it. It was nothing to do with Labor's legislation. That law was passed three years before Labor came to office. Also, legislation was introduced to deal with specific schemes. I remember the legislation to deal with the Curran scheme and other asset stripping schemes of the same kind. Above all, I recall the legislation in 1981 to change substantially old section 260 of the Income Tax Assessment Act about which Senator Walsh complains so much in this place and to replace it with a whole new Part IVa, which was specifically designed to attack tax avoidance. Those actions alone absolutely destroyed the tax avoidance industry. The only tax legislation of any real moment this Government has introduced since it came to office is the package we saw last May, which came before us as a result of the Keating so-called tax package last year.

SPEECH.PARA: So let us have no more humbug about John Howard and tax avoidance, and let us turn to the real questions at issue. The reason why fringe benefits have become such a big problem in the avoidance industry is quite clearly the very steep marginal income tax structure. That has led to many people seeking to abuse the system in the way that it has been abused. We do not deny that. Nevertheless we believe that the fundamental change that should occur in order to curtail those avoidance schemes is a change in the income tax structure. That is why we are working to prepare policies that will introduce a system of lower and flatter rates of personal income tax. That is where the solution to these problems lies-not in band-aid proposals involving taxes as stupid as the fringe benefits tax which the Government has introduced.

Let us just look at what the Government says it will achieve by the introduction of a new tax structure by next July. When this Government came to office in March 1983, the marginal tax rate applying to the average weekly earner was 30 per cent. That is the tax rate that he paid on his next dollar of income. But lo and behold, after this Government has struggled mightily to bring in a new tax system to apply from July next year, that tax rate will go up to 40 per cent. That is how much better off the taxpayers of Australia will be. They will have a 10 per cent rise in the tax rate that they have to pay. The same applies to those taxpayers with a family, with a dependent spouse and two children. The tax rate applying for an average weekly earner in 1983 was 30 per cent but next year, after this episode, that rate will rise to 40 per cent.

This is the kind of nonsense that this Government goes on with-telling us that it will save us taxation when all it is doing is pushing us into higher and higher tax brackets. It is doing nothing in the way of fundamental tax reform and unfortunately the people of Australia will have to await the result of the next election before they get a National and Liberal Party Government which will change the tax system and fundamentally change the incentive of Australians. That will come.

Let us turn to some of the other points raised in this particularly good motion of Senator Watson that draws attention to the Government's tax failures. We have the famed capital gains tax that was a part of the package in which the fringe benefits tax nonsense was recently introduced. We are now starting to see that the Government is fundamentally breaking its promises in this area too. It has said to us on previous occasions that if one held assets before 19 September last year which were sold and a profit realised, one would not be taxed. This has been found to be absolutely untrue because many old people who have retired and many others in the community who have put money into unit trusts-a very common form of investment these days-now find that if there is a change in the membership of the unit trust of more than 50 per cent, they will pay capital gains tax on the profit they make on the eventual realisation of those units.

Similarly, we find that if a trust estate, such as a unit trust, buys and sells property and makes a profit, tax will apply it that profit insofar as there is a change to the underlying property of the trust which is thereby reflected in the unit holder's asset. One other area of real concern to the Opposition at present is the administration of the tax laws. The Commissioner for Taxation issues very many taxation rulings these days. I would like to refer to one-No. 2121-which sought to change the way in which contractors are taxed. It is true that there have been a large number of sham arrangements in this area which have deserved to be attacked by the Commissioner for Taxation. Senator Watson's motion acknowledges that. But it is also true that many contractors, in order to protect their assets and to limit attack from outside by creditors, have arranged themselves into limited liability companies. They have done so quite legitimately with the purpose in mind not of tax avoidance or evasion but of simply ordering their affairs in a business-like way. Yet those people are now being caught by the Commissioner's ruling No. 2121. It is leading to vast taxation disadvantages for people in that legitimate situation. This is again part and parcel of this Government's administration of the taxation law, which brings into question its bona fides in terms of what it is really on about in relation to tax abuse and evasion.

It is fascinating to see that there are to be no Australian Democrat speakers in this debate. I suppose that the reasons for that are painfully obvious-they were part and parcel of the deal done to introduce this nonsensical fringe benefits tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was a Keating-Haines Act, wasn't it?

—Yes, it was the Keating-Haines axis which introduced these fringe benefits and capital gains taxes and which disallowed legitimately incurred entertainment expenses, consequently leading to the deterioration of industries in this country. For Senator Walsh's benefit, I instance the wine industry, which of course will be affected in his own State. Those kinds of actions are part and parcel of the policy of the Democrats on taxation. Quite clearly they will have to answer to the electorate for that when the time comes.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is that most of the issues raised by Senator Watson so clearly during this debate and in his motion were raised during the initial debate on this tax legislation. The absolute shame is that this Government has taken five months to wake up to what was painfully obvious to everybody in this Senate at the time of that debate. We could have saved the people of Australia an enormous amount of worry, time and wasted energy had the Government listened to us in the first place and thought again about the introduction of this crazy fringe benefits tax legislation. The time has come when the Government deserves to be turned out, but before that happens we call upon it to repeal the fringe benefits tax lock, stock and barrel. We call upon it to face up to its responsibilities and modify the legislation so that we can at least have some kind of workable tax.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the motion of my colleague Senator Watson, who, together with others on this side of the chamber, has highlighted again the problems and confusion in the community which the Federal Government's fringe benefits tax has caused. Only a couple of weeks before employers are expected to lodge their first FBT declarations, we find ourselves in a chaotic situation where no one is certain of what they are expected to do. This has been exacerbated by the announcement this week by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) that the tax is to be reviewed.

SPEECH.PARA: This morning's newspapers reflect the dismal state this Federal Government is in and the problems it is foisting upon the nation. The story `Confusion reigns on review of FBT' in this morning's Australian sums it up. The Government's review is ill-defined, but then that should come as no surprise as it is consistent with the whole tax, which is ill-defined, confusing, indiscriminating and vague. I suppose that this is the sort of tax legislation one gets when the architects of the tax-the Prime Minister and the Treasurer (Mr Keating)-are so divided over how to deal with it. The Australian Financial Review this morning reported that the Prime Minister and the Treasurer cannot agree on how to review the tax, with Mr Hawke favouring the consensus approach while Mr Keating is all for the Australian Taxation Office controlling any modifications. Indeed, there appears to be a very serious rift between those two leaders of the nation.

Mr Hawke's consensus with the Australian community is wearing a bit thin and, with his inability to reach consensus within the ranks of his own Party, I do not like his chances of getting anywhere with the people who are really affected by this tax. But if he is really genuine in his wish to consult the community, I suggest that he consult those people who were polled by Newspol for the Sydney Daily Telegraph, as referred to by Senator Messner. Only 15 per cent of those polled were in favour of the tax. The overwhelming majority wanted the tax dropped or modified.

As for Mr Keating's wish to keep the review in the hands of the Taxation Office, I am not sure that that would be advisable in view of the confusion which is apparent there. Yesterday a Taxation Office spokesperson was reported as saying that the Office was still waiting to be told what was meant by the words `unintended consequences'. If the Taxation Office itself is still unaware of what changes are to take place, how is the Australian public expected to be able to make head or tail of the tax? No wonder accountancy firms, overwhelmed by the complexity of this legislation and the difficulty to employers in determining what liabilities they face under it, have lodged claims for deferments and extensions of time. It will be interesting to see how those who do not lodge returns by 28 October will be treated by the Taxation Office. Are employers still required to lodge their FBT statements by this date in view of the proposed review which has left them not knowing what they should declare?

It is appalling to see a Federal government which is so incompetent as to have taken from September last year to May this year to produce the legislation, to take from May to October to iron out what is going on. It is fewer than three weeks until the day when employers are supposed to lodge declarations, yet they have been threatened that failure to do so could mean they face gaol. Still the Federal Government has not been able to get its act together or even realise what it is doing.

Earlier this week the Prime Minister demonstrated his ignorance of the consequences of the fringe benefits tax for disabled persons who have to pay the tax on live-in help. He claimed that the Opposition was derelict in its duty in not raising the matter when, as many as four months ago, this issue was raised with the Treasurer in a letter from the honourable member for Wentworth, Mr Coleman. Clearly, the Government and its Ministers are not aware of the ramifications of this tax and are now back- pedalling as they realise just how much damage will be done within the electorate.

Senator Watson's motion makes particular mention of the effect of the tax on isolated areas, mining operations and small business. The effects upon these sectors have been examined in the Northern Territory in a study commissioned by a number of employer groups. I mentioned in the adjournment debate yesterday that I had presented a petition from 1,868 Northern Territory residents who are opposed to the fringe benefits tax, calling for its rescission on a number of grounds. The petition stated that the tax will increase both personal and company taxation; undermine employment levels through reducing profitability and international competitiveness; lead to price increases; force employers to withdraw voluntary incentives to employees paid over and above existing payments; and endanger stable industrial relations because of the potential for forced withdrawal of fringe benefits.

These are all legitimate concerns arising out of this legislation and when one considers the findings of the employer group study one sees that they can be substantiated. The employer groups involved were the Northern Territory Confederation of Industry and Commerce, the Master Builders Association of the Northern Territory, and many other organisations. The survey which was conducted represented a sample of 13.2 per cent of the private sector work force, which is quite a sizable sample and very reliable. As I have said, the survey was to establish in dollars and cents terms the impact of the FBT on the private sector, and the form and subsequent analysis were undertaken by an economist. One very interesting fact shown by the survey was that long-standing award provisions are now deemed to be fringe benefits taxable in the hands of the employer. These provisions are awards of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, they were not introduced or contemplated as tax avoidance schemes.

The survey concluded that the benefits of these employers which would be subject to the new taxation were worth about $60m, so the tax payable would be about $26m. The highest tax payable was estimated at $1,451 in the mining industry and, at the other end of the scale, the estimate was $258 per employee in the pastoral industry. The weighted average was $755 per employee. This taxation represents an increase in private sector costs of 5 per cent-and we are looking for development. The report addressed the administration difficulties with the tax and found that all Northern Territory employer organisations were having massive difficulty in advising their members as to the interpretation of the legislation. Of course, this is just a sample taken in the Northern Territory but it is a nationwide problem.

Senator Watson's motion referred to the administrative nightmares and massive paper burden imposed by this tax. Nowhere is such a burden more difficult to bear than on the land. Many pastoralists are flat out making enough merely to get by these days without being forced to fill in log books and to do massive amounts of paperwork justifying the meals and board they provide to workers. This legislation, which was supposed to catch the tax cheats, is hurting the little people more than anyone. But in the long run no one will win from this tax. It will hurt employers, employees and consumers alike.

In the Territory, as in other remote areas of Australia, we already have our fair share of additional costs to consumers. We can do without more. The FBT will impose particular hardships on outback people, the small people. It attacks subsidised housing, assistance with children's education-the small people's education-vehicle allowances and the like, which are part of many remote area employment packages over and above an employee's salary. These packages are provided to employees at all levels, not just to well-paid executives-there are not too many well-paid executives out in the scrub-and are often necessary to get people to live in remote and isolated areas.

Things such as assistance with air fares to southern States have been criticised as perks, but these are provided because most people in the Territory have come from elsewhere and still have their families in the south. It is only reasonable that they should be able to keep in touch with their families and have a holiday south. It is unreasonable that this assistance should be taxed, just as it is unreasonable that employers who fly people into the Territory for job interviews are liable to pay the tax. Relocation expenses should not be subject to this tax.

The introduction of this tax could literally kill development in the outback, with employers unable to offer the benefits which are necessary to bring people there. At a time when development and population growth are coming on very nicely, we now have the FBT to contend with. It is not a question of perks or handouts. The people of the north work very hard but often in much more difficult conditions than do their southern counterparts, and the incentives which employers provide are essential.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today to support my Tasmanian colleague Senator Watson in the motion he has moved. Yesterday we witnessed the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) finally cracking. He finally backed down on his beloved fringe benefits tax. That occurred, of course, only because Bob Ansett and the Livestock and Grain Producers Association have said that they will not pay the tax and have advised other people not to pay it. Indeed, they were leading a tax revolt. The Prime Minister could not allow one section of the community to refuse to pay the tax. Because he could not gaol them all-once one section of the community got away with not paying the tax everybody would join in the avalanche-the Prime Minister was forced to back down. He buckled as he promised to review the tax.

SPEECH.PARA: It is no use Senator Richardson blaming the Opposition for objecting to the fringe benefits tax being paid; there has been a general revolt by the people of Australia against the tax that is so unfair. As my colleagues have said today, a headline in the Daily Telegraph states `Australians reject perks tax'. We have the extraordinary situation in which 69 per cent of Australian Labor Party voters say that the tax is no good; and 78 per cent of those ALP voters say that is does not affect them but the injustice of it is appalling and they will not put up with it.

Let us find out what has been occurring. There is no doubt that at the moment there is a crisis in Australia regarding the fringe benefits tax. Today I asked the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) what advice he would give to people who would be travelling in the next fortnight and, as they were forced to compile their fringe benefits tax details before 28 October, they would have to do so this week. His advice to them was: `Abide by the law'. That would be very good advice if we knew what the law was. We have no idea what the law is. When I asked him to explain it, he hid behind the fact that it was a legal question and he did not have to answer it. There is, indeed, complete chaos. A headline in the Daily Telegraph reads: `Crisis talks on the FBT chaos'. The article reads:
As the fringe benefits tax confusion turned to chaos yesterday, the Federal Government decided to meet business groups next week in a desperate attempt to rescue the tax by the October 28 deadline.

What has been occurring to date, of course, is that, as the anomalies that the Labor Government did not even think about came up, the tax man has been asked by the Government to give his interpretation of the legislation. Following the debate in this House, the tax man came up with his interpretation of how it would affect farmers. It was not the legislation that we passed in this place, but the interpretation put on that legislation by the tax man under the direction of this Government. I asked the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) this question: What would be the situation if a farmer employed his son as a farm labourer on a full time salary? If that lad were living in the family home, eating meals cooked for him by the mother, would the farmer have to pay fringe benefits tax on the accommodation and meals, as would be the case in regard to any other employee? After great consultation with his bureaucrats who were sitting behind him, Senator Walsh came up with this extraordinary answer: `It depends whether the farmer is allowing his employee-his son-to have accommodation because he is his son or because he is an employee'. That, of course, was the first indication that the Opposition had that directions would be given to the tax man to place his interpretation on the legislation so that the Government would not appear to be backing down and having to amend the legislation.

Let us look at the part that has been played by the Australian Democrats. The Democrats have played a disgraceful part in this whole business. Open letters were written to the Democrats, stating that they had let down small business. One such letter stated:
This Country can no longer afford the luxury of having Senators--
that is, Democrat senators--
who have been elected by some 5 per cent of electors, controlling the destiny of the rest of the population.
In another letter we were told that the Democrats had made this statement in an article in the Sunday Telegraph of 1 June this year:
Now is the time to do unpopular things because the Australian memory is such that by the end of 1987, when the next election will be held, people will forget this.

That is an extraordinary way for the Democrats to carry on. They have told us that they are assisting the Government to bring in unpopular things. They then say: `But we are only doing it because by the end of 1987, when the election will be held, the Australian people will have forgotten about it, and it will not worry us'. Of course, that letter, Mr Acting Deputy President, as you know, states:

Well, now that's a coincidence. You see, I have already allowed for that contingency. I have planned to place a full page advertisement in the National Press every quarter, when the employers are filling out their quarterly Fringe Benefits Tax forms and cheques.

Those advertisements will certainly make the people well aware-and their memory will be refreshed every quarter-that the Democrats have let down small business and that the Democrats, by doing a deal with the Labor Government, had joined with it to pass this ridiculous piece of legislation.
