Headlines such as `Perk slug causes misery' have appeared in the Press. I refer to the various Labor Premiers who have come out of the woodwork. We have heard from the South Australian Premier, Mr Bannon, the Labor Leader in Queensland, Neville Warburton, Mr Burke and Mr Cain. The latest is Mr Unsworth. A newspaper article states:
The fringe benefits tax is making lives miserable and will cost the NSW Government at least $1 million to administer . . .
Mr Unsworth, who has been a staunch opponent of the way the FBT has been allowed to spread, yesterday launched his most vicious assault on the tax.
So all of the Premiers have abused the Federal Government and have said that the whole thing is unjust.

Let us look at the way in which the back bench is asking the Government to back off. Back benchers, according to the Australian as far back as August, have pleaded with the Prime Minister: `If you are going to keep this fringe benefits tax, for heaven's sake, let us sell it better. Let us get our story across to the people.' We then had the absurd situation of Senator Richardson saying today: `The people we are after, and the only ones we are after, are the big wigs'. He told us of one incident. The Treasurer, Mr Keating, of course, talks about the poor workers travelling by train, carrying their lunch in paper bags, looking out of the windows at the expensive cars. He does not talk about the farm labourers. He does not talk about the delicatessen owner who gives his employee free milk on a Friday as he closes the door. He does not talk about the butcher who gives his employees cheap meat on a Friday as he closes his doors for the weekend. The nervous back benchers are well aware of this, because they are more involved at the street level. They understand the problems that this fringe benefits tax is creating. The situation must be changed. Just as the little purple book that was first put out in May had to be withdrawn, this tax should no longer exist.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to join other Opposition senators who have spoken to this motion calling for the repeal of the Hawke Government's fringe benefits tax. I congratulate my colleague Senator Watson on moving the motion. There are many reasons for opposing this legislation and for opposing it with all the strength at our command. In doing so, I recognise, of course, that the tax came into being only because the Australian Democrats supported the Hawke Government. The Democrats supported a piece of legislation which is an absolute nightmare for small business, in terms of both cost and administration. Yet the Democrats have the pathetic hypocrisy to parade themselves as the champions of small business. Nothing could be further from the truth. That is perhaps not surprising, because truth and integrity are not words which spring readily to mind when one thinks of the Democrats.

SPEECH.PARA: The Hawke Government's fringe benefits tax is wrong in principle because it violates the cardinal rule of taxation-that is, that tax should be paid by the receiver of the benefits, not by the giver. The Hawke Government's legislation taxes the giver. Apart from the total inequity and abrogation of principle that this involves, it also imposes a double cost on the provider of the benefit. The provider has to pay the fringe benefits tax as a business cost but is then not allowed to claim it as a deductible income tax item. The inevitable result, of course, is increased costs to business and increased inflation to consumers.

The fringe benefits tax violates three of the basic tax principles which the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) laid down prior to the 1984 election. First, he said that any changes to the system should simplify the system. Yet, here he introduces a new tax which comprises 139 pages of legislation, 176 pages of explanatory memorandum, two booklets of 69 pages, 14 rulings of 115 pages and innumerable pamphlets, Press releases and a video tape. Some simplification! Not even the Taxation Office can understand it. It has become blindingly clear in recent days that the Prime Minister, the Treasurer (Mr Keating), Senator Walsh, Mr Hurford and Senator Button have no clue as to what it is all about. By the way, guess who is the presenter on the video tape. I am advised that he is none other than Richard Carleton, that intrepid blood-on-your-hands interviewer of the Prime Minister. What an irony that is.

The second of the Prime Minister's own principles which this tax violates is that of providing the best possible climate for investment, growth and employment. In total contrast, this iniquitous tax imposes a mountain of incomprehensible and non-productive administrative paper work and excessive compliance costs. The fringe benefits tax will inhibit investment, retard growth and reduce employment. We are already seeing this in many areas, even before the first tax instalment is due. The motor vehicle industry is a vital case in point. The third of the Prime Minister's principles which the fringe benefits tax violates is that tax changes should have wide community support. As already mentioned, a national survey published in today's Sydney Daily Telegraph indicates that 75 per cent of Australians want the fringe benefits tax dropped altogether or modified. So much for widespread community support.

Other speakers in this debate have mentioned many examples of the iniquity of this tax. The Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals will be forced to pay $50,000 in fringe benefits tax this year because of the free accommodation that it supplies to its lowly paid regional inspectors in homes that are used also as 24-hour animal shelters. An 80-year-old crippled war widow pensioner in Melbourne will have to pay fringe benefits tax on the meals and accommodation provided to the live-in housekeeper without whom she cannot live.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't forget the National Trust.

—The National Trust of Australia is also affected. I am advised that the contribution by an employer to the cost of funerals of employees, including employees who may have been killed at work, is also subject to the fringe benefits tax. The tax will apply also when the children of farm hands living in remote areas become ill and the employer provides medical treatment or transport to a hospital. The tax will apply also to the prizes which sporting clubs provide to their members, the free car-parking spaces that are provided by an employer for his employees and the use of a farm vehicle by a worker living on a farm simply to drive his kids to the bus stop. The list is endless.
—What about taxi fares?

—It affects many taxi fares as well. The list goes on and on. I will conclude my brief remarks today, because time is short, by mentioning one other example which to my knowledge has not been made public. I refer to the very long and very complex application of the fringe benefits tax to film production. I will highlight a couple of the more ridiculous aspects. Accommodation away from home for film crews, actors, director, producer, et cetera, is not subject to fringe benefits tax. However, the cost of breakfast has to be withdrawn from the accommodation component because meals are treated differently for fringe benefits purposes. Breakfast provided to employees with accommodation is subject to fringe benefits tax at the rate of $2 per breakfast. I am advised by the Screen Production Association of Australia that, unless and until the Tax Office changes its present position, fringe benefits tax is payable at 46 per cent of $2 for each lunch provided to crew and cast on location away from home. But when the crew and actors are not filming away from home, fringe benefits tax is payable at 46 per cent of the total cost of the meal to the producer. When filming away from home and using country extras-say, in a provincial centre such as Ballarat-the lunch of the crew and the major cast is taxable at 46 per cent of $2, but the country extras would be taxable at 46 per cent of the total cost of the meal.

SPEECH.PARA: What are we coming to in this country? How crazy can we get? How long can we survive the stupidity of this bureaucratic socialist ideology? Four weeks ago the Prime Minister said that the fringe benefits tax: `will not be watered down. No, we will not change it'. Yesterday he changed his tune and said that aspects of the tax will be reviewed, that the review will be completed in three weeks, by the end of October, and that in undertaking this review the Government would listen to what people think. I think the Prime Minister had best enjoy or make the most of the next few days because when Paul gets back from his present overseas soiree he will not be at all amused by this further cave-in by his so-called leader. Today in this chamber the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) was unable to tell me in detail who would conduct the review or when it would commence. He was totally unable to tell me whether the public would be able to make submissions to enable the Government to listen, as it says it wants to do, to what the people think. No amount of review will correct the fundamental flaws and the iniquities contained in the Hawke Government's fringe benefits tax.

The tax is bad law. It violates long standing theories of taxation. It violates the Government's own tax principles. It is a legal nightmare, it is vague, it is ambiguous, it is contradictory and it is a total shambles. It is the product of a socialistic, ideologically twisted government that is totally out of touch with the real world. It must be repealed. It appears though, and it is certain, that this Government will not take this step. The next government-a Liberal and National Party government-will, and that is a total and unequivocal commitment which the Leader of the Opposition, John Howard, has given on behalf of the coalition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The only Government speaker on this matter today has been Senator Richardson who, as everyone knows, is the de facto leader of this Government. The interesting thing is that when he spoke he in fact made no effective response to the very serious concerns that have been expressed across a wide range of Australians-not simply the Opposition, not simply big business but in fact those people who are most affected by this tax-the ordinary Australians, the decent Australians, the honest taxpaying Australian, so many thousands of whom have been hit unfairly, unreasonably and improperly by this tax, and particularly those who are disadvantaged. We have heard many instances of people-Senator Short has just raised some of them-such as paraplegics or persons involved in non-profit organisations who are being obliged to suffer.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting to note that Senator Richardson's basic complaint about the Opposition was that it had provided no details of its tax policy and that, as a result-the impression I got was that this was the burden of his argument-it should not be listened to on this matter, whether or not it happens to be reflecting the attitudes of the great bulk of Australians. We have just heard in this place the results of a recent poll conducted by the Sydney Daily Telegraph. Let us recognise this: Senator Richardson's incredible hypocrisy really bears examining. Before the last election in December 1984 Senator Richardson was a member of a party which went to an election with no tax policy beyond the policy of saying: `We will have a meeting to discuss what our tax policies should be after the election'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Didn't he say no capital gains tax?

—As my friend Senator Watson interjects, the Australian Labor Party did have one positive element in its tax policy, and that was that there would be no capital gains tax, and that was said in words that even we could understand. I think it is remarkable that Senator Richardson expects the people of Australia to have such short memories that they are incapable of remembering this perfidy by the Party opposite, this perfidious performance under which it first promised that there would be no capital gains tax and then introduced one. Then it had the hide to go to an election with no remaining tax policy whatsoever beyond saying: `We will talk about it. We will have a talkfest'. A key member of that same Party in this chamber, in fact the key member of that Party, if one believes what goes on on the 10th floor of hotels where the Australian Labor Party has its conferences, has had the hide to criticise the Opposition at this stage, 18 months before an election, for not being prepared to state in detail how it is going to achieve its tax objectives. Yet the Party opposite had no policy whatsoever at election time.

SPEECH.PARA: We will, in fact, have a policy stated clearly at election time so that the people of Australia can make a judgment on which party's policy they prefer. I imagine that the Government's performance and the performance of Senator Richardson today will underline the dramatic difference between the positive policy--

TALK.START.PARA: —We've still got it.

—As Senator Messner interjects, we still do have a policy. The only thing we are not divulging at the moment is our method of achieving those policy objectives. For the benefit of people such as Senator Richardson or those he has managed to confuse, let me restate that it is key and central to our tax policy that abuses involving tax avoidance should be dealt with and removed. That is essential. We are not saying how we will achieve that, for a variety of reasons, the first of which is that, quite frankly, we are sick and tired of having policies we announce knocked off by the Government because it is incapable of developing its own.
—Except messes like this.
—Except of course, to create messes such as this, which, I hasten to say, is an example of their not following our policy.
—It is a mess.

—When the Government goes it alone it makes an incredible mess, as Senator Watson quite rightly interjects. Here the Opposition has a clear policy thrust, a clear set of objectives, and this Government is endeavouring to muddy that water by pretending that somehow it is in a stronger moral position. What kind of morality is that? I suppose we could ask what kind of person would claim his to be a moral position? What kind of person could possibly justify going to the last election with no tax policy beyond a promise not to introduce a capital gains tax, and then criticising us, 18 months before an election, for not having released the fine tuning details of how we will achieve our policy objectives, which were clearly stated in 1984 and which continue to this day. Our policy objectives in taxation are clear. They are to reduce the incidence of taxation and to reduce even further the incidence of income taxation by replacing it in some areas with a broader based consumption tax, and then to stop abuses involving tax avoidance. There is no doubt about that.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the confusions that have emerged over this tax. I have some very strong views about this indeed. There certainly is confusion because when a member of my staff rang the Taxation Office today to try to get a copy of the video that was being made available-one of the many expensive items that have been produced by the Government to try to justify and/or explain this ludicrous tax-she was told that it was not available, that it had been withdrawn from distribution.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is inaccurate.

—Because frankly the Taxation Office just does not know whether it is accurate or not. Senator Newman is quite right. The Government has no idea what is going to happen to this tax at the moment and the Taxation Office presumably has less idea than even the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). Heaven knows, we have already seen that he has no idea.
—We do not know what the unintended consequences are.

—We know nothing of the unintended consequences because as far as I am concerned-every one of those consequences that Mr Hawke is calling unintended was pointed out to him, over the last two, three or four months-and as far as the Taxation Office is concerned I believe those consequences were not unintended; they were intended consequences. The letter from Mr Hurford, as Acting Treasurer, to our colleague Peter Coleman in other place clearly indicates that those consequences were intended and that the intention was that they should not be removed. This relates to the paraplegic person in particular.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the other confusions that are taking place. In the Public Service, which has to pay this fringe benefits tax at a cost to the taxpayer, there is overwhelming confusion. Honourable senators who were in the House today would have been made aware that during the hearing of the Senate Estimates Committee inquiry into the Department of Defence, we were told that the Department made a $45m mistake about what it thought should be its fringe benefits tax bill. That was a 40 per cent mistake. In its original estimates the Department of Defence allocated $115m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does it include the rations tax and other items?

—Senator Newman asks whether it includes these various items. Who knows what it involves. The essential point is that the Department of Defence made that estimate in good faith. It then found, after lengthy discussion with the Tax Office, that perhaps it may have been wrong and as a result has subsequently amended that amount to $70m. It was wrong by $45m.
—What sort of resources did they use?

—As Senator Watson says, what sort of resources had to be used within the Public Service to establish what were the realities of this tax? To what extent did it depend on the Taxation Office putting out subsequent clarifying statements, changing things around and creating confusion? If the Public Service is confused about this, for heaven's sake, what about the ordinary taxpayer? Even worse, I continually asked other departments whether they would stand by their budgeted fringe benefits tax amounts and how strongly they would do so. Most of them said: `Well, they are a degree of rubbery'. This is clearly one of the rubbery elements. If the departments do not know, if the Government does not know, how can the ordinary taxpayer be expected to know?

SPEECH.PARA: Another thing I want to know is whether the Prime Minister will have to pay a fringe benefits tax on the nights he is spending at the Regent Hotel in Sydney while Kirribilli House is being renovated over five months at a cost of half a million dollars? Having just spent half a million dollars on the Lodge, he is now spending half a million dollars on Kirribilli House. According to him, it is urgent, immediate and essential expenditure. He is the only person who thinks that that is so at this time of restraint. I understand that he receives an allowance when staying in other capital cities. There is no doubt that the cost of staying at the Regent Hotel would be far above whatever the Remuneration Tribunal allows. This sort of question comes to mind: Will the Prime Minister's Department have to pay fringe benefits tax on the cost of staying in that place? There is a whole range of uncertainty about this, and that is why I strongly support Senator Watson's motion. I congratulate him on bringing it forward. It is about time that we had a more coherent response from the Government on all these serious questions affecting many thousands of Australians. For heavens sake, stop talking about the rip-off merchants and start talking about the real people, the decent people who will be unfairly hit by this tax.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Watson's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN INSTITUTE OF SPORT BILL 1986AUSTRALIAN INSTITUTE OF SPORT (CONSEQUENTIAL PROVISIONS) BILL 1986

Consideration resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee is considering clause 15 of the Australian Institute of Sport Bill 1986 and an amendment moved by Senator Vigor to insert a new sub-clause (6) (a) in the clause. The question is that the words proposed to be inserted be inserted.

—A number of remarks, including those by Senator Puplick, have been made on this subject. One has to point out that we have women's sports and men's sports rather than persons' sports. As we have women's sports bodies and men's sports bodies which are separated by the community it is important that there be equal representation of men and women on the Board of the Australian Institute of Sport. If we had persons' sports bodies I might agree that the merit alone should be used for selecting the board. But in this case I believe that both women's and men's sports, each representing approximately 50 per cent of the community, should be equally represented on the Board of the Institute.

—Although I am in sympathy with the spirit of Senator Vigor's amendment I remind him that it is the policy of our Government, and one we have gone to considerable lengths to implement, that on any Government appointed body there should be as far as possible equal representation of the sexes. In that sense, the amendment is unnecessary and therefore it is not accepted. The intent, of course, is incorporated in the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to correct an Australian Associated Press report dealing with this matter which states that, despite what is described as a tortuous explanation of this clause, the amendment was passed by 35 votes to 27. Whether the statement on the part of AAP that the clause will be passed by 35 votes to 27 was a prophetic one-in which case AAP knows that the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) and the Australian Democrats have done yet another deal and nobody else has been informed of it-or whether on this occasion Senator Ryan, having said that she will not accept the amendment, will stick by her guns and not accept it, we shall wait to see. I wanted to indicate my understanding that the report, which has already appeared on the wire service, that this amendment has been passed by 35 votes to 27 is not correct.

Clause agreed to.

Page 2, sub-clause 6 (1), sub-paragraph (a) (ii), after `coaches', insert `, umpires, referees or officials essential to the conduct of sport'.
I canvassed this matter fully in my original speech on these two amendments. I thank the Government for keeping to its arrangement in this case. I commend the amendments to the Senate.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLARD
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —One Simon Cameron once said that an honest politician is one who, once he has been bought, stays bought. I do not know how one interprets the behaviour of the Australian Democrats at this stage. As Senator Puplick said in his dissertation this morning on the Democrats and their behaviour, they are for rent, and they are for rent by the hour. We have now seen what the Democrats are really all about. We are still opposed to the amendments. We think they are a useless exercise in semantics. As I indicated this morning, the phrase `persons who excel' covers all. But for the purpose of the experiment, and obviously for Senator Ryan to get her Bill through, the Government has succumbed to the tremendous pressure that has been put on it by the Senate's rent-a-crowd. So the amendments obviously will be passed. I will not be calling for a division, but I place on the record that these amendments are a useless exercise in semantics. It has all been covered. But everybody has his price.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the amendments moved by Senator Vigor and wish to comment on remarks made by Senator Puplick both in the Committee stage of the consideration of this Bill and earlier in the debate on the motion for its resumption. Senator Puplick commented about the diligence with which Senator Vigor pursues his work in this place. Senator Puplick might find it better if he were to do more work rather than if Senator Vigor were to do less work. The clear implication of what Senator Puplick said was that he felt that Senator Vigor was working too hard for Senator Puplick's comfort. I give Senator Puplick that mild injunction, that mild piece of advice. If he applies himself to his work as a senator with more diligence he might not have to force himself to make that sort of invidious comparison.

SPEECH.PARA: As for Senator Collard's bleat that the coalition did not know what was going on, how can one expect to give any information to a party as gutless, spineless and hypocritical as the Liberal-National Party which hides behind the specious excuse, which all its members know to be a lie, that certain things must not be touched here because they are reported here on Budget night? I say to Senator Puplick and Senator Collard that they are a part of this gutless organisation which has betrayed and sold out people by the millions. Even over the last week it sold them out over the ex-servicemen's pensions and superannuation-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Mason, we are discussing two amendments moved by Senator Vigor to clause 6. Senator Puplick's remarks were made in another context and are not up for debate now.

—With respect to you, Mr Chairman, Senator Puplick remarked again only a few minutes ago that he wondered why the Opposition was not informed about the arrangements we had made about these amendments. That is the point I was addressing.
—As long as you confine your remarks to the amendments you may proceed.

—I will indeed do so. Thank you very much for your advice, Mr Chairman. These amendments are now to be accepted by the Government. We are pleased that that is to happen. It is a part of normal negotiation over legislation which is to be applauded and which allows the smooth workings of this place to proceed. On that basis I commend the amendments to the Senate and especially to the Opposition.

We move this amendment with the intention of not giving the chairman of the Board any special position. We believe that the normal practice would be for a chairman, if he had the casting vote, to vote in the negative. However, we would prefer to have it written into the legislation. Unlike the other amendments, it is not an amendment on which hinges the fate of the Bill. However, it is an amendment to which we would like the Committee to agree.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLARD
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not quite sure what Senator Vigor puts the fate of the Bill on. However, we will oppose the amendment. Most organisations, except this august chamber, give their chairman the ability to have a casting voter. The main reason why the chairman in this august chamber does not have a casting vote is the equality of representations from the States. A casting vote by the chairman would undoubtedly give an advantage to one State over the other States and would give that State literally an extra senator. Not giving such a vote to an organisation that is as likely to have a deadlock as is any other organisation is as ludicrous as half the other stuff we have heard from the Australian Democrats today.

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendment proposed by Senator Vigor in our view suggests a lack of confidence in the chair. We do not share that lack of confidence, so we will not accept the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Pages 6 to 8, clauses 17 and 18, line 14 (page 6) to line 5 (page 8), leave out the clauses, insert the following clause:
Application of Division 2 of Part XI of Audit Act in relation to year ending on 30 June 1987

``17. Division 2 of Part XI of the Audit Act 1901 (as that Division applies by virtue of sub-section 38 (1) of the Australian Institute of Sport Act 1986) has effect in relation to the year ending on 30 June 1987 as if-
(a) sub-sections 63G (3) and (4) were omitted and the following sub-sections were substituted:

`(2A) The Auditor-General may inspect and audit such of the accounts and records of financial transactions (including transactions relating to money received or held on trust) of the company named ``Australian Institute of Sport'' that was incorporated on 24 September 1980 under the Companies Ordinance 1962 of the Australian Capital Territory and records relating to the assets (including assets held on trust) of, or in the custody of, the company, being accounts and records in so far as they-
(a) relate to the period commencing on 1 July 1986 and ending immediately before the Australian Institute of Sport Act 1986 came into operation; and
(b) have become assets of the authority under section 12 of that Act,

and shall forthwith draw the attention of the appropriate Minister in relation to the authority to any irregularity disclosed by the inspection and audit that is, in the opinion of the Auditor-General, of sufficient importance to justify the Auditor-General in so doing.
`(3) The Auditor-General shall-

(a) at least once in the year ending on 30 June 1988, report to the appropriate Minister the results of the inspection and audit carried out under sub-section (1) of the accounts and records of the authority in so far as they relate to the period commencing on the day on which the Australian Institute of Sport Act 1986 came into operation and ending on the expiration of 30 June 1987; and

(b) at the time at which the Auditor-General makes the first such report to that Minister, also report to that Minister the results of any inspection and audit, carried out by the Auditor-General under this Act or any other Act, of the accounts and records of the company referred to in sub-section (2A) in so far as they relate to the period commencing on 1 July 1986 and ending immediately before the Australian Institute of Sport Act 1986 came into operation.
`(4) The Auditor-General or a person authorised by the Auditor-General is entitled at all reasonable times to full and free access to-

(a) all accounts and records of the authority relating directly or indirectly to the receipt or payment of money by the authority or to the acquisition, receipt, custody or disposal of assets by the authority; and

(b) all accounts and records of the company referred to in sub-section (2a) that have become assets of the authority under section 12 of the Australian Institute of Sport Act 1986, being accounts and records relating directly or indirectly to the receipt or payment of money (including money received or held by the company on trust) by the company or to the acquisition, receipt, custody or disposal of assets (including assets received or held by the company on trust) by the company.'; and
(b) section 63h were omitted and the following section were substituted:
Annual report and financial statements
`63h. (1) The authority shall, as soon as practicable after 30 June 1987, prepare and submit to the appropriate Minister in relation to the authority a report of-

(a) the operations of the company referred to in sub-section 63g (2a) during the period (in this section referred to as the ``first period'') commencing on 1 July 1986 and ending immediately before the Australian Institute of Sport Act 1986 came into operation; and

(b) the operations of the authority during the period (in this section referred to as the ``second period'') commencing on the day on which that Act came into operation and ending on the expiration of 30 June 1987,
together with financial statements in respect of the year ending on 30 June 1987, in such form as the Minister administering this Act approves, that-
(c) in so far as they are statements in respect of the first period, relate to the company during that period; and
(d) in so far as they are statements in respect of the second period, relate to the authority during that period.
`(1a) The report referred to in sub-section (1) shall, in so far as it relates to the company referred to in sub-section 63g (2a), be prepared by the authority having regard to-
(a) such of the accounts and records of the company as have become assets of the authority under section 12 of the Australian Institute of Sport Act 1986; and
(b) any information concerning the operation of the company that is given to the authority by persons who were members of the Board of Management or staff of the company.

`(1b) The financial statements referred to in sub-section (1) shall, in so far as they relate to the company referred to in sub-section 63g (2a), be based on the accounts and records referred to in paragraph (1a) (a) of this section.
`(2) Before submitting financial statements to the appropriate Minister under sub-section (1), the authority shall submit them to the Auditor-General, who shall report to the appropriate Minister-
(a) whether, in the opinion of the Auditor-General, the statements are based on proper accounts and records;
(b) whether the statements are in agreement with the accounts and records and, in the opinion of the Auditor-General, show fairly-
(i) the financial transactions of the company referred to in sub-section 63g (2a) during the first period; and
(ii) the financial transactions and the state of affairs of the authority during the second period;

(c) whether, in the opinion of the Auditor-General, the receipt, expenditure and investment of monies and the acquisition and disposal of assets, by the company during the first period have been in accordance with the law;

(d) whether, in the opinion of the Auditor-General, the receipt, expenditure and investment of monies and the acquisition and disposal of assets, by the authority during the second period have been in accordance with the enactment establishing the authority; and
(e) as to such matters arising out of the statements as the Auditor-General considers should be reported to the appropriate Minister.

`(3) The appropriate Minister shall cause copies of the report and financial statements together with a copy of the report of the Auditor-General to be laid before each House of the Parliament within 15 sitting days of that House after their receipt by the appropriate Minister.'.''.
This amendment simply put into effect the amendment that the Committee has just approved.
Amendment agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.

DEBATE.TITLE: INSPECTOR-GENERAL OF INTELLIGENCE AND SECURITY BILL 1986AUSTRALIAN SECURITY INTELLIGENCE ORGANIZATION AMENDMENT BILL 1986INTELLIGENCE AND SECURITY (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 11 June, on motion by Senator Button:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security Bill 1986, the Australian Security Intelligence Organization Amendment Bill 1986, and the Intelligence and Security (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1986 make major changes-very serious changes in our view-to the legislation dealing with the administration and control of Australia's intelligence agencies. Of course, those agencies are not confined simply to the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation; they comprise the Australian Secret Intelligence Service, the Joint Intelligence Organisation, known as JIO, the Office of National Assessments and the Defence Signals Directorate. This legislation is comprehensive, but its main impact and focus, as one would expect in legislation from the present Government, seems as usual to be directed at ASIO. That is not surprising because the Australian Labor Party has a continuing paranoia, to the point of obsession, about ASIO. As the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr N. A. Brown) said in another place when speaking on this legislation:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . I would not trust the Australian Labor Party as far as I could kick it so far as its having anything to do with the security services of this country is concerned.

I certainly agree with and adopt the attitude expressed by Mr Brown in the debate in the other place. The concern that we have about the Labor Party's ability to influence a Labor government, particularly in relation to ASIO but in relation to security services generally, is well justified because of this continuing evidence of paranoia by major elements of the Party, certainly in the left wing, and, I think, because of some concerns of a somewhat prurient kind in other areas. Unfortunately, the man responsible for introducing this legislation, the Deputy Prime Minister and Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen), and other people whom I regard as the saner elements in the Party in these matters, have been too weak-kneed to resist the pressures which have been brought to bear upon the Government, through the Party organisation generally, about matters of security in general and ASIO in particular.

There is no doubt that the proposals in this legislation are politically motivated and will result in a further shackling, in particular of ASIO. That is very serious and very sad. The Government justifies its action and these wide-ranging amendments by falling back on the report of Mr Justice Hope. It says that it is implementing the Hope recommendations. To a large extent that is so. It is implementing Hope recommendations, but it is implementing a very major matter which Mr Justice Hope rejected-namely, the establishment of a joint parliamentary committee to oversee ASIO. That proposal was well canvassed before Mr Justice Hope and he rejected it. There are other matters in the legislation which certainly implement the recommendations. That proposal is not implementing a recommendation of Mr Justice Hope; it is, in fact, implementing a proposal which he specifically rejected. That is probably the centrepiece of this whole exercise. It is certainly a matter which gives the Opposition the greatest concern. I say at this stage that we will be voting against the amendments to the Australian Security Intelligence Organization Act, primarily because of the proposal to set up this committee but also because of other criticisms which I will develop later.

Before I go into the details, I want to speak generally about the question of our security services. I will direct my remarks mainly to ASIO because I think that is the focus of this government legislation and this obsessive interest by many members of the Australian Labor Party and the Government. ASIO has been well and truly investigated and well and truly reformed over the last 10 years or so. The Whitlam Government set up a royal commission presided over by Mr Justice Hope, who reported to the Fraser Government. It proceeded substantially to implement his report in a major piece of legislation that was passed by this Parliament in 1979. Whatever ASIO's faults may have been in the past, as a result of that investigation by Mr Justice Hope, as a result of the appointment of the Director-General, Mr Justice Woodward, who presided over the Organisation with great success and distinction for a number of years-his work was carried on by his successor, Mr Barnett-and as a result of the morale and resource building of that Organisation by the Fraser Government, it was transformed in those years.

Mr Justice Hope came back again to look at the Organisation. He was invited to do so and was given a further commission in 1983-84. At the end of 1984 he made his report, the recommendations of which the Government says it is now implementing in this legislation. He had a lot of interesting things to say in his report about the Organisation, comparing it as it is now with the Organisation he first looked at. He specifically mentioned the changes that he had found. He said:
The ASIO that I have reviewed is very different from the ASIO that I got to know during the RCIS.
That was his previous royal commission. He went on to say:
My overall view is that ASIO has properly served the interests of the Australian people and Government in recent years and that it has done so with a fair degree of effectiveness.

He went on to canvass the continuing need for security services to defend, by their work, the basic interests and the security of the nation. Mr Justice Hope, referring to his earlier Royal Commission, said:

. . . I reported that Australia needs intelligence of quality, timeless and relevance, and that for this purpose it requires to have a highly professional system of intelligence and security services. These needs are as important as they were a decade ago, and indeed the matters in respect of which Australia requires intelligence have expanded considerably.
The report which is the subject of this legislation goes on to say:

The product of Australia's intelligence services is of great value to the nation. No doubt there will always be room for improvement, and no doubt their need for resources will always have to be measured against the proper claims of other national interests. I am satisfied, however, that Australia's investment in its intelligence services is well justified, and that governments should continue to ensure that they are able to fulfil the important roles they play in helping to advise and protect Australia's national interests.

That is what we are concerned about; that is what this debate is a about. Those considerations will be gravely affected by many of the proposals in the legislation the Government has placed before us and for which it is seeking our support. Security services must be secret; they cannot be otherwise. The importance of their work for the nation and for the protection of our liberties is at the very core of this debate. As I have said, they are the very things which so many people in the Labor Party do not understand. I regret that many people in the community-I hope there are not any in the Labor Party-want to see those things destroyed. Legislation of this kind which puts more and more shackles on the effectiveness of such organisations has to be considered seriously. If the requirements placed upon the organisations are too severe such proposals should be opposed and certainly deplored.

Mr Justice Hope is not the only person who has been making this point about the need for proper security organisations and in particular the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation, but of course he is the person to whom Labor governments turned on two occasions to investigate and report on the Organisation. So even by the Government and members of the Labor Party one would expect him to be accepted as an authority. Interestingly, the new Director-General of ASIO, Mr Alan Wrigley, formerly Deputy Secretary of the Department of Defence, recently spoke at the National Press Club about the ASIO that he has found in the just over 12 months that he has been its Director-General. In the speech to the Press Club he addressed the need that Australia has for an organisation such as ASIO. He emphasised the threats within our society to the maintenance of our basic values, institutions and freedoms. He made it clear that, as any sane person would know, there are threats in our society and people are working away to undermine and destroy our society. Such people could be just as effective, if they were not properly watched, controlled and resisted, as an enemy from outside. Indeed, the activities of these people are in many cases directed and financed by enemies from outside-foreign governments and foreign organisations of one sort of another which are engaged in trying to undermine and subvert our institutions and our basic ways of life. Mr Wrigley has pointed this out. To the Press-it was well directed at the Press because it has been very reckless and irresponsible generally in this country in the way in which it has reported on this matter-Mr Wrigley said:

You shouldn't be under the slightest doubt that there are undeclared foreign intelligence officers working in Australia today, and some of them use coercion and prey on character or family vulnerabilities and other human frailties in order to enlist Australian residents to work against this country's interests.

He went on to talk about those engaged here in preparing for terrorist activities or politically motivated violence, which is of course abhorrent to us. He instanced a case in Australia at the end of 1982. He said that several hundred people could have been killed if it were not for very skilled intelligence work-as recently as at the end of 1982. He also went on to talk about the other important needs of ASIO. He said that even though the old concept of subversion had been removed from the Australian Security and Intelligence Organisation Act, nevertheless the sorts of activities and threats that used to come under that concept of subversion were now being brought back into the charter of ASIO. There is a focusing on matters which may not be called subversion but which concern much the same things as used to be called subversion. These are realities in our lives. We need these intelligence agencies to cope with them. We need intelligence agencies that are efficient and well resourced. Although they must be accountable to somebody they should not be hobbled or shackled by so many controls that they are ineffective.

Let us turn to the controls that have been put on ASIO in recent years very much as a result of the first Hope report. ASIO now operates under a charter. As Mr Justice Hope found, it operates within the legalities of that charter. If it does not operate under that charter it can be challenged in the courts of this country, as it has been in the High Court of Australia. Of course, it is subject to the general control of the Attorney-General, the Minister responsible for it; but the Prime Minister of the day traditionally takes a great interest in the activities of the Organisation.

ASIO reports annually to the Government and tables in the Parliament a version of its report in which secret and sensitive matters are eliminated. The full ASIO report must be given to the Leader of the Opposition and the Leader of the Opposition must be consulted on the appointment of the Director-General of ASIO. People who have been the subject of an adverse or qualified security assessment can appeal to the Security Appeals Tribunal. Since it was set up by the 1979 legislation it has overturned a number of decisions of the Director-General on such matters. The Attorney-General of the day, as Mr Wrigley recognised in his speech to the Press Club, personally signs warrants for telephone interceptions and listening devices which are legally available to ASIO under the proper procedures in existing legislation. Having been the Minister responsible for ASIO for 5 1/2 years, I can confirm that the personal attention which is required of the Attorney-General in respect of applications for warrants, which Mr Wrigley has said is still continuing, means that the Attorney has a great deal of knowledge of the way ASIO works and so has a major degree of control, particularly over human rights and civil liberty questions. In place at the moment is a series of bipartisan controls-I mentioned the role of the Leader of the Opposition-which work effectively, and it is very difficult to see why more are required.

Under this legislation, in addition to all those controls that already exist, the Government proposes to establish an Inspector-General of Security Agencies. Admittedly he will oversee not only ASIO but also all the other security agencies, but the Government again seems to be focusing his attention on ASIO. The Inspector-General, either on his own initiative or at the request of the Prime Minister or the Attorney, will investigate virtually the whole range of activities of intelligence organisations, but particularly ASIO. The legislation gives him a much greater focus on ASIO than on the others. It will obviously be a very sensitive office. The Inspector-General will virtually sit in the room next door to the heads of any of these agencies when he is devoting his attention to them. I have no doubt that he will be spending a lot of time with and, in effect, second-guessing the work of the Director-General of ASIO. When directions are given to ASIO by the Minister of the day the Inspector-General will have to be shown them and he can comment on them in his annual report. He will be virtually looking over the shoulder of the Attorney as well.

It is very difficult to see how in practice his role will be other than virtually a dual control of these organisations. On the one hand there will be the Director-General or Director of an organisation, whatever he may be called, and on the other hand there will be the Director-General of Security. This is a major new and additional person who will have to be responded to by the security organisations and to whom the organisations will be clearly answerable and accountable. This is in addition to this panoply of control that I have already referred to.

In addition to the creation of this new office of Director-General there is to be a wider role for the Attorney-General. He now will have much more direct control over ASIO. He can even direct organisations as to who they will and will not investigate. He cannot direct them as to the advice they give, but he can direct them individually. This is a grave political problem which we will debate at the Committee stage in more detail. I think there is a grave political danger created in this legislation of using ASIO for political purposes.

In addition to this wider role of the Attorney-General and this new office of Inspector- General, the proposal is to create a parliamentary joint statutory committee as well. Although certain matters will be excluded from it, such as sources and the operations of the organisations, nevertheless the organisations will have to account to that committee. That is in addition to accounting to the Attorney, the Prime Minister, the Leader of the Opposition, the Security Appeals Tribunal and the Director-General of Security. It is really the totality of these new proposals which the Opposition believes are so serious because they introduce so many more requirements for reporting that the degree of accountability expected from the intelligence organisations, and particularly from ASIO, will mean that a great deal of work of the senior officers of the organisations will be taken up in accounting for what they are doing and explaining what they are doing, or want to do. The time they have to devote to running and achieving the purposes of the organisations will be seriously affected.
There is no doubt that the morale of ASIO has been seriously affected in recent years. In Mr Justice Hope's latest report he sadly reported on the morale that he found in 1983 and 1984. He said:

There are several reasons for this. One of the more important reasons is the battering (in my opinion quite unjustified, except in relation to a limited number of mistakes which it made in its reports of facts) which it took from the media at the time of the inquiry-
that was his inquiry-

into the Ivanov-Combe affair. Time will heal that scar, but it is incumbent on those responsible for leading the organisation to restore the firm belief which its officers must have in ASIO's purpose, and in the importance of that purpose to the nation.

From what Mr Wrigley said in his speech to the National Press Club a few weeks ago, that morale rebuilding is certainly taking place. Time will heal poor morale, provided there is proper leadership, and proper understanding of and support for the organisation by the Government of the day, and provided it is defended properly by the Government of the day and, I might say, by the Opposition of the day. There is the most widespread support for ASIO. Mr Justice Hope dealt with complaints made by a number of people about the organisation but he found that there was virtually no substance in any of them. There were not even a great many people who came forward with such complaints. Mr Wrigley, in his speech, recorded the extent of the support that ASIO gets from ordinary members of the community when it seeks their help. ASIO has to rely on ordinary members of the community. He recorded, I think with some surprise, the extent to which ordinary members of the community want to co-operate with and help ASIO. As I said, that is to be contrasted with the sort of battering that the media and elements of our society have given ASIO. Unfortunately, in many cases those criticisms have come from members of the Australian Labor Party, particularly its left wing.

It should not surprise the Director-General that ASIO gets support from the Australian community because, as polls have shown, there is overwhelming agreement in the community with the need to have this organisation. It simply amazes me that we have to debate and defend so often the need for this organisation. The need for this organisation has been attested to by Mr Justice Hope, who was twice selected by the Labor Party to investigate ASIO on its behalf; by people such as Mr Wrigley, who has just taken over responsibility for it; by people such as Mr Justice Woodward, whose leadership contributed so much to the reform of the organisation; and by the community.

It simply amazes me that we have this continual battering of the organisation in the Press by totally immature and irresponsible people and, as I said, that criticism is fanned by small elements of the community, particularly on the far left of the political spectrum. It is high time that governments stood up and defended the need for these organisations. It is high time this Government came out fighting for them rather than simply giving in to the pressures of small minorities in the community and, as I have said, problems within the left wing of its own Party. Clearly, there is a need for efficient organisations to be well resourced, but there is an overwhelming need for them to be supported and encouraged by the government of the day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security Bill 1986, the Australian Security Intelligence Organization Amendment Bill 1986 and the Intelligence and Security (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1986 raise some very interesting questions in a democratic society. I think the need for intelligence, both internally for the security of the country and externally, is recognised by most people. The difficulty of politically controlling such organisations is also recognised. But one of the premises of a democratic society is that the people of the country are able to elect their own government and that that government shall be paramount within the country and shall direct and have knowledge of the activities of those who are servants of the community.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Democrats do not believe that it is possible within a democratic society to have organisations which are totally independent of the Parliament and the Executive of the day. However, the difficulty arises when one attempts to translate those somewhat conflicting ideas into practical terms. How does one have a security organisation which, by its very nature, must undertake activities of a kind that cannot find their way on to the front page of newspapers day after day? How is one to keep the necessary political control over servants of the state so that no group funded by the people of the country is outside the control of the people?

This package of Bills refers not only to the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation but also to the Australian Secret Intelligence Service, the Defence Signals Directorate, the Office of National Assessments and the Joint Intelligence Organisation. Together those five organisations have a role, both internally and externally, of operating to promote the general well-being of this country. I, on behalf of the Democrats, am not in any way upset that we have had a continuing debate about these organisations in Australia. In any healthy democracy those types of organisations, operating under the type of tension to which I have already referred, ought to be the subject of continuing scrutiny by the representatives of people; that is, by the Parliament. I think it is outrageous to suggest that we should not look at them, that somehow or other that is wrong.

One of the essential features of parliamentary democracy is a continuing and rigorous scrutiny of all elements of society. The major changes to the Australian Security Intelligence Organization Act occurred in April 1979. It is now October 1986. That does not seem to represent an excessive preoccupation with such organisations or with ways in which we might be able to fine tune the delicate relationship which has to exist. I hoped that we would apply our minds to the Bills to see whether the proposals take us forward in that type of relationship and to look at the details of the measures the Government proposes.

I now turn my attention to the various pieces of legislation we are debating. The first is the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security Bill. The purpose of this Bill is to create an Office of Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security. That office will be called upon to assist elected Ministers of State to ensure that the public interest, in the proper functioning of those security agencies, is met. The final report of Mr Justice Hope's Royal Commission on Australian Security and Intelligence Agencies recommended the creation of the Office, and the Australian Democrats believe that that recommendation ought to be followed. We believe that it will be a valuable addition to the existing machinery. It is very interesting that Senator Durack pointed to various items in Mr Justice Hope's report but not to this recommendation.

Specifically, the Inspector-General will be required to inquire into the agencies' compliance with legality, propriety, ministerial directions and guidelines, human rights and the procedures relating to grievances of employees. I believe that that is a very useful step forward. It resolves one of the difficulties that have arisen previously, particularly with regard to employees of those agencies. I refer to the difficulty of integrating them into any reasonable type of arbitration system under which their rights and any particular grievances they may have with regard to their employer organisation can be looked at. There does not seem to be any other conceivable way of dealing with that matter. I would have thought that that measure ought to be supported by every senator. I would also have thought that it was the obvious way to go in terms of seeking compliance with ministerial directions. How are ministerial directions to be handled and followed through? This, I believe, is the appropriate method. It is not direct intervention but rather a method with which the various agencies will be able to work easily and well.

Apart from those roles that I have mentioned, the Inspector-General will have two additional functions vis-a-vis ASIO in particular. First, at the request of the responsible Minister, and providing it is outside the jurisdiction of the Security Appeals Tribunal, the Inspector-General will inquire into actions that should be taken to protect the rights of Australian citizens. Considering the fact that ASIO is working internally, I think that it is an appropriate way of dealing with that issue.

The second function of the Inspector-General regarding ASIO relates to a written direction to ASIO as the responsible Minister concerning the justification on security grounds of the collection or communication of intelligence about a particular individual.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of sitting for dinner I was referring to the first of the Bills that we are debating as allied Bills-that is, the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security Bill. I wish to refer now to the second of the Bills-that is, the Australian Security Intelligence Organization Amendment Bill. Basically, this is a clarification Bill with regard to the role and power of ASIO. I draw attention in particular to the Hope Royal Commission's recommendations on the collection of foreign intelligence. Clause 8 of this Bill amends section 17 of the Act so that ASIO will now have the power to collect certain foreign intelligence in Australia. It also clarifies its power with regard to advice and protective security. I think they are important elements in this Bill. It is a development that clarifies and distinguishes the role of ASIO from those of the other security agencies, particularly ASIS-the Australian Secret Intelligence Service-with regard to domestic and foreign security gathering.

SPEECH.PARA: Probably one of the most significant changes proposed in this Bill is the establishment of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation. This is not a recommendation of the Hope Royal Commission; it is something on which the Government has chosen to move. I think it is very interesting, but I will reserve my comments on it until the Committee stage, since the Opposition parties will move amendments with regard to that measure; hence there will obviously be a debate at that time. Attention ought to be drawn also to clause 3 of this Bill, in particular the endeavour to delete various anachronisms in terms of subversion and terrorism. I also make particular mention of clause 9, which inserts into the Act a new section to make it completely clear that the ASIO Act is not to limit the right of any Australian citizen to engage in lawful advocacy, protest or dissent. This is a most gratifying addition to the Bill.

The third Bill that we are debating is the Intelligence and Security (Consequential Amendments) Bill. This Bill seeks to amend a range of Acts with regard to security measures. It will amend the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act, the Archives Act, the Audit Act, the Crimes Act, the Freedom of Information Act, the Human Rights Commission Act, the Migration Act and the Telecommunications (Interception) Act. The Acts basically are being amended to allow the establishment of the position of Inspector-General. For example, the Archives Act is being amended in such a way that the Inspector-General will not be required to transfer to Archives records which it obviously would be inappropriate to transfer. I note that the Opposition will move some amendments, particularly in regard to the Crimes Act and the Human Rights Commission Act. I think that they are probably more appropriately debated at the Committee stage.

The Hope Royal Commission in its report raised many of the issues that have fully come to fruition in these amending Bills. Justice Hope reiterated his view, in terms of the evaluation of the performance of the agencies, that Australian needed intelligence equality, timeliness and relevance, and also required a high professional standard from the security services. The Government, in terms of this legislation, has endorsed those views and has, I believe, sought to come to terms with them in a way which is compatible with the requirements of a democratic society; hence the Australian Democrats will support the Government's Bills in general. I will indicate, as each of the Opposition's amendments are moved, what our view is with regard to those amendments.

We will also move two amendments to clause 39 of the Australian Security Intelligence Organization Amendment Bill. I will briefly rehearse the reasons for those amendments. We are interested, in particular with regard to page 17, as to who will make the definition of those various exclusions which are included in proposed new sub-section (4). I believe the Bill is deficient in as much as it does not clarify who is to make the decisions with regard to those exclusions. We will also be looking at proposed new sub-section 92f (2). We propose to leave out the words 'with the approval of the Minister'. It seems to us inappropriate to move to the new arrangements with regard to the Committee of this Parliament and to then have it subjected to the operation of the Executive. I believe that runs counter to and confuses in a very radical way the powers of the Parliament and the powers of the Executive. If there is to be a joint committee on ASIO, it must be a joint committee of the Parliament. It seems to me to be inappropriate for that committee to then be subjected to ministerial direction as to whether it will do this or that. If any particular exclusion is desired, as is the case in regard to proposed new sub-section 92c (4), it would be appropriate to exclude it by way of legislative operation which would then be passed by this Parliament. I feel that there is confusion and that that confusion should not be allowed to occur. I flag those amendments at this stage so that the responsible Minister may give attention to those points at the appropriate time.

I reiterate that in general the Australian Democrats support these measures. We believe they are an advance on the present position. I also reiterate the point that I believe it is timely from time to time that the Parliament reviews in a serious manner the operation of the security forces of this country. It seems to me that to do so in the span of seven or eight year periods, as has been the case, probably is not adequate and that a more timely way of doing it might be in the way that the Government has suggested-by way of a joint committee of the Parliament; hence we would support that most strongly. I believe it is a function of the Parliament to do that. For example, one finds that in the United States the Congress is involved in the supervision of the intelligence agencies and has in recent years taken a much more rigorous role in circumscribing the activities of intelligence agencies. I believe that by this advance, as with the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority, the parliamentary role is being expanded and enhanced. I think that is an important development in our constitutional history. I hope that that continues and that the Parliament does undertake a vigorous role in this manner. I am minded, of course, of the initial problems that the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority had and I hope that those problems will not emerge in the early history of this Joint Committee.

If there is to be a joint committee, I believe that a fruitful role for it would be to support the proper role of intelligence agencies, not to interfere in their workings. This is the sort of approach that was made very clear by the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority. Such a joint committee should seek to enhance the democratic scrutiny of such organisations. There is disquiet in the community over these types of agencies and authorities. I believe that one way of satisfying the public's uncertainty about the types of powers that such groups hold within our community is for the Parliament to be actively involved in the overseeing of such organisations. Hence, the Democrats will give their strong support to the proposal that the Government has mentioned in this regard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate has before it three Bills relating to intelligence and security systems in this country. The Bills are the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security Bill 1986, the Australian Security Intelligence Organization Amendment Bill 1986 and the Intelligence and Security (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1986. The Bills come before the Senate by way of a response by the Hawke Government to a very comprehensive inquiry into our security systems carried out in recent years by Mr Justice Robert Hope. I should add that Mr Justice Hope is a very senior judge of the New South Wales Supreme Court, a man universally regarded for his qualities of intellect, his analytical ability and his integrity. He has undertaken two such very detailed inquiries and his reports, therefore, bear detailed study.

SPEECH.PARA: To understand the nature of the need for legislation, let me start with a single premise, and that is that every country, sadly enough, has found it necessary, indeed imperative, to set up security and intelligence systems of its own. Every country has found that within it there are agents acting in the interests of foreign countries and often against the interests of the indigenous community. Countries have also found that there is always the danger of subversion and terrorism. So I make the initial point that all countries have intelligence and security services, that all of them regard such services as imperative to their national security and that all seek to install both efficiency and integrity in those services.

Over the years Australia has developed five individual security and intelligence systems and those systems have all been the subject of review by Mr Justice Hope. The one most commonly known is ASIO-the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation. ASIO is responsible for the collection, evaluation and communication of intelligence relevant to the protection of Australia from espionage, subversion and terrorism. It is important to understand its nature because so often it is quite wrongly projected by the media and others who seek to damage it as having some kind of political internal activity, that it is acting in some partisan manner. That is well beyond its charter and no evidence has ever been shown of that. It is important to understand that ASIO has no powers of interrogation and no powers of detention and arrest. ASIO's functions are the gathering of intelligence and security information and the informing and advising of governments. It is important to understand that over the years the Prime Ministers and Attorney-General of the day have had direct access to ASIO. The very important work of ASIO is such that it can be scrutinised continually buy a Prime Minister and an Attorney-General.

The Australian Secret Intelligence Service-ASIS-is responsible for the collection of foreign intelligence for Australia. The Joint Intelligence Organisation provides specialised intelligence databanks and analyses and assessments for the government of the day in relation to Australia's strategic environment. The Defence Signals Directorate-the DSD-is concerned with information and intelligence from electronic emissions and with the security of government communications. Finally, the Office of National Assessments-ONA-provides the government of the day with assessments on international matters of political, strategic and economic significance. So Australia has five individual bodies working in the community to safeguard our security.

Over the years Australia has been well served by the Directors-General of ASIO. One thinks in the early days of Directors-General such as Brigadier Charles Spry, who was involved in the formation of ASIO and who was respected by governments of both Liberal and Labor faith. One remembers more recently Mr Justice Woodward, who gave very distinguished service, and Mr Barnett and his successor, Mr Alan Wrigley, a former Deputy Secretary of the Department of Defence. The integrity and ability of these Directors-General have never been seriously questioned. Their devotion and dedication to their charter have never been seriously questioned. Indeed, it is fair to say that ASIO itself has never been under very serious question. The sad part of its history was the tragic raiding of it by a former Attorney-General and member of the Senate in the Whitlam regime. That tragic situation sent a message round the world that our security system might not be secure. But worse than that was the revelation of a breach of security.

It is important to understand that ASIO itself simply gives information to the government of the day. It was never thought that its information and files would be revealed to the general public or used in any way to condemn people. Sadly, I recall the tabling in this Senate of some 2,000 names of immigrants to Australia, largely of Yugoslav Croatians, with the inference that they were bad people-an inference which was never justified and which really pointed to the grave danger of political intervention in the intelligence and security services of this country. I say that with sadness because we are looking to establish in any kind of reforms a system of considerable integrity. I pay tribute to the Directors-General over the years. Many of them are outstanding Australians. I pay tribute to all those servants of ASIO who work in a very difficult and anonymous fashion.

Against that background, it is important to understand that there have been two very thorough investigations of ASIO by Mr Justice Hope. Both were instigated by Labor governments and the reports are available for honourable senators to peruse. It is utterly important to understand that in the more recent report. Mr Justice Hope reported very favourable indeed upon all of the five elements of our security and intelligence services. It is important to understand that he said of ASIO, amongst other things:

ASIO has been concerned to ensure that its operations and actions are within its charter, the Australian Security Intelligence Organization Act 1979 (ASIO Act), since the Act came into force, whether in relation to the collection or communication of intelligence or to advice to Ministers and Commonwealth authorities. It has been substantially successful in achieving that goal.
That is a very significant commendation. Looking at the changes in ASIO from 1979 to 1984, Mr Justice Hope went on to say:
Perhaps one of the greatest changes that I have found in ASIO is in the degree of its concern for compliance with the requirements of the law and of propriety.

I pause here to say that the judge on whose report we must place our trust, a man of very great respect in this community, has said that he has found that ASIO has complied with its charter and that its work is successful. He went on to mention the second of the bodies, ASIS, and of course made note of that very unfortunate aberration at the Sheraton Hotel in Melbourne. He mentioned it as an aberration and said:
Firm and clear steps have been taken to ensure that no such incident will happen again.

He went on to deal with the Defence Signals Directorate and said that neither in the former report on security nor in this inquiry had he found any evidence supporting any allegations that had been raised against that organisation. He said that the effectiveness and efficiency of ASIS appeared to have been growing over the decade. Those are pretty strong commendations of these bodies. Of the Office of National Assessment he said:
Although it is a relatively small body, ONA has been able to establish its independence and authority, and it has done this by the quality of the work which it produces.
That is also a pretty good commendation of such a body. In relation to JIO he said:

JIO has adjusted well to the changes it had to make, and it handles a vast amount of intelligence and issues assessments and reports, many of which are of a high standard. Its product is well regarded by those who receive it.

Those are a significant number of commendations from the Royal Commissioner, a man who over the years has learnt a lot more about the intimate structure, detail and function of our security system than any other living Australian. May I, while on my feet, pay tribute to Mr Justice Hope and say that Australia is well served by senior members of the judiciary, such as he, who are willing to set aside their judicial duties for infinite lengths of time to undertake a most painstaking examination of our security systems. I think honourable senators on both sides of this chamber would want to place on record that commendation, and I so do. I remind the Senate that Mr Justice Hope's report is very comforting for Australians. He has said that despite the reports that appear in the media from time to time and despite the allegations and the rhetoric of some careless politicians, the security services in this country have acted sensibly and with full regard for their charter and have carried out their duties in the best interests of Australia. One could scarcely have a better commendation than that.

Senator Durack referred to a recent public statement made by the present Director-General of ASIO, Mr Alan Wrigley, at the National Press Club in relation to ASIO as he finds it today. Mr Wrigley, a former senior member of the Department of Defence, had had the chance to look at ASIO, to take stock of its work, and to look at its integrity and the quality of its work. He said a number of important things. First of all he said that the existence of such a body was amply justified and that there are and have been very real threats to Australia's security in various ways and that the actions of ASIO over the years had frustrated such dangerous incidents. That is a pretty high tribute, said in public by the present Director-General, a man who, with his Defence background, would know these things.

We come to this legislation against that background. We come to it with a number of recommendations by Mr Justice Hope, many of which are in the legislation before us. There are two about which I wish to comment and the others will be dealt with in the Committee stage. Mr Justice Hope has recommended the appointment of an Inspector-General. I respect the man who has put forward this recommendation, but I must say that nothing I have seen has justified that recommendation or the translation of it into legislation. In fact, the very report of Mr Justice Hope argues against the need for such an appointment. He has said that ASIO observes its charter, that it is successful and efficient, and that it has a quality of integrity. If it has all those and if indeed the Prime Minister and the Attorney-General have supervisory roles over it, what need is there for further looking over the shoulder of ASIO?

Putting an intermediary in between the government of the day and the Director-General is to do something that could be both destructive and corrosive, and it could certainly be divisive. If someone is appointed whose eternal job is one of auditing and looking over the shoulder of the Director-General and looking into ASIO as an organisation, of querying whether this or that is right, no person in a managerial position can feel that he has any sense of independence. If there is one great virtue that a Director-General of ASIO must have, it must be the freedom to be independent and objective in what he does. If all the time he knows that somebody is double guessing him, he must feel constrained. In any case, there will always be room for differences of judgment in the conduct of such an organisation. Such a position would make the Director-General of the day feel that he was under scrutiny all the time. Already he is under scrutiny by the Prime Minister and the Attorney-General as often as they wish to seek, to ask, to inquire, to investigate. How can a man have many masters? How can the Director-General be in a situation in which right down to the grass roots, to the very employment of his staff, to the very question of a dissident member of staff raising some problem, he himself is not totally responsible in the end, to deal with it? Someone is looking over his shoulder, someone who can have an inquiry, someone who can query things and raise doubts. The government of the day would be put in a dilemma.
