How could it adjudicate if from time to time it had two sets of opinions? How could the Director-General go about his business that way?

Sadly, I feel, having read Mr Justice Hope's report, that a wrong conclusion has been reached. We have had over the years and have at the moment an organisation of great integrity which observes its charter and works with great efficiency. It has a Director-General acting with independence and objectivity, reporting to the Attorney-General and to the Prime Minister. In future by its actions the Government will put a dilemma into the system. Who is to say what the quality of the Inspector-General will be? We ought to be picking the best man in Australia for the job as Director-General of ASIO. If we are not, where is our judgment?

The Director-General will have an Inspector-General who ought to be next best to him-not best. If we have chosen as Director-General the best qualified man in Australia, how can we have somebody second-guessing him? If we have an Inspector-General with such qualities we should make him the Director-General, otherwise we have a nonsense system. Who would ever have in a major enterprise in this country a managing director and an inspector reporting over him to the board of directors and who would say to that board: `I do not think he is right; I think he is wrong. Bill Smith, the third grade clerk, has a grievance and I think that the managing director handled it wrongly.' That is a nonsense.

I come to the formation of a parliamentary committee to which certain information is to be given about ASIO but not about particular events. There will be a constant probing by the parliamentary committee, a constant guessing of what is happening, and therefore in my judgment a constant threat to the integrity and the security of ASIO. I am not reflecting upon individual members of the Parliament, but if we cannot have a Senate select committee report such as that brought into this place yesterday without it being leaked as it was leaked to the Age last Friday, how can we stop leaks from a parliamentary committee which acts in the ordinary, free and independent way that such committees do. Unless the parliamentary committee knows everything, how can it make judgments on a few things? That is the dilemma. Mr Justice Hope has said that Directors-General and the organisation have acted within ASIO's charter and with integrity, so why do we introduce a third force to look over the Director-General's shoulder? All that will happen is that we will emasculate ASIO. Sadly, that is what some would want. We will make ASIO fearful to act. Nobody has ever suggested that it has, over its long history, ever acted badly or against the interests of the Australian nation. Over history the quality of its actions has stood up under an independent Director-General responsible to a Prime Minister and to an Attorney-General.

We are to have an Inspector-General who, if he is good enough, ought to be the Director-General. We will then have a parliamentary committee. What we are doing-it is what every one of those foreign interests in this nation would like our indigenous community to do-is opening out and exposing the clues to our security system; in other words, we are being helpful to those who are not concerned with the best interests of Australia. I cannot imagine why we would do such a thing. If a parliamentary committee is to be set up, it ought to do what it purports to do. There ought to be an assurance to the Australian people that it knows all there is to know about ASIO and therefore can be a safeguard, the watchdog of the Australian people. But that is not intended at all; the committee is to know only what it is told. It will probe and, as is the ordinary way of parliamentarians, make allegations and assertions which will be picked up by the media. We will have every wild hare running that one can imagine. When we spell it out, we can see the lack of common sense of these things.

Every country finds it imperative to have a security and intelligence system, so every country knows that it is vulnerable from within. A democracy, in particular, is doubly vulnerable. A totalitarian state can deal with those who are subversive, who are terrorists, who will threaten its security. Democracies open up their activities and so expose their soft underbellies to the terrorists. Therefore, it is most important that we have a security system that can act effectively and fearlessly. If I had any evidence before me that the system has not been, or is not, acting in this way I would look with much greater interest at the idea of an Inspector-General and at the idea of a parliamentary committee. But I have before me the words of the royal commissioner; words which reinforce the view that each of the reforms made to the security system have been faithfully taken up, carried out and discharged. He says that ASIO is obeying its charter, that it is efficient and that the other bodies are going about their business efficiently and in the best interests of Australia. In looking at one of the most important jobs in Australia, that of Director-General of ASIO, I repeat that we must search Australia to find the best qualified person there is, put that person in that position and put our trust in him.

There are all sorts of safeguards. ASIO is always held up by those who want to denigrate it as being a body that races around, subversively tapping telephones, invading the privacy of people and getting information, not in the interests of Australia but because of some party political interest. That is an absolute nonsense. Australians must understand that before ASIO can tap a telephone, before it can invade the privacy of someone, before it can look at particular information, it must go to the Attorney-General of the day who will or will not give it the authority to act. So if there is an allegation that ASIO is doing these things, it is a reflection on the Attorney-General and the Prime Minister of the Day.

None of these things has happened. I remind the Senate that sadly the only reflection on ASIO occurred when it was raided and papers that should never have seen the light of day were tabled in this Senate. Those who denigrate ASIO say that ASIO would be raising files on people to denigrate them. I know of no file prepared by ASIO that has ever been exposed to the light of day-other than, presumably, to the Attorney-General and the Prime Minister-other than those tabled in this Senate. It is to the disgrace of this Senate that it was ever allowed; it is to the disgrace of the political system, not of ASIO, that it ever happened.

One must conclude that whilst there are a number of worthwhile mechanical measures in the reform of these security systems, we have had a major assurance from the royal commissioner who has said that after two thorough searches of these organisations he has found so much to commend and so very little to criticise. He has found integrity, he has found efficiency and he has found dedication. On that note I repeat that one should record one's thanks to the people in these various organisations who anonymously or otherwise go about their business in the interests of the safety and security of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —A strong defence has been made of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation, its integrity and its record. It is good to hear that defence being made but it does not necessarily follow from that that the sorts of conclusions reached are correct. I turn to clause 9 of the Australian Security Intelligence Organization Amendment Bill 1986, which inserts the following new section 17A into the principle Act:

SPEECH.PARA: This Act shall not limit the right of persons to engage in lawful advocacy, protest or dissent and the exercise of that right shall not, by itself, be regarded as prejudicial to security, and the functions of the Organization shall be construed accordingly.

This section has been proposed because of a perception by people, whether rightly or wrongly-it has been suggested that such people may be of the extreme Left or at least in the minority which, I think, denigrates them-that ASIO has gone outside its charter. I am talking now of perceptions. Partly as a result of those perceptions two inquiries have been conducted by Mr Justice Hope. The results of those inquiries have been discussed here tonight. If there is this perception of ASIO, and if ASIO carries out internal investigations within Australia as it is meant to do, there must be concern, not that ASIO is necessarily doing the wrong thing, but certainly that people are being watched for the purpose of seeing whether they have in some way prejudiced the security of Australia. Certainly one can understand people who are looked at in this way feeling quite badly about it.

Two instruments which have been objected to are, at the very least, a reassurance to the people of Australia that ASIO is operating within its charter. I refer to the appointment of the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security and the appointment of a parliamentary committee, the Joint Committee on the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation. There has been criticism of the proposed establishment of this Committee. I find that somewhat strange, for the following reason. Certainly the Prime Minister of the day and the Attorney-General of the day have a supervisory role over ASIO, but they are members of the Executive. The supreme body in Australia is the Parliament. Parliament is the place where citizens' rights are protected, where people are looked after and where the excesses of the Executive are checked. If Parliament cannot in some way look at a body which has the potential to look at and inform upon its citizens, either rightly or wrongly, if Parliament cannot be put forward as an instrument in some way to supervise a body such as ASIO, what have we come to? The very heart of our democracy is the parliamentary system. It seems to me to be going too far in the protection of ASIO to deny the supreme body, the Parliament of Australia, a proper role. That proper role is set out in Part Va of the legislation, which deals with the Joint Committee on the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation.

Senator Durack spoke about the proper functions of our society. He spoke about its basic values and institutions. I ask Senator Durack: If this Parliament is not one of the basic institutions of our society, perhaps along with the law courts, what are we all about? It has been said that this parliamentary body would leak to the Press and that in some ways it would be untrustworthy. Nevertheless, the Parliament is an elected body-which ASIO is not-a basic institution of our society.

I want to say something about the use of the words `basic values'. The basic value of this society, I hope, is freedom being very much to the fore. Ours should be a benign, tolerant and aspiring society which can go about its functions untrammelled by the rigours of the state and by the instruments that are set up in totalitarian regimes. Senator Sir John Carrick pointed out that there are risks in democracy. Of course there are risks in democracy, but if one wants to save democracy, those risks must be taken. To say that a non-elected body can, without any scrutiny at all by the elected representatives of Australia, look at the citizens of Australia and the way they live, perhaps for the most legitimate of reasons, seems to me to turn on their head the values we ought to be desperate to preserve as a country and as a people.

Criticism has been made of the proposed appointment of the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security. It has been said that his function will double up on that of the Prime Minister and the Attorney-General. It is interesting to look at clause 4 of the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security Bill, which states:
The objects of this Act are-
(a) to assist Ministers in the oversight and review of-
(i) the compliance with the law by, and the propriety of particular activities of, Australian intelligence or security agencies . . .

Certainly it is proper that ASIO, or any of the other organisations whose function is mainly to collect intelligence other than on the citizens of Australia, complies with the law as set down by Parliament and acts with propriety. This legislation will enable the Attorney-General and the Prime Minister to see that that happens.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is wrong with the courts?

—The courts are not an investigatory body. They do not consider whether a particular organisation has stayed within the law. They decide on the evidence brought before them whether there has been compliance. How do we know whether a body such as ASIO complies with the law if we do not have an Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security, as Mr Justice Hope suggests we should?
—Mr Justice Hope looked at them and found that they were not complying with it.

—Senator Durack has raised an interesting point. It has been felt necessary to have two royal commissions conducted by Mr Justice Hope. With the appointment of an Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security and the establishment of a parliamentary committee, that sort of need will now be eliminated and we will have a proper functioning of this body with the ability to assure people that all is going well. One will not now need a royal commission which, by its very nature, is quite disruptive. I do not say that in any critical sense at all, but obviously a royal commission, entering a field in an extraordinary way-the very function of a royal commission is to act in an extraordinary way-is disruptive. We will not have the need for that in the future because we will have, firstly, an Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security and, secondly, a committee of parliamentary representatives. They will be able to reassure the people of Australia of the effectiveness, use and integrity of ASIO, which have been spoken about by speakers before me in this debate, and that the organisation has stayed within its charter and within the objects of the Act as set out in clause 4 of the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security Bill 1986. I quote again clause 4:

SPEECH.PARA: The objects of this Act are-
(a) to assist Ministers in the oversight-
It is not as if the office of the Inspector-General will be an instrument additional to the Prime Minister and the Attorney. The objects of the Act will be:
(a) to assist Ministers in the oversight and review of-
(i) the compliance with the law . . .
(ii) the effectiveness and appropriateness of the procedures of those agencies relating to the legality or propriety of their activities-
surely nobody will object to that-
(iii) certain other aspects of the activities and procedures of certain of those agencies;
(b) to assist Ministers in ensuring that the activities of those agencies are consistent with human rights;

I have not heard it suggested, and I hope I do not hear it suggested-that a body that is set up to protect us against an internal or external threat to our security will do so in a way which is inconsistent and denies human rights. In addition, clause 4 states:
(c) to allow for review of certain directions given to ASIO by the Attorney-General.

So to say that we have the Attorney-General and the Prime Minister compartmentalised, as it were, and that the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security will operate separately from them I think is to misread what this legislation is all about. The Inspector-General is to operate to assist the Ministers and to see that ASIO functions, and functions properly. I turn now to clause 8 which, under the heading `Functions of Inspector-General', states:
(1) Subject to this section, the functions of the Inspector-General in relation to ASIO are-

There are special provisions as far as that goes because ASIO operates within Australia and the other agencies tend to operate outside Australia, so that the sorts of people we are looking at are different. Clause 8 continues:
(a) at the request of the responsible Minister, of the Inspector-General's own motion or in response to a complaint made to the Inspector-General, to inquire into any matter that relates to-
(i) the compliance by ASIO with the laws of the Commonwealth and of the States and Territories;

I repeat that I certainly do not think it has been suggested in this debate that, in some way, ASIO should be allowed to range outside the laws of the Commonwealth, the States and the Territories. Clause 8 states further:
(ii) the compliance by ASIO with directions or guidelines given to ASIO by the responsible Minister;
(iii) the propriety of particular activities of ASIO;
(iv) the effectiveness and appropriateness of the procedures of ASIO relating to the legality or propriety of the activities of ASIO; or
(v) an act or practice of ASIO that is or may be inconsistent with or contrary to any human right, being an act or practice referred to the Inspector-General by the Human Rights Commission;

The clause goes on. But none of the legislation presently before the Parliament suggests in any way that any of the additional instruments set up can interfere with the day to day running of the intelligence organisations concerned. The legislation does not suggest in any way that it can override the proper directions given by the Inspector-General to his staff. Senator Sir John Carrick used the example of a company. He said that we do not have somebody overriding the executive director of a company. Of course we do not, but nor do we in this legislation. A company is very much subject to the law, to the courts and to supervision by the community to ensure that the company will stay within the law. All this legislation does is enable an assurance to be given that intelligence organisations, in particular ASIO, are doing the same thing. So when we look at the legislation in those terms we can hardly say: `Here is legislation that in some way will disrupt, corrode'-I think that was one word that was used-`the way in which ASIO operates'. I think the words `destruction' and `corroding' the influence of the Inspector-General were used. When we look at the legislation and see how it functions and what the Inspector-General's functions are it is very hard to see how those words can be justified.

I will now deal with the sorts of powers that the parliamentary committee will not have. That is set out in proposed new section 92c (4) of the Australian Security Intelligence Organization Bill, which states:
The functions of the Committee do not include-
(a) reviewing a matter that relates to the obtaining or communicating by the Organization of foreign intelligence;
(b) reviewing an aspect of the activities of the Organization that does not affect any person who is an Australian citizen or a permanent resident;
(c) reviewing a matter, including a matter that relates to intelligence collection methods or sources of information, that is operationally sensitive; or
(d) originating inquiries into individual complaints concerning the activities of the Organization.

Here we have very specific exclusions from the Committee's activities and powers. If we read in fair measure proposed new Part Va of the Australian Security Intelligence Organization amendment Bill we see that it gives the Parliament what I say is its proper role as the supreme elected body of this land over a body which is its creation and which is not elected. But it does it in such a way as to ensure that that creation of the Parliament is still able to operate effectively so as to protect the legitimate interests of the citizens of this country. So to talk about it in the strong terms that have been used so far is to be unfair, firstly on the Parliament, secondly, on the Committee and, thirdly, on the creation of the Office of the Inspector-General.

It has been said in debate that only extreme left wingers would object to ASIO being unfettered, that only a minority would take up that position. I think if we were to put fairly to the Australian people the question of whether organisations created by Parliament, including intelligence organisations such as ASIO, should stay within their charter, should be under some sort of supervision to see that they do that, we would find the people of Australia saying: `Of course they should do that. Of course there should be supervision at that level'. We certainly do not want bodies interfering in the very important functions of this Organisation but, at the same time, we want some assurance that the body that our parliament created and that we have adopted over the years will stay, as every organisation ought to do, within the law and that it will act with propriety, justice and fairness to all.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you want to have a parliamentary committee on the AFP as well?

—The Australian Federal Police are subject to scrutiny. That is exactly the point. The Australian Federal Police act by investigating crime, arresting people and bringing them before the courts. What they do and how they function is very much subject to the scrutiny of the courts. Their activities are well and truly in the open but the activities of ASIO, by their very nature, are not in the open. The Inspector-General and the proposed Parliamentary Committee will provide that missing link which, as far as the police force is concerned, means that it operates publicly. Let us say, for example, that ASIO collected information and passed it on wrongly. Surely that is something that ought to be checked.

SPEECH.PARA: I find difficulty with Senator Durack's approach in that he seems in some way not to trust the Parliament-the very body to which he has been elected. He seems to be saying that the Parliament that he has served so nobly over the years, served with such distinction as Attorney-General and served, no doubt, to the pleasure of us all is in some way a failure, that it is a debased body that should not be trusted, that when it operates it is somehow less these intelligence bodies such as ASIO that have not been elected and that act is secret, as they must-that is at the very essence of their functions-and that somehow they are superior bodies. It is at that level that I find difficulty with Senator Durack's arguments. It seems to me that he lacks faith in the very institution that he has adorned over the years. It is a pity that somebody who has served the Parliament so well as Attorney-General and in other capacities over the years does not have trust in the very institution which he has served with such distinction. If Senator Durack does not feel that Parliament should be able to provide a body to see that this organisation it has created stays within the bounds of the law and propriety, I find it difficult to see what he would accept as functions which the Parliament may be able to perform well. I suppose that is where we differ.

Australia lives in more freedom than perhaps any other nation in the world. We can come and go, exchange differences of opinion, and walk freely in the streets. I have been recently to London and Paris, where one cannot walk in the streets without police being there and bags being searched because of the sorts of activities that are being carried on. Australia is a place where one still can walk abroad. It has a quality of life and an approach to things which I find most exhilarating. Lessening that in any way ought to be resisted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you include Queensland in that? Have you walked abroad in Queensland? If you do it with one other person you might cause a march.

—I have been told that there have been some difficulties with police there recently, particularly with regard to the Aborigines, but that is another matter. I am talking about the great institution of the Federal Parliament which Senator Macklin and Senator Durack adorn. I do not wish to speak much longer. It distresses me when people in some way discount and belittle the institution of Parliament, that they should somehow see it as nasty or subversive to have an Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security to help the Prime Minister and the Attorney-General to perform their function. If it is subversive to have Parliament and the elected Attorney-General and the elected Prime Minister oversee a body that is not elected, surely we have started to twist the values, the culture, the very ethos of this community, and that is a great pity.

SPEECH.PARA: I am sure that when people think about this matter they do not reach that conclusion. People have seen that there is a parliamentary committee and an office of the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security and they have thought that the two bodies would somehow reduce the effectiveness of ASIO. They have wrongly reacted adversely. This process will save the need to have a royal commission in the future and will keep ASIO within the proper bounds of its functions without in any way making those functions any less effective than they have been. When people see this they will agree that this is good legislation. We should join as with one voice in passing this legislation when it is put to the vote.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The problem of the control of intelligence and security organisations is one of the most difficult to face a democracy. How does one ensure respect for human rights? How does one ensure that the public is told what it has the right to know without damaging the operations of the agencies? They are really difficult problems for any democratic government. They are no problem at all in a dictatorship such as the Soviet Union. They do not have to respect human rights. They do not tell the people anything they do not want them to know. Even in the Soviet Union, organisations such as the KGB, which is far more ruthless than anything we could contemplate, sometimes appear to get away from political control and take actions which could scarcely be in the interests of the foreign policy of the government they are supposed to be supporting. Even in a country such as that, control of such organisations is a continuing question.

SPEECH.PARA: Here in this democracy we have five relevant organisations. The Australian Security Intelligence Organisation deals with internal security. It is the most public of our security organisations. I think I should qualify something that Senator Cooney said. ASIO is not an organisation which can arrest or charge anyone; it is an intelligence collection agency. If, as a result of its investigations, someone has to be charged, it has to go through the ordinary public courts. ASIO is an intelligence collection organisation, not a law or security enforcement agency. It is very important that people should understand that. It is the first of our security organisations and perhaps the one most in the firing line. The second is the Australian Secret Intelligence Service, which is involved in the clandestine collection of overseas intelligence. Of course it hit the news headlines some time ago following the Sheraton raid. I do not want to deal with that, except to say it was a very unfortunate incident caused by a total lack of a meeting of minds between some new ex-Special Air Service Army recruits devoted to a very public and dramatic way of solving problems and the organisation of ASIS, which never contemplated people would tackle problems in quite such a direct way. It was a matter of a lack of control and a lack of understanding by new recruits.

The fourth security organisation is the Defence Signals Division, which deals with electronic intelligence. The Joint Intelligence Organisation of the Department of Defence has an obvious function. The Office of National Assessments has the job of giving advice to the Government. I have long been a critic of that organisation, mainly because of its dominance by the Department of Foreign Affairs. Foreign Affairs officers, in my experience, by their training and background are quite unsuited to perform intelligence functions. Nevertheless, they have a regrettable control over ONA.

In a democracy, when dealing with these organisations, we must look for three things. Firstly, they must be efficient, and that may well require secrecy. Secret organisations can scarcely be expected to be public because, if they are public, they will cease to be efficient. Efficiency may require secrecy. The second requirement is responsiveness to government directions. These directions must be on the record. The organisations must not be subservient; they must be independent. It is just as important for the Director-General of ASIO to be an independent statutory officer as it is for the Auditor-General or the Commissioner of Taxation to be independent of direct Government orders. They must follow general policy directives but not detailed orders. The third requirement for the control of our security organisations in a democracy is that they must respect the human rights of citizens. Things can go wrong in a democracy. They have very publicly gone wrong in America in recent years. The stories of President Nixon using American agencies to pursue political enemies are horrifying. The stories of President Johnson being fed with files on political friends and enemies by the chief of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and laughing over the stories of alleged failings of his political acquaintances are horrifying. We must not have that sort of thing-a direct improper involvement of political heads in the operations of security and intelligence organisations.

That was the real worry about the events mentioned by Senator Sir John Carrick-the raids on ASIO-when into the hands of political people who were in no way entitled or qualified to receive it went raw ASIO intelligence, intelligence not in the form in which ASIO might have wanted to present it. It may not have been checked. It may not have been accurate. We must not have a system in which political heads can get their hands on intelligence organisations and use them for political purposes. Everything that is done must be done above board. Things can go very wrong. As I said, they did go wrong in America. They have gone wrong in Australia, but not very often.

These Bills institute two new controls. I will look at whether these Bills are going to help the situation I have outlined. There are three requirements: Efficiency, which may involve secrecy; responsiveness to government directives; and respect for human rights. The Government proposes two things. The first is the establishment of the office of Inspector-General and the second is the establishment of a parliamentary committee to supervise ASIO in particular. I can see a role for an Inspector-General. It is always awkward if something comes up, if serious allegations are made against an intelligence organisation, and one has to set up a royal commission. It is dramatic, it is news, and there are allegations grossly in excess of what has really happened when one has to set up a special royal commission. I can understand the setting up of an Inspector-General to act in two ways: First, to act as an ombudsman for complaints about the operations of ASIO; and, secondly, on direction by the Minister, to investigate any particular worries the Minister might have about the operations of ASIO. In my mind those are reasonable and acceptable roles for the Inspector-General.

But that is not all of the responsibilities that the Inspector-General is given. If one looks at the Bill, he is permitted `of the Inspector-General's own motion', to inquire into any matter that relates to the compliance by ASIO with the laws of the Commonwealth, the States and Territories, the compliance by ASIO with directions or guidelines given to it by the responsible Minister and the propriety of particular activities of ASIO'. What he is really doing is supervising all the activities of ASIO. This seems to me to be a total administrative nonsense. One appoints the Director-General and, if one is not satisfied with him, one can get rid of him. But to have an Inspector-General with virtually all functions of the Director-General sitting beside him and on his own initiative allowed to investigate virtually any activity of the Director-General seems to me to be an administrative nightmare. It will cause great problems and great friction. Maybe if the new Inspector-General shows great tact and forbearance it will work, but I do not think it is sensible administration, I do not think it will act for the efficiency of ASIO and I do not think it will act for the good of the country. In my view it should be cut out of this Bill. If the Government is not prepared to do that, it certainly should be reviewed after a short period to see how it is working and I think experience will show that it is very damaging to the efficiency of ASIO.

The second new control is the establishment of a parliamentary committee to oversee ASIO. I think the Government might be copying the United States of America. I think for anybody who is interested in this it is worth looking at what has been the effect of those congressional committees, one in the House of Representatives and one in the Senate, on the efficiency of the American intelligence service. In my view-I think I would be supported by many others-it has been catastrophic. It has not made for more efficiency and more accountability; it has just made for inefficiency, cover-ups and incompetence. I do not believe that we should use the American experience as a guide to what might be a successful operation here.

I wish to refer to something that Senator Cooney said-that the Parliament is supreme, therefore surely we have the right to supervise in detail any organisation we set up. That is not strictly true. Under our system, the detailed conduct of defence and foreign affairs is a matter for the Executive, not for the Parliament. Parliament can supervise everything else, and does. Under the British tradition detailed matters of defence and foreign affairs are matters for the Executive. For Parliament to intrude into this there has to be a very clear reason why this will be advantageous. I cannot see that that reason has been established.

One of the problems of setting up a parliamentary committee is the danger of leaks. A leak occurred recently when the report on the Joint Select Committee on the Human Embryo Experimentation Bill 1985 was leaked two days before its publication. Leaks do occur in Parliament and I think we would be very foolish if we thought that if a parliamentary committee were given highly sensitive information it would not be leaked. The American experience indicates that it would be leaked. I see no particular reason why it would not be leaked here. The result is going to be either a dramatic drop in the efficiency of ASIO or the parliamentary committee will be given incomplete or inaccurate information. Mr Justice Hope referred to the American Congressional committees and he said about this matter:

It is particularly important to keep in mind what it is that the Congressional committees do in the course of their oversight. Much of their influence is exercised through their participation in the budgetary process. In reviewing the financial bids for the agencies they examine the justification advanced for the various programs for which the agencies are seeking funds. The emphasis in the review by the committees is on the nature of the programs rather than on particular operations which may be included in them.
That is not a role which could be done under our system by the committee. Mr Justice Hope went on to say:

If a special committee to oversee ASIO were to have access to detailed information consideration would have to be given to the practical problems which would be created by further widening access to such information. Difficult questions would also arise about the position of committee members in relation to such information. When the information is of sensitive operations activities, committee members would in a real sense share a degree of responsibility for those operations.

Mr Justice Hope came down very clearly against the setting up of such a committee. It is a constitutional innovation. I think it has great security problems for ASIO and I do not think any proper case for its establishment has been made out. Therefore, I think it should be opposed by this Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is considering three pieces of legislation concerning the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation. They are the Australian Security Intelligence Organization Amendment Bill 1986, the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security Bill 1986 and the Intelligence and Security (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1986. The principal Bill is the Australian Security Intelligence Organization Amendment Bill 1986, which amends the Australian Security Intelligence Organization Act 1979. The major changes proposed by the Bill are the following: To delete the term `subversion' from the definition of `security'. The term `subversion' is to be replaced by a new concept of `politically motivated violence'. This new concept covers what is included in the definition of terrorism in the 1979 Act as well as a more narrow definition of what previously went under the definition of subversion.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill also seeks to replace the definition of `active measures of foreign intervention' with that of `acts of foreign interference' in the 1979 Act. It seeks to establish greater ministerial control over ASIO and to establish a parliamentary joint committee on ASIO. The latter amendment has been dealt with in the Senate by previous speakers, including the last speaker, Senator Hamer. The Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Gareth Evans, said in his second reading speech:

. . . substitution of `subversion' for `politically motivated violence' has been designed to concentrate ASIO's attention more clearly `on those violent activities going beyond the scope of lawful advocacy and dissent, directed at undermining Australia's system of government'.
This objective is met by clause 9 of the ASIO Amendment Bill, which inserts into the Act the following new section 17a:

This Act shall not limit the right of persons to engage in lawful advocacy, protest or dissent and the exercise of that right shall not, by itself, be regarded as prejudicial to security, and the functions of the Organisation shall be construed accordingly.

On the face of it, this amendment appears to be unexceptionable. It seems simply to give expression to the democratic tradition of ensuring to each and every individual and group in our society their freedom to advance in the sphere of civic life their particular political principles and policies. The problem, however, arises from the assumption implicit in the amending Bill that ASIO, by its very nature, poses a threat to political liberties. This assumption, which the historical record does not bear out-certainly in recent years-and the move to counteract this presumed threat, appears to have placed a severe and unnecessary limitation on ASIO's ability to be an effective organisation.

I realise that we are touching on very delicate matters and that concern for security should definitely not develop into a preoccupation which devours in the end the very liberties and institutions which security agencies are intended to protect within democratic countries. On the other hand, the opposite tendency, namely, a myopic preoccupation with preserving civil liberties, can weaken a nation's defences so that it becomes incapable of preserving its liberties and institutions when they are faced with a real threat. It is into this second trap that this legislation has the risk of falling.

The ASIO Amendment Bill proposes that, as long as individuals and organisations do not go beyond lawful advocacy, protest or dissent, ASIO will not target them for investigation. To put it another way, only those individuals or groups who explicitly adopt political principles and programs of action which involve commitment to violent political activity will receive attention from ASIO. This means that ASIO will be prevented from detecting within otherwise peaceful seeming and legitimate groups embryonic developments which could ultimately take the form of a clearly violent threat to legitimate government, the Constitution and democracy itself.

In other words, this Bill appears to prohibit ASIO from investigating potential subversive activities. From my reading of the Bill, ASIO must wait until potential subversion becomes actual. Moreover, this signals to subversive activists, whether they be domestic activists or agents of foreign powers, that a disguise of lawful advocacy, protest or dissent will debar ASIO from conducting intelligence operations against them. Therefore, this legislation offers what amounts to an invitation to undertake subversive activities of a kind in which, on principle, ASIO will be obliged to take no interest.

It is true that the Bill contains a definition of the words `acts of foreign interference' which should adequately cover what the 1979 Act terms `active measures of foreign intervention'. Nevertheless, there seems to be nothing in the Bill to suggest that individuals and organisations acting in collaboration with a foreign agency, for the purpose, say, of affecting our political or governmental process will not be protected from the attentions of ASIO while it confines its activities to the level of lawful advocacy, protest or dissent. For example, one of the chief ways in which the Soviet Union interferes in the internal affairs of other countries is by making alliances with individuals or groups engaged in lawful advocacy, protest or dissent of a kind which, from the Soviet point of view, objectively advances Soviet interests. This is precisely what the KGB means by its term `active measures'. I conclude from the recent remarks of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on Soviet connections with certain movements within Australia that he understands this point, even if the political illiterates in the media who are outraged at his remarks do not.

I wonder whether the Minister and the Government can assure the Senate that, on the basis of either this Bill or ASIO's operational orders, ASIO will not be deterred by the concept of lawful advocacy, protest and dissent from identifying and investigating individuals or groups who are targets of, say, Soviet active measures. Could any assurance which the Minister might sincerely give have any objective value? I ask this in light of the amazing decision handed down on 1 June 1983 by the Security Appeals Tribunal to the effect that the Communist Party of Australia is not a `subversive' organisation within the meaning of the ASIO Act 1979. It is clear that, as a result of this decision, ASIO is now obliged to ignore CPA activities as such, even though these are clearly subversive in that they attack the fundamental national security interest of Australia. The judgment of members of the Tribunal notwithstanding, certain groups within the country, such as Marxist groups, clothe their activities, as a matter of policy, in the garb of legitimate advocacy.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about groups that receive other funds from overseas?

—That is an interesting question. I also thought about currency manipulation, for example, although that may well result in a demarcation dispute between ASIO and the Australian Federal Police. I think currency manipulation is a subversive activity, particularly when a country is faced with an economic crisis which, according to the Prime Minister, is one such as we have not seen since World War II. Despite being, according to the Tribunal, a non-subversive organisation, members and, for that matter, some former members of the group concerned do maintain active contacts with officials and organs of the Soviet Union for the purposes of promoting policies which in reality serve the interests of the Soviet Union at the expense of Australia. I refer particularly to the agency that was known as the Pacific Trade Union Forum, which is now known as the Pacific Trade Union Community. This organisation, of course, was established and is activated by individuals who do not wish to see or follow a policy which is consistent with that of the security of this country. It is more likely to advance the foreign policy objectives of the Soviet Union in the Pacific Ocean and indeed, in that sense, would be contrary to the external security interests of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: It is also true that, in the current situation in the Philippines, a feature of our policy towards the Philippines is to seek to sustain the democratic process in that country against the trust which is now taking place by the NPA-the New People's Army-backed up by the Communist Party of the Philippines. Some groups within Australia are actively campaigning to support the activities of the NPA which appear, on the face of its policies, to pose a problem for the security of the region. It seems to me that there needs to be an assurance or a guarantee that-bearing in mind what I said about the need to ensure that the pursuit and investigation of subversive activities does not ultimately devour the democratic character of our society-despite the provisions of this Bill, the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation, ASIO, will be able to investigate organisations which support acts of foreign interference to the detriment of Australian government policy and the security of peoples and governments with whom Australia is friendly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable senators for their contributions to this debate-a debate which is often difficult and a debate which, as Senator Macklin reminded us, does not occur very often in this place, despite the protestations of some honourable senators opposite that some people in this place are apparently preoccupied with the activities of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation and our other security organisations. Let me say at the outset that, in my wilder and less responsible days, I may have responded to Senator Harradine's remarks a little differently. I may have given some examples of organisations in another section of the political spectrum which may have warranted the attention of our security agencies in the way that a couple of organisations that we mentioned have. I do not intend to comment tonight on the organisations, individuals or agencies that he referred to; nor do I intend to respond to them in kind. I intend merely to cover the points which have been raised by honourable senators which are pertinent to the legislation before us.

SPEECH.PARA: I think all honourable senators tonight have recognised the difficulty in a democracy of coping with the problems of our security agencies. I believe that all members of this Parliament-or certainly all parties in this Parliament-would accept that those security agencies are necessary for the internal and external security of the country. I point out that honourable senators opposite tonight have frequently drawn on the reports of Mr Justice Hope for support for their advocacy of our security agencies, in particular ASIO, and their support for the efficiency, effectiveness, et cetera, of that Organisation. I point out equally that members on this side of the House agree with those reports of Mr Justice Hope.

I point out to Senator Durack and Senator Sir John Carrick in particular that Mr Justice Hope made recommendations which form the basis of most of the provisions of this legislation. Most of the provisions follow the recommendations of his Royal Commission on Australia's Security and Intelligence Agencies. The major exception, of course, is not, as one gets the impression from Senator Durack, the appointment of an Inspector-General, but is the appointment of a joint parliamentary committee on ASIO. We will undoubtedly have some debate on that at the Committee stage. Mr Justice Hope recommended that we have an Inspector-General in the way that this legislation provides. I think it is very interesting that Senator Sir John Carrick spent most of his speech using the words of Mr Justice Hope and the report of Mr Justice Hope to back his arguments, but then said-and I do not think I am being unfair to him when I say it-that Mr Justice Hope's report does not back the appointment of an Inspector-General. It is one of his recommendations.

Contrary to comments by Senator Durack, Senator Sir John Carrick and others, the Government accepts, and has always accepted, the need for Australia to have an effective intelligence and security capability. We do not want to see the intelligence and security agencies destroyed, as has been alleged by Senator Durack. We do not want to place unnecessary shackles on such agencies. As long as we have such agencies, as long as we recognise the need for such agencies, there will be differences of opinion in this place and in the community in general about what are reasonable restrictions on the activities of such agencies. There will undoubtedly be those who, like Senator Sir John Carrick, seem to believe that such agencies should be left untrammelled to do as they please. It is certainly not a view that is shared by the governments of the United States of America, Canada or any other democratic nation. There are those who take another extreme view that we should not have such agencies, but most of us believe that we should have such agencies and that we should strike a balance so that the civil liberties and rights of individuals in this community shall be protected.

Senator Durack suggested in his speech that the Inspector-General will duplicate the work of ASIO. In fact, I believe he has misread the legislation's proposals for the Inspector-General. I believe he has a misunderstanding of what is proposed. The functions of the Inspector-General are quite different from the functions of ASIO. He or she will be charged with the review of the various agencies, not with double guessing their activities or taking over their functions. With a staff of five, it is impossible to suggest that the Inspector-General has the capacity to duplicate the functions of ASIO which, on my information, has a staff of about 700. We in fact take up the recommendation of Mr Justice Hope in this area. But we agree with Senator Macklin and the Australian Democrats that finding the right balance between accountability and the effectiveness of such agencies is difficult. We think we have found the right balance. We think we have taken up the proposals of Mr Justice Hope. Where he has made them, we think we have improved them with the increased parliamentary oversight that we are talking about.

I must make the point that Senator Sir John Carrick claimed that nothing in Mr Justice Hope's report justifies the creation of the Office of Inspector-General. I refer honourable senators to page 23 of Mr Justice Hope's general report of the Royal Commission on Australia's Security and Intelligence Agencies. In paragraph 3.20 he says:

Both ASIS and DSD have to operate within the law of Australia, and at times (although less often than in the case of ASIO) questions of propriety affect their activities. Although the occasions have been infrequent, allegations of misconduct have been made against each of those services. If any official statement is made about such allegations, it is liable to be challenged (rightly or wrongly) as being based on a response by the service itself.
In paragraph 3.21 he says:

There is thus a case for the Inspector-General to check, as occasion requires, the legality and propriety of the activities of each of these services as well as of ASIO. Since the rights or standing of Australian citizens would rarely be involved, this responsibility should not be onerous but it would be valuable in providing an assurance for the Minister and the public, as well as a protection for the services, if allegations of misconduct are made against them.
In paragraph 3.24 on page 24 he said:

There is little occasion for the involvement of an Inspector-General in the case of ONA or JIO. As I indicate in respect of those agencies (Chapter 1), issues of legality and propriety can rarely arise. These services report upon or assess intelligence collected by others. However, there have been occasions when matters within these organisations have had to be investigated. I have concluded that the Inspector-General should not have any general role in respect of them, but that he should be able to investigate and report upon any particular matters referred to him by the Minister responsible for the particular service, the Prime Minister in the case of ONA and the Minister for Defence in the case of JIO. I would not expect this to happen often; but the facility of resorting to the Inspector-General could be useful from time to time.
In paragraph 16.77 on page 329 of his report on ASIO, he said:

Having regard to the nature of ASIO's functions, the public concern to which those functions can give rise, and the secrecy pertaining to them, there is strong pressure on the Attorney, as the responsible Minister, to satisfy himself that ASIO conducts itself in a proper fashion. However diligent the Attorney may be, there are practical limits on his ability to investigate and satisfy himself that ASIO is at all times acting properly or appropriately. At the very least, full inquiry requires time which a Minister cannot be expected regularly to spare to examine materials and to interrogate people.
In paragraph 16.78 he says:

Moreover, apart from the procedures for review of security assessments by the Security Appeals Tribunal, ASIO, unlike departments and many other agencies, is not subject to provisions for external review of its administrative actions. In particular (and for reasons which I fully understand), the Ombudsman does not have jurisdiction in respect of ASIO, and documents held by ASIO are not subject to the Freedom of Information Act 1982. Decisions by ASIO are not subject to review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal or by the Federal Court under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977. The Attorney, therefore, does not have the assurance that is provided where a body for which he is responsible is subject to the ongoing discipline of independent external review.

Hence the importance of the Inspector-General in Mr Justice Hope's recommendations and in this legislation; hence, I think, the adequate docu- mentation and support for the recommendation which is made by Mr Justice Hope and which has been picked up in this legislation.

It is important that ASIO use its resources efficiently and effectively. So far as intelligence collection is concerned, this means devoting its investigation capacity to activities that represent a real threat to the security of the nation. It is important that we, as elected representatives of the people, can be assured that this happened, and it is in line with this that Mr Justice Hope recommended, and the Bill in fact deletes, the vague term `subversion' from the definition of security in favour of the concept of politically motivated violence. Of the activities previously covered by subversion, only those activities that can be reasonably regarded as being of security concern are included in the new definition. I think the explanations given by the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) and by others in this area are adequate to demonstrate to the Parliament that what we are concerned about is in fact actual breaches of security-a legitimate security concern-rather than the sort of fairly vague legislation that we had before.

As far as increased ministerial control is concerned, which was expressed by Senator Durack and Senator Sir John Carrick, I point out also that the provisions in the legislation are in line with Mr Justice Hope's recommendation. I point out to honourable senators that greater ministerial control over ASIO carries greater ministerial accountability, and this is an essential aspect of the new accountability procedures. The function of proposed new section 8 is to increase ASIO's accountability by a proper strengthening of ministerial control. It firstly provides that in the performance of its functions under the Act the Director-General is subject to the directions of the Minister rather than the general directions as presently provided. The current provision that the Minister cannot override the opinion of the Director-General on the nature of the advice which should be given by ASIO is retained in this legislation.

The Act currently provides that the Minister cannot override the opinion of the Director-General on the question of whether the collection or communication of intelligence concerning a particular individual would be connected with security. This, too, is retained, subject to the very important qualification which recognises that there can be occasions when a conscientious and responsible Attorney-General should so act. If he does do so, he must do so in writing. He must also give a copy of any such direction to the Prime Minister. He also must give a copy of such directions to the Inspector-General of Security. It will be open to the Inspector-General to make inquiries in relation to that direction and it will be open to him to comment on the matter in his annual report, a copy of which is given to the Leader of the Opposition. The giving of directions, therefore, may be subject to additional ministerial scrutiny, independent examination and possibly notification to Parliament. Where possible to do so, guidelines must be laid before each House of the Parliament. Copies of the guidelines should be made available to the Leader of the Opposition and the Inspector-General. Unless inappropriate, guidelines will be examined also by the parliamentary joint committee. I believe the scrutiny to which the Minister's action may be subject provides a satisfactory check to the possibility of abuse. Any suggestion that the Attorney-General could make ASIO his own private police force is, I believe, a nonsensical suggestion and should be treated as such.

I think the checks and balances in this sort of proposal demonstrate the Government's concern that we should in fact be very careful in providing that balance between the democratic process and the need for security. I found it very difficult to understand Senator Sir John Carrick's assertion that what we should do is somehow find the best person to be the Director-General of ASIO-I certainly do not argue with that-and that, once we have found him, in our judgment we should let him do what he likes. The honourable senator argues that we should not have an Inspector-General with his staff of five looking at what he does, we should not have the Attorney-General questioning what he does and we should not have a parliamentary committee questioning what he does. Once we have decided that this is the right person, then apparently we all should accept that he can do absolutely what he likes. That is the impression I gained from Senator Sir John Carrick's proposal.

TALK.START.PARA: —What happens if he turns out to be a mole?

—That is a very real problem, but I am not going to go into that sort of nonsense tonight. Senator Harradine was rightly concerned about changes to the definitions, particularly in the area where I think he believed that those people who belonged to or infiltrated organisations which claimed through their actions or aims to be indulging only in lawful advocacy and lawful protest or dissent would be able to get into organisations which are hostile to Australia's well-being and, because they were in those organisations, would apparently be protected from the activities of ASIO. Proposed new section 17a of the legislation makes it clear that there is a basic right to engage in political activity but it states:

SPEECH.PARA: This Act shall not limit the right of persons to engage in lawful advocacy, protest or dissent and the exercise of that right shall not, by itself, be regarded as prejudicial to security, and the functions of the Organisation shall be construed accordingly.

I think most honourable senators would accept that the exercise of that basic right should not by itself be regarded as prejudicial to security, and I do not see that there should be much argument about that. Persons whose activities and intentions go further than engaging in lawful advocacy, protest or dissent could be subject to the scrutiny of ASIO if their conduct comes within the definition of security in the Act. The definition of security in the Act covers, as Senator Harradine pointed out, a fairly broad area. The scrutiny that such persons come under from ASIO will not be based on their participation in ordinary political activities, but on the activities and the intentions that lie behind such participation.

It is always difficult in this area not to swing one way or the other. I accept that it is always difficult not to make life impossible, as happens in the Soviet Union, as Senator Harradine pointed out, and in other areas, by stifling almost all dissent. Most of us do not want to go the other way to a system of anarchy where there are no such restraints. I would have thought that proposed new section 17a of the legislation and the definition of security, as it has been introduced into the legislation, would cover most situations.

The Government will be moving an amendment to the Australian Security Intelligence Organization Amendment Bill in the Committee stage. The amendment, which relates to the Security Appeals Tribunal and which I understand has been distributed, is an exercise in fine tuning rather than a substantive change to the legislation. The Tribunal's function is to review adverse or qualified security assessments furnished to government agencies by ASIO. An adverse assessment contains an opinion, an advice or information which is or could be prejudicial to the interests of the person involved, together with a recommendation from ASIO that relevant action, such as the granting of security clearance, be not taken. A qualified assessment contains opinion, advice or information but it does not contain a positive recommendation. The amendment proposed is to clarify the effect of the Tribunal's findings in respect to information contained in the statement of grounds upon which an adverse or qualified security assessment is based. The amendment is to make it clear that information is to be deleted by the tribunal from an assessment only if that information is incorrect, incorrectly represented, or could not reasonably be relevant to the requirements of security. The amendment does not affect the Tribunal's power to include in its findings an opinion on the weight to be given to any particular information. It compliments the new definition of qualified security assessment provided for in clause 19 (b). I hope honourable senators opposite have been given sufficient time to consider that amendment. I again thank honourable senators for their reasoned and reasonable contributions to this legislation, which I dare say will continue in the Committee stage.

This legislation was last amended in 1979. I believe it is not surprising that such legislation should need amending from time to time in the light of changing circumstances and changing community attitudes. It is important that we have security legislation which strikes the balance that so many honourable senators opposite have spoken about between the preservation of democracy, the preservation of civil liberties and the preservation of the security, both internal and external, of this country. For those reasons I can understand that we have differences of opinion and differences in attitude. I think the differences that have been expressed here, however vigorously they may have been expressed, have been pretty marginal. I would hope that debate on the legislation in the Committee stage will clarify a lot of the problems we have. I commend the legislation to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I seek the division of the question. There are three Bills and, to my surprise, they were put in one question. I ask that they be divided into three questions.

—Is it the wish of the Senate that the second reading votes on these Bills be taken separately? There being no objection, it is so ordered. The question now before the Chair is: That the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security Bill 1986 be now read a second time.
—The question now is: That the Australian Security Intelligence Organization Amendment Bill 1986 be now read a second time.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —The question now is: That the Intelligence and Security (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1986 be now read a second time.

INTERJECT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: INSPECTOR-GENERAL OF INTELLIGENCE AND SECURITY BILL 1986
Clauses 1 and 2-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition is proposing amendments to delete from this legislation the jurisdiction of the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security to perform his various functions in relation to several intelligence agencies to the extent to which those organisations exercise their human rights functions, which are widely defined. The first amendment deals with the definition of human rights. Amendments Nos 2, 3, 5 and 6 all deal with the same issue-they pick up the functions of the Inspector-General in relation to the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation, the Australian Secret Intelligence Service and the Defence Signals Directorate.
—Do you wish to move amendment No. 4 separately, Senator Durack?
—No, I am suggesting that I move amendments Nos 1, 2, 3, 5 and 6 together but not 4 as it deals with a different matter.

—It would be simpler if we took the remainder of the Bill as a whole if the amendments relate to different clauses. Is it the wish of the Committee that the Bill be taken as a whole. There being no objection, it is so ordered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 2, sub-clause 3(1), leave out the definition of ``human rights''.
(2) Page 3, clause 4, leave out paragraph (b).
(3) Page 5, sub-clause 8(1), leave out sub-paragraph (a) (v).
(5) Page 5, sub-clause 8(2), leave out sub-paragraph (a) (iv).
(6) Page 6, sub-clause 8(3), leave out sub-paragraph (b) (i).

A matter of concern to the Opposition relating to the office of the Inspector-General is the extraordinary width of his role. We have not voted against the Bill on the second reading as we believe that the recommendation of Mr Justice Hope that there should be such an Inspector-General is worth some trial. I will be moving an amendment later to oppose a sunset clause to the Inspector-General experiment. I will speak more generally about the office and its operation when I move the amendment. In a sense, the way these amendments are put is putting the cart before the horse. This is a minor aspect of his role; nevertheless, that is the way we have to proceed.

The Inspector-General is given, in relation to several of the intelligence agencies-particularly in relation to ASIO-a very wide role. He is not only given the task of ensuring, either at the request of the Minister or of his own motion, that the organisation complies with the laws, as according to the finding of Mr Justice Hope ASIO has so complied; the Inspector-General also is to keep an eye on ASIO to make sure that it continues to comply with the laws. Another of his functions is to inquire into any matter that relates to the propriety of particular activities of ASIO, which seems to be an extremely wide role. It is difficult enough to determine whether people are abiding by the laws of the Commonwealth and the States. However, to have to make a judgment about the propriety of particular activities of an intelligence organisation is a mind-boggling task. There is no definition of propriety in the Bill. Therefore, this is an extraordinarily wide power to give to the Inspector-General. I do not know how he will be able to cope with it. He also has the role of checking on the effectiveness and appropriateness of the procedures of ASIO in its determination of whether its officers are abiding by the law or by the proprieties of its functions.

Finally, the Inspector-General is given the role of determining whether any act or practice of ASIO is or may be inconsistent with or contrary to any human right, being an act or practice referred to the Inspector-General by the Human Rights Commission. It is to this role of the Inspector-General that these amendments are directed. We are proposing that they should be deleted. We do so for two reasons. There is an enormous, further widening of the Inspector-General's role. I suppose that we could have proposed an amendment to eliminate the function of checking on the propriety of activities of ASIO using the same argument. However, on top of that general, vague role and in addition to his other very wide functions-not necessarily vague but very onerous ones-there is the function of checking on the propriety of activities of ASIO and the role of investigating whether acts or practices of ASIO have been consistent with a human right.

Human rights are those defined by the Human Rights Commission which covers the ambit of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. The Human Rights Commission's definition of human rights is:

All rights and freedoms recognised in the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, the Declaration of the Rights of the Child, the Declaration on the Rights of Mentally Disabled Persons or as recognised in any international instrument to be an international instrument relating to human rights for the purpose of the Human Rights Act.

As the Government keeps reminding us, we had our longest debate ever in the Senate earlier this year on the Bill of Rights legislation and the implementation in Australian domestic law of the rights under the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. I do not need to emphasise again the extraordinarily wide ambit of the Covenant or the extraordinary vagueness and controversy about the meaning of sections of that Covenant and the extent to which they are qualified in one form or another within the Covenant by reference to concepts of law which are quite foreign to our legal system. Questions arise in relation to this matter which may well provide the greatest difficulties for the highest courts of the land to determine. We were very critical of the attempts by the Government to import into our domestic law these very vague and potentially extraordinarily wide concepts and their qualifications-concepts which are quite alien to our legal system.

In one fell swoop, added to all the other burdens of the Inspector-General we have an obligation to determine whether something referred to him by the Human Rights Commission-a body which incidentally will expire under a sunset clause on, I think, 10 December this year, although the Government has said that it will re-create the Commission in some form or another-is consistent with any human right. However, from what we can ascertain from the Senate Estimates committee which examined the estimates of the Attorney-General's Department, the Government does not yet have the foggiest notion as to what it will do about replacing the Human Rights Commission. The question arises also of whether the proposal to replace it will go through the Parliament. Certainly, the Opposition does not intend to support the re-creation of the existing Human Rights Commission, because of the discredited nature of that body. Yet it is that body's right to refer to the Inspector-General questions of whether ASIO has observed some act or practice contrary to the International Covenant to which I have referred which in this Bill we are being asked to acknowledge.

Apart from those mind-boggling tasks which may be referred to the Inspector-General and their inappropriateness, the very idea of having the actions of ASIO judged on the basis of whether or not they conform with a human right as defined in the Covenant is beside the point and self-contradictory. The very existence of a security and intelligence-gathering organisation and the powers that are properly given by this Parliament to that organisation are themselves major qualifications of the guaranteed civil and political rights set out in general terms in the Covenant. As I have said, the Covenant gives rise to great controversy as to the limitations it places on its generally stated rights. But one thing that is quite clear under the Covenant is that many qualifications may be made to them to make them work at all.

It is for this Parliament to decide on the sorts of qualifications to be made on general guarantees of human, civil or political rights which individuals would otherwise have. It has done so in the ASIO legislation. It is not for the organisation to have to be second-guessed or third-guessed by the Inspector-General as to whether or not its activities conform with any human right. It is a most incredible provision to appear in a Bill of this kind. It will clearly impose an enormous, further impossible burden on the Inspector-General. For those reasons the Opposition has moved this series of amendments which are designed to remove that burden from the Inspector-General.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government does not accept the amendments moved by Senator Durack. Senator Durack, I think, argued considerably during his long contribution that civil and human rights violations by intelligence and security organisations should not be investigated and that to ask the Inspector-General or anyone else to investigate them was an intolerable burden. It is the Government's view that it is not a question of whether such human rights violations should be investigated but a question of by whom they should be investigated. Currently they can be investigated by the Human Rights Commission. The legislation provides that the Inspector-General should look at the effectiveness and appropriateness of the procedures of ASIO relating to the legality or propriety of its activities-when they are referred by the Human Rights Commission certainly, but also the Inspector-General can do this off his own bat. The Government believes that such investigations should be carried out by the Inspector-General rather than by the Human Rights Commission as it is at the moment. We believe that the Inspector-General is far better placed to do so, being familiar with and having full access to the agency's activities, and he can then make a judgment about the legality and the propriety of such things. To suggest that the Parliament collectively can make a judgment about such propriety I think is drawing a very long bow indeed.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government recognises that intelligence and security activities sometime involve justi- fiable violations of human rights, as Senator Durack has said-this is inherent in the activities of intelligence and security organisations-but we do not think it is unreasonable that someone who can relatively independently at his, or I suppose her, discretion examine complaints when complaints are made about violations of human rights. Complaints in this area happen to have been very infrequent. I do not think, on past history in this area, that such complaints will place an onerous burden on the Inspector-General.

The legislation has been drafted on the basis that we have the current human rights legislation and certainly subsequent amendments will be required when the future of the human rights machinery has been settled by this Parliament, but we do not think it is unreasonable that some individual, in this case, should have a look at potential violations of human rights by our intelligence and security organisations. We do not think it is unreasonable that such a person should look at the propriety of intelligence agencies' actions in such circumstances, recognising, of course, that sometimes the activities of such organisations involve justifiable violations of human rights. It is for these reasons that we think the legislation is reasonable and we think the Opposition's amendments are unnecessary.

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendments moved by the Opposition are not supported by the Australian Democrats. In simple terms, what the Opposition spokesperson in the other place, Mr Spender, said when he said that the broad purpose of these agencies `invariably involves from time to time trespassing on human rights and freedoms' seems to us to be an adequate explanation as to why one would want to have an inspector-general with a capacity to involve himself in looking at those human freedoms and human rights that the Opposition has already accepted will invariably be violated from time to time. If the Opposition has accepted that that will occur, it seems to me that it should also accept that it is an inadequate role for the Inspector-General to look at such cases to see what might be able to be done in terms of those citizens whose human rights have been violated by these organisations and to determine whether some changes can be made to prevent such occurrences in the future. If this is not possible, it seems to me that, flowing from this, the people whose rights have been violated should in some way be compensated. Presumably, such recommendations should be able to flow from any Inspector-General's investigations of such activities. I really cannot understand the Opposition saying, on the one hand, that invariably human rights will be violated and, on the other hand, that nobody should do anything about it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —It really seems, particularly from Senator Macklin's comment but also from the comment of the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes), that the problem the Opposition has with such a provision in this kind of legislation is this: We are certainly saying that, inherent in the nature of a security service, limitations are placed upon what would otherwise be acknowledged as human rights. That is done by this Parliament. It sets down those limitations. It may in other pieces of legislation, or indeed in security legislation, give life, force and clarity to what it believes are civil and political rights. As I have pointed out in other debates in this chamber, we believe that giving effect to human rights should be determined by this Parliament in the legislation it passes, as we do in relation to racial discrimination and as we have done in recent years in relation to sex discrimination and manifold other matters in this area where we determine what those rights are.

SPEECH.PARA: We have had the experiment of an executive body, such as the Human Rights Commission, floundering around and trying to determine what human rights are in the minds of the officials of that organisation. We are extremely dissatisfied with the result, to the extent that we are opposed to the continuance of the Human Rights Commission.
