We believe that that has proved to be the wrong approach for the Parliament to take in handing over the determination of what are human rights, what these vague generalisations in the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights really mean. We believe that for such matters to be determined in that way has proved to be quite inappropriate. Thank goodness we in this chamber insisted on amendments to the Human Rights Commission legislation which put in a sunset clause, as a result of which the Human Rights Commission will disappear, we hope, on 10 December this year. Admittedly, at that stage there may be legislation to recreate it in some shape or form and our position in relation to that legislation will be determined when we see it. If it simply perpetuates the present discredited organisation we will certainly not be supporting it.

That is one objection that we have to this provision which I thought I had made clear before, but the basic objection we have to it is that here we are handing over the very function performed by the Human Rights Commission, which we believe has been a failure, to the Inspector-General of Security and Intelligence-a pioneering, herculean task for any person to have to perform. I have pointed out the extent of that task. As it is, without this problem being given to him, we believe that an absurdly wide further obligation and function is being placed upon him. We also believe that it is a quite inappropriate task for him to have to decide what is a human right in any case in accordance with the terms of the International Covenant. It is not as though we can just read from tablets of stone just what a human right is. The Inspector-General will have to work that out for himself. That is what we are objecting to and that is why we have moved the amendments.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Queensland National Party-Deafness Awareness Week-War Criminals in Australia-Queensland Premier: Defamation Action

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —The question now is:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today the National Party of Australia demonstrated its absolute contempt for the people of Queensland by launching a policy that completely ignores the reality of its performance in economic areas over the last three years. It is a speech which is big on rhetoric but very limited in detailing just what the National Party proposes for Queensland in the next three years if, heaven forbid, it is given the opportunity. The Queensland Premier has demonstrated yet again his complete inability to plan rationally. His speech is full of gross distortions and blatant inaccuracies, which I will detail in a few moments. He fondly imagines that Queenslanders will continue to accept the lies that are constantly put forward by his propaganda machine. He is so obsessed with his own particular-
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. Senator Reynolds used the word `lies' in regard to the Queensland Premier. I ask her to withdraw the word.
—I did not quite hear what the honourable senator said, but if she used the word `lies' in that respect I ask her to withdraw the word.

—I used the word `lies' in relation to the propaganda machine of the Queensland National Party, Mr President. I believe that the Queensland Premier has become so obsessed with what he believes is the truth in Queensland that he can no longer discriminate between fact and fiction. Let me give some examples. In his speech on employment he claims:

SPEECH.PARA: Queensland has left the rest of the nation far behind in the job creation stakes.

Let us examine that claim for fact. The Australian Bureau of Statistics labour force survey shows employment growth from September 1983 to September 1986 as follows: New South Wales, 8.6 per cent; South Australia, 9.4 per cent; and Queensland, 10.4 per cent. In fact there are five other States and Territories well ahead of Queensland. What about job creation figures? Who funds the community employment program that the Queensland Premier so conveniently forgets? How much has Queensland actually received from the wicked Federal Government that Premier Bjelke-Petersen is so fond of criticising? Up to 23 June 1986 Queensland had received $184m for the community employment program and this has generated over 19,000 jobs in Queensland alone. Yet still Queensland has one of the highest rates of unemployment. Figures released only today by the Australian Bureau of Statistics show that Queensland has an unemployment rate of 9.3 per cent compared with a national rate of 8.3 per cent. In the last 12 months Queensland has increased its unemployment levels from 8.7 per cent to 9.3 per cent. That scarcely seems to me hard evidence of the fanciful claim:
The National Party provides the most attractive climate in the nation to establish and expand and create new jobs.

The facts are that Queensland has had the worst unemployment record of any State over the past two years. Since October 1984 Queensland has had either the highest rate of unemployment or the second highest rate of unemployment in the country. National Party claims that Queensland's high level of unemployment is due to migration of young unemployed southerners to resort areas have been torpedoed by a special report soon to be released by the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe), but the same report shows very significant increases in youth unemployment recorded in Brisbane suburbs and rural areas in Queensland. Furthermore, the Queensland Government should not blame high unemployment in the State on transient young people. Let us look at another area, transport. The poor deluded Premier notes in his speech today:
Queensland's road system is the largest in the nation.

Thank goodness, he got something right, but his pretence that his Government is involved in the expenditure of more than $1.5 billion is utter fraud. The Federal Government has funded 60 per cent of Queensland road projects. Queensland has the poorest record of all the States in regard to road funding. The Premier says that he will provide thousands and thousands of jobs through the State with around half the budget being allocated to private enterprise and the remainder to sustain employment in local authority and main roads department work forces. But tenders have to be called. Clearly, neither the minority Queensland Government nor the Queensland Premier can be relied on to give the facts. They refuse to face the reality. They refuse to co-operate in recognising anything good that might have come out of Canberra since the Hawke Labor Government was elected. They are much more interested in financial rhetoric. Proposal for things such as space launching facilities on Cape York indicate a great degree of imagination but fail to solve the reality of Queensland's dismal economic performance and the problems that exist in regard to people services in that State.

Let me place on record a number of facts because I am much more interested in facts than is some of the rhetoric that is continually coming out of the Queensland Government. Of 18 key economic indicators released up to September 1986, Queensland had the worst result in four, the second worst in nine, and was below the national average in 14. Does that sound like the vision that the Queensland Premier continually referred to in his speech today? Queensland has the worst results in several areas. It had the lowest average weekly male earnings for May 1986. Queensland also has the second lowest average weekly earnings for females. Queensland had the highest fall in the number of new dwelling units approved for the three months to July. For the three months ended August 1986 Queensland had the highest drop in the number of new telephone connections and Queensland had the lowest job vacancy rate in August 1986. Queensland also had the second worst results in the following areas: The unemployment rate; the number of overtime hours per employee working overtime in August 1986; and household income per capita, which was $10,410. This was 9.8 per cent below the national average. The number of new residential buildings under construction in the March quarter 1986 had dropped by 1.5 per cent compared with the same period a year ago. The number of new residential buildings commenced in Queensland for the June quarter 1986 was 28.4 per cent below the figure for the same quarter a year previously. So the facts pile up one after the other. If only we could get facts out of the National Party Government in Queensland! (Quorum formed) I was detailing some facts about Queensland's dismal economic performance. The Queensland Premier constantly carps about Canberra. Anything that happens in Queensland must somehow be the fault of Bob Hawke or Canberra. He is absolutely paranoid about this Government. He has not accepted the wishes of the people on two occasions and he has made no secret of the fact--

TALK.START.PARA: —What two occasions were they?

—At the beginning of 1983, at the end of the election campaign, he disgraced himself when he was in Japan by speaking against the election of the Hawke Government and again in 1984 he was not prepared to accept the umpire's decision. But then I suppose if I were a minority Premier I would be a little bit sensitive about the majority vote of Bob Hawke. He says that any Queensland problem must be the fault of the Federal Government. But again let me give the Premier a lesson in cold hard facts. He does not seem to like facts. I do not know whether he reads them, whether he is advised about them or whether he just prefers to grandstand with his own particular and peculiar form of biases. The 1986-87 Federal Budget Papers show that recurrent grants to Queensland total $1,215.45 per head of population, in comparison with New South Wales, with $1,076.04 and Victoria with $1,081.56.
—How much in Tasmania?

—I am more concerned with Queensland. Queensland was actually favoured ahead of those two more populous States and received more than the six-State average of $1,173.75. All this talk of Bjelke-Petersen's that Queensland is badly off because of Canberra and that Queensland is discriminated against is nonsense and cannot be substantiated by anybody who is interested in facts. But we all know that the National Party, in particular the Leader of the National Party in Queensland, Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen, is simply not interested in facts. The National Party fondly imagines that it can fool the people of Queensland. This election is going to see the time that it can no longer fool the people of Queensland.

SPEECH.PARA: In housing, health, welfare and education the same blatant dishonesty applies. Today's policy claims $100m assistance in housing. I wonder where it came from. It is the result of Federal priorities; it is the result of Federal public policy commitment. The Premier even tries to tell us that people in other States are three times sicker than people in Queensland, simply because he and Mr Austin mischievously manipulate health care funding facts. But again Queensland will receive some $915 per head from the Commonwealth in 1986-87. This compares with $782 for New South Wales, $753 for Victoria and a State average of $859. Does that sound like discrimination against Queensland?

TALK.START.PARA: —No.

—I thank the Minister. Therefore, it is clear that Queensland has been generously funded by the Hawke Government. The Queensland Government has been unusually quiet recently about the total level of Federal funding to the State for its health services and it can only be assumed from this that the famous chapter 7 of the 1985 Commonwealth Grants Commission report-an independent arbitrator's report feared and banned from Queensland but which has at last found its way north over the border-has established beyond doubt that, except for a small Commonwealth contribution which has been paid to the State this financial year, the State of Queensland was not disadvantaged by Medicare. As well, the Federal Government has announced funding of more than $23m over the next three years for new equipment to upgrade considerably facilities in public hospitals throughout Queensland. Do not forget that it is very difficult for anybody interested in public hospitals in Queensland actually to get in to see what is happening in those hospitals, especially if one happens to be the Federal Minister for Health (Dr Blewett). He is not allowed into public hospitals in Queensland.
—Not if he does campaigning with the nurses. That is what he was there for.

—He was there to discuss a very important matter relating to nurse education and one assumes that that was important enough for the Federal Minister to be allowed into the Toowoomba Hospital. But the Queensland Health Minister is so sensitive about the failures of his Government that he banned the Federal Health Minister from the Queensland hospital system, just as Senator Susan Ryan, as Minister for Education, was banned from Queensland schools during the last federal election campaign. That is the kind of paranoia that exists in Queensland.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me conclude by referring to all those glaring omissions in the National Party's policy. We have pages and pages of the typical rhetoric from the National Party and from Bjelke-Petersen that we have all become used to, but let us see what has not been included. Let us see who has been missed out. First of all there is no mention of the National Party's need to lift its welfare spending, which is currently the lowest in Australia. Aged care, child care and the family services cannot rate highly in a speech delivered to concentrate on private enterprise. The Premier is very interested in co-operating with private enterprise but he and the Minister responsible for aged care services-Brian Austin, the Queensland Health Minister-will not even allow the Government to join a community consultative committee set up by the Federal Government to plan aged care services. Again, aged care service funding is lower in Queensland than in any other State with the possible exception of Tasmania. There is no mention of any of those service areas in the National Party's policy released today.

I seem to have crossed swords over women's policy with a couple of representatives of the National Party in the last six months. As we know, it is non-existent. Some 51 per cent of the population rate just four lines. I would like to read those four lines because we had better hang on to them. They state:
Your Government-
it is certainly not a government concerned with women-

has always recognised women as equal partners in Queensland's progress and has ensured increased participation in all fields of endeavour through policies that provide all Queenslanders with the opportunity to advance according to their merit.

That applies as long as they are closely associated with the National Party and preferably paid up members of the Bjelke-Petersen Trust Fund. There is no recognition in those four lines, no policy commitment, no legislation, and no reference to a women's advisory committee, a toll free telephone service, nurse education, et cetera. It is the only State-again with the exception of Tasmania-not to have a women's policy and not to be interested in providing services to 51 per cent of the population. Obviously, the women of Queensland have no reason to vote for such an arrogant regime of old men.

Let us now look at another significant group that has been overlooked in the National Party's policy. Queensland has approximately 50,000 Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders. They do not even rate a mention in the National Party policy. They do not exist as far as the Premier is concerned.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are equal citizens with everyone else.
—If they are equal, I am not quite sure why it is good enough to pick out business enterprises throughout the policy and not to mention Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders.
—We even had one of them as a candidate. That is what we think of Islanders and Aboriginals. We ask them even to stand for us.
—You even do, do you?
—Yes. We have Getano Lui, in Cook, and he will take the seat.
—Order! Senator Boswell, you have been continually interjecting and I ask you to cease.

—We all know that the Queensland Premier has a reputation as a racist-an international reputation, unfortunately for this country-but I would have thought that even he and wiser heads, if they exist in the National Party, would be--

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I think I heard the honourable senator say that she thought the Premier had a reputation as a racist. I believe that that breaches the terms of standing order 418 and I ask that appropriate action be taken.

—If Senator Reynolds used the term `racist' in respect of the Queensland Premier, his being a member of the Queensland Parliament, under standing order 418 I ask Senator Reynolds to withdraw that remark.

—I withdraw that remark in deference to you, Mr President. I was saying that I am surprised that even the National Party would not be prepared to announce policies for 50,000 Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders in the lead up to the Queensland election. However, it is not only women, Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders who do not rate a mention, or who rate very little mention, in the National Party's policy; there are about 200,000 migrants in Queensland and again there was no reference to migrant policy. In the last 12 months or more I have had a considerable number of representations from representatives of the Queensland migrant community who are very concerned about the lack of services, particularly interpreting services, which are so important.
—It is a Federal matter.

—It is a Federal matter-I see. Perhaps I can send Senator Sheil some details of what other States are doing in regard to migrant services. It might help him catch up with the reality of joint State and Federal co-operation in this regard. Obviously, the National Party's policy is an anti-people policy. The only people who rate as far as the National Party is concerned are those who are close to the National Party ranks and who have money and influence. It is a dishonest policy and it relies on fear and smear tactics. Clearly, this minority State Government is too frightened to run its campaign on State issues. Its own performance is so impossible that it is not prepared to run on State issues; it has to run a State election on Federal issues and campaigns against the Hawke Labor Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Time is running out for those who have led this corrupt regime, even for the Premier who apparently has other plans for after 1 November. I fail to understand how a Premier who is running for another term in Queensland and who launched a policy today with great pomp, ceremony and, I believe, even tinsel can be talking to leading members of the right wing business community about how he will move to Canberra. He would take things over here and change the whole direction of Australia's traditions in regard to the way of life that we have accepted over many years. Obviously, even the Queensland Premier has some doubts about whether he will be successful on 1 November. Otherwise, why would he be talking to business communities about taking over here? Clearly, everything about the policy and everything that has been said by the Premier today and on previous occasions is not reliable and, in many instances, is blatantly fraudulent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last week was Deafness Awareness Week. Perhaps deafness is one of the most difficult handicaps. In many respects that may be hard to justify when one thinks of what people have to suffer. However, a person who suffers from deafness frequently looks to be a totally unhandicapped person in every other respect, and for that reason the handicap he or she suffers by being profoundly deaf makes life particularly difficult. Other people when dealing with the deaf tend not to know their handicap. They overlook it and expect from them a standard to which they are not able to adhere. There are 900,000 profoundly deaf people in this country. Twenty thousand have been born that way and many become deaf during their lifetime. There are a number of reasons for this. Deafness sometimes occurs through industrial accidents, many cases are caused through leisure activities and some people acquire deafness through age.

SPEECH.PARA: The importance of Deafness Awareness Week is to let people know that a number of things can be done about the problem. It is needed to highlight the fact that this is the case and to encourage people to get help rather than to let the problem get worse after they have become aware that helpful aids are available. The Deafness Council does a great deal to promote the problems of deafness, and Deafness Awareness Week is one of the activities it organises. I think Deafness Awareness Week was particularly successful in Canberra, where films were shown in libraries and a number of other activities were held. One day during the week Capital 7 had the news signed by a person skilled in sign language. It is not easy to present such a program. It would be nice if it could be done every night, but that is not yet the case. I think it was appreciated that Capital 7 did this.

There was considerable publicity for the week in various media outlets in the Australian Capital Territory. It needs to go on for more than just one week a year for people to become aware of what can be achieved. It is necessary to have telephones with the right sort of facilities situated where deaf people are able to use them. A number of aids can be made available reasonably simply in the community if the need is known. There was an article in the Canberra Times on 29 September entitled `My son Brendan, deaf since birth'. The parent of the child, who wrote the article, concludes by saying:

Hopefully, Deafness Awareness Week can stimulate a real interest in the effects of deafness on children and thereby generate the changes necessary to ensure children such as Brendan have only one disability, not many, caused by the inability to hear sounds clearly.

There is a significant problem in regard to education for people who have a high degree of deafness. One of the difficulties is that there are only four people in Canberra who are qualified to translate in sign language. This is not a large number of interpreters to deal with police or court situations. There is less assistance available in organisations such as the Public Service than one would hope. The publicity generated by Deafness Awareness Week hopefully will address some of these problems. A number of retired people could take this on, in a sense as a hobby but in a way filling a very real purpose. If they were able to learn sign language they could assist considerably in coaching deaf children with their education, assisting in other ways and interpreting if they acquired the relevant skills. I think there are many in the community who, if they were aware of what they could contribute in this way, could provide very valuable assistance. I commend the local Council for what is achieved last week. I hope that we will all continue to be aware of what deafness and profound deafness mean to so many people and not forget the difficulties that they have in living.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Monday this week the Australian newspaper ran as its lead story an item which used certain documents dating from 1951 which seemed to reveal a lack of enthusiasm on the part of certain civil servants in the pursuit of alleged war criminals in this country. The documents came from me. I, in turn, got them from the Australian Archives, as anyone can do. Indeed, I am getting more documents every day. But as a result of that story an item was run on the AM program at 8 o'clock. I have only today had a chance to look at the transcript of that AM program.
—I heard you on it.

—Yes. Now I have looked at the transcript, I want to be quite certain that no injustice is done to anyone. In particular I am concerned that some listeners may have gained a slightly unfair view of the position of the then Colonel Charles Spry, now Sir Charles Spry, in one of the documents which he provided to the Government at that time. What I desire to do, therefore, is put the documents themselves into the record to allow people to make their own judgment about the role of the Commonwealth Public Service at that time.

SPEECH.PARA: I am concerned that the documents contain certain allegations against two named persons. To be fair, I have not named the people publicly, nor has the Press, because they are only allegations and it would not be fair to name the people. I will not name them now. Indeed, in seeking to incorporate the documents in the record, I have expunged the names of the persons wherever they appear. There are several documents. The first is dated 4 June 1951. It is an internal minute in the Department of External Affairs marked `for the Secretary' and headed `Yugoslav ``War Criminals'' in Australia'. It sets out the problems which faced the Secretary in the light of certain requests from the Yugoslav Government. I seek leave to have that document, with the names of the two persons expunged, incorporated in Hansard.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the document been shown to the Minister?
—I have mentioned it to Senator Grimes.
—I would rather you left the names in as well. It is your choice to take them out.
—The documents can be obtained from the Records Office--
—Order! Is leave granted for the incorporation of the document in Hansard with the names expunged?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Walsh

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes.

INTERJECT.PARA: The Yugoslav Consulate-General has asked that the Australian authorities should deliver to the Yugoslav Government two Yugoslav displaced persons now resident in Australia named . . . and . . . , who apparently have been named as war criminals by a Yugoslav Federal Commission. The Yugoslav Note is attached.

2. . . . is at present Editor of the Perth migrant newspaper ``Sloga'', which is allegedly hostile to the present Yugoslav Government. . . . is stated to be associated with . . . on ``Sloga''. The political motive behind the Yugoslav request is thus quite apparent.

3. The evidence advanced against . . . is particularly weak and is unsubstantiated. A rather better prima facie case has been made out against . . ., but of course it should not be accepted as true without verification. There does not appear to be any international agreement binding on Australia to surrender such persons.

4. Even if investigation discloses that there is some truth in the Consulate-General's allegations, it does not appear desirable to accede to its request for the men's extradition. Similar requests have been made to the United Kingdom Government, but almost all have been refused on the grounds that it is time to bring to an end the punishment of minor war criminals. The few persons handed over to the Yugoslav Government were those who ``by the nature of their official positions, rendered such signal service to the enemy that it would be difficult, if not impossible to justify a refusal to consider surrendering them''. . . . and . . . do not appear to be in this category.

5. It is recommended however that a copy of the Note should be referred to Immigration and the Security Service for a report, for it seems desirable to ascertain the facts of the matter and to inform these agencies that this request has been made. A report might also be obtained from the British Embassy in Belgrade, if this is practicable for it, upon the findings of the relevant War Crimes Commission and the validity of its decisions.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The second document, in response to the document just incorporated, dated 11 July 1951, is from the Director-General of Security. It was, at that time, marked `secret' but has now been released under the normal provisions. It is a letter from the then Colonel Spry which was the subject of some comment in the Australian article. Again, the names of the two people have been expunged. I seek leave to have that letter incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
COMMONWEALTH OF AUSTRALIA
ATTORNEY-GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT,
D BRANCH,
BOX 5219 BB, G.P.O.,
MELBOURNE
11th July, 1951.
TELEGRAMS:
`AUSTERITY, MELBOURNE'
SECRET
The Secretary,
Department of External Affairs,
CANBERRA. A.C.T.
Dear Mr North,

With reference to your memorandum 1550/20 of 13th June, 1951, seeking information in connection with the note from the Yugoslav Consulate General requesting return of . . . and . . . to Yugoslavia for trial as War Criminals, I am forwarding the attached report compiled by my officers.

While this matter appears to be an extension of Yugoslav internal politics, it must be stated these two men represent a body of Yugoslavs who cause infinitely less trouble to this organisation than the great body of their fellow immigrants. They are unceasing in their campaign against Communism and can and do assist A.S.I.O. to the limit of their ability.
It would be appreciated if I could be informed in due course of the nature of your reply to the Yugoslav Consulate General.
Yours sincerely,
Colonel Spry
Director-General of Security

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The final document is a minute in the Department of External Affairs to the Secretary, dated 14 September 1951, which brings together the advice received from various officers regarding the request by the Yugoslav Consulate. Again, the names of the two people have been expunged. I seek leave to incorporate the minute in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
EXTERNAL AFFAIRS
For the Secretary:

You will recall from a minute of the 13th June that the Yugoslav Consulate-General in Sydney requested that two migrants, former displaced persons now in Australia, be delivered to the Yugoslav authorities as war criminals for trial before a Yugoslav court. The two persons in question are named . . . and . . . .

Copies of the Yugoslav note in question were passed to the Department of Immigration and the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation and also to the Australian External Affairs Officer in London for comment.

The Department of Immigration has provided all the information known to it on these two persons and has confirmed that both men would have been security checked in Europe before emigration. The particulars supplied by the Department of Immigration mainly relate to the life histories of these persons and their families, and throw no light on the present request. The Department of Immigration has been endeavouring to obtain any further information which might be available from Europe but so far has not been able to obtain anything which might be relevant.
The Australian Security Intelligence Organisation has pointed out that in Western Australia where the two persons in question are now residing, the Yugoslav community is divided into three sections:
(1) Royalists (a minority),
(2) supporters of the Tito regime,
(3) anti-Tito and pro-Soviet supporters (the dominant group).

The Director-General of Security goes on to say that these two men represent a body of Yugoslavs who cause infinitely less trouble to his Service than the great body of their fellow migrants. They are unceasing in their campaign against communism and can and do assist A.S.I.O to the limit of their ability.

The United Kingdom Government some years ago surrendered to the Yugoslav Government, after careful examination of all the charges, 58 persons. It has been stated in the House of Commons in 1948 that the United Kingdom Government would also be prepared to return 19 other Yugoslavs if they were found on United Kingdom territory. They would, however, be disinclined now to hand over any persons other than the 19 specified lest the charge should have a political rather than a criminal basis. It was also expressed in the House of Commons that it was considered by the United Kingdom Government that there must be some time limit during which war crimes charges could be pressed. This last argument would, however, perhaps be less appropriate in the case of the Australian Government which has only recently concluded its trials of Japanese war criminals.

It seems clear that the present approach stems very largely from political motives, in view of the activities of these persons in connection with the anti-Tito newspaper ``SLOGA'' with which the both are connected.

There is the further point as to how the persons in question could be handed over if it were desired to do so. The Yugoslav note in question claims that the persons should be handed over pursuant to the 1943 Allied Declaration on Atrocities which was made in Moscow on the 30th October, 1943, with the Big Three acting for the other allies. This Declaration has been examined, however, and appears only to relate to ``German officers and men and members of the Nazi Party''. The fact that it purported to relate only to Germans seems clear from the title-``A Declaration on German Atrocities''. There certainly is no possibility of arbitrarily arresting persons within the jurisdiction, whether they be Australian citizens or aliens. In the case of these two persons the machinery deportation perhaps could be invoked if it were desired to remove them and the only other alternative would be for a formal request to be made through the normal channels for their extradition. A list of extraditable crimes is set out in the 1900 Extradition Treaty with Yugoslavia which is still in force, but obviously at that time war crimes were never thought of and it seems fairly safe to say that the machinery of extradition could not be relied on.

For all the reasons outlined above it would seem that the Yugoslav request should not be met, and unless a long explanation is to be given to the Yugoslav Consul-General, it would seem preferable that a short reply should be sent. A draft suggested reply is attached for your consideration and signature if approved.
Consular and Protocol,
AHB/PF
14th September, 1951.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. It is now possible for anyone who may be concerned to understand what the article in the Australian newspaper was about to look at the Hansard record and make his own judgment. While I was not particularly happy with the way that the requests from the Yugoslav Consulate were dealt with, I want people to be able to make up their own mind on a perusal of the documents.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sheil Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not rise to rebut the confused and vitriolic invective of that knocker from the north, Senator Reynolds. If she wants to conduct a State election campaign in the Senate late at night, I am willing for her to do so. I am not here to talk about her. I am concerned about the threat issued today in another place by the Minister who is noted for his association with Paddington bears that he will raise the issue of the Queensland Premier's settlement with Mr Bond every day from now until the Queensland State election in the hope of creating suspicions that political favours have been shown, that there have been political kickbacks or other political arrangements, which I think is a typical Labor tactic. It has been used here today by the Minister for the Lack of Finance, Senator Walsh, who is in the chamber at the moment.

SPEECH.PARA: Labor members hurl personal abuse and accusation in the hope that some of it will stick like mud and react to their advantage. They should consider a little of the old philosophy of Confucius, who said that he who slings mud always lose ground. I think that that will show up in their actions. All their accusations are not standing up to scrutiny. The Premier and the Queensland Government have an unbeatable record with their decentralised and prosperous State. An election is coming up and people will get their chance to show their appreciation of the Government-or not, if they are not appreciative-and that is despite the holding back of Federal funds from Queensland. Obviously, neither the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) nor the Special Minister of State (Mr Young) are conscious of the investigative reporting in the Courier-Mail of 27 September by a reporter who is not noted for his support of the Queensland National Party or the Premier. He gave a very accurate and truthful report of the whole case of the Bond-Bjelke-Petersen settlement. In fact, I think the Labor Leader in Queensland thought that he was going to score a big win by using this incident. He threw out the accusations, hoping that they would create suspicions about the Queensland Premier, but it looks as though he has dropped the pass on the way. In fact, when the settlement was first suggested, I do not think the Queensland Premier thought that it was ever going to cause any political trouble at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was only because of the previous owner.

—That is right. This matter arose only because when Mr Bond bought the television station he bought the court case with it. People talk about the Queensland Premier suffering from a rash of writs. This one was the very first writ that he issued. He warned the television station that if it went ahead and published this allegation that he had used his position as Queensland Premier when he was overseas to raise money to finance his son he would sue. He even told the station this an hour before the show went to air.
—He did?

—He did. This is reported in the newspaper article to which I referred. The show still went to air and so he sued the station. The case went on for a couple of years. The Channel 9 show Today Tonight, which is now defunct, probably because of this action, put the program to air and so the station got the writ. That writ was current when Mr Bond bought the station, so the matter had to be settled.
—So there is no connection between the two?

—There is no connection between the two. There was an out of court settlement. The Bond Corporation documents, which were made public a couple of days after that, showed no evidence of political favours, kick-backs or arrangements favourable to either party. They are public documents which are being published now.
—Who said that?
—They were made public by the court. They show that there is no evidence-
—But who said it?

—The article is by Peter Morley in the Courier-Mail of that day. The Premier and Mr Bond had to go ahead and come to some arrangement about the settlement. The legal advice to Mr Bond was that the Premier had a case and the damages were variously estimated as being between $75,000 and $300,000. This was on the advice of Tom Hughes, QC.
—A hired gun; and ex-Liberal Party Minister.

—The Minister would not be game to say that outside this place. So in an ordinary business arrangement, rather than have court costs, legal costs and all the other costs, they settled the case. There is no question of there being any of the favours, kick-backs or other political arrangements that have been suggested by the Government. As part of the settlement, it is up to Mr Bond to release the figure, whatever it was. Even if he does, what will it prove? It will prove absolutely nothing.

SPEECH.PARA: It might be interesting to compare the size of the settlement with other out-of-court settlements that have been made to other state politicians. The Minister for Finance, who is in the chamber tonight, always associates these matters with the loan that was given to Mr Michael Behan on ministerial discretion, but he fails to say that in order to qualify for that ministerial discretion one has to be refused loans from every other source before the Minister can use his discretion. Why does the Minister have discretion? The discretion is written into the legislation. In any case, such loans have to be paid back, unlike the deal in Western Australia where the Minister's State Government has paid an enormous amount of money for assets that are overvalued. The Minister does not want to know anything about that. He says: `Oh, that is State money and they can do with it whatever they want'. Because Mr Behan got national disaster relief money the minister thinks that the Federal Government should say a lot about it. However, he says nothing about the Western Australian money.

Similarly, the Minister always associates such matters with John Bjelke-Petersen, the son of the Premier of Queensland. He says: `Ah, they have built a bitumen road right outside his house. They have built a dam for him and they have built a bridge for him'. It is curious that one of his reporter friends from the Sydney Morning Herald got bogged on the road outside John Bjelke-Petersen's house. It is a dirt road. There is no bitumen road. John Bjelke-Petersen went out in his tractor and pulled him out of the bog, but the reporter still went back and said there was a big bitumen road outside his house. The dam that the Minister talks about is 35 miles from John Bjelke-Petersen's house. He gets no water from it. He does not need water from it because he happens to have sufficient rainfall where he is. I think the bridge is 100 miles from his place. It is on a road that does not even service his place. These are the kinds of innuendos that some politicians spring out in the hope that some of the mud will stick. It is suggested that there has been political patronage and favouritism shown by the Premier to his family. That is just not so.

If politicians want to play this sort of game, they must expect reaction in a couple of ways. I have heard of Mr Uren boasting about his out of court settlements. I believe he has got three houses. He names them after the companies he has sued and got the money off them. He calls one house the Sydney Morning Herald and another house the Age. I do not know what the other one is called. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has also had out of court settlements. He has a swimming pool which he calls the Murdoch swimming pool, which he got from an out of court settlement. He has a tennis court at his Sandringham home which he calls the Packer tennis court, which he got from out of court settlements. There are probably a lot of other settlements that have been made that could qualify in a dirt slinging match if people want to have it. I have heard that Mr Keating has got a house on Lake Como. Why do they want to have these sorts of fights? They are completely out of all political principle.

I hope that by what I have said tonight, I can show that the argument about the Bjelke-Petersen-Bond settlement has no undertones of a political nature. Young John Bjelke-Petersen's house is disconnected from any accusations of a road, a dam or a bridge. If the Minister in the other place and the Minister here want to go on with it, there are probably a lot of other areas that could well do with closer scrutiny.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not think that I would ever come to the support of the Bond Corporation Ltd, but I feel it is necessary to do so tonight. The truth of the matter raised by Senator Sheil is that the Bond Corporation was brought under considerable pressure by the Premier of Queensland to come to a settlement. In fact, the pressure was such that one could almost use the word-I hesitate to use it in this place-blackmail. What in effect happened was that the Bond Corporation bought the television station to which Senator Sheil referred and that television station was subject to a writ by the Premier of Queensland for $1m.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bond Corporation had a considerable number of investments in Queensland. One of the investments was in the television station concerned. The other investments were in the company which brews XXXX and the Bond Corporation had decided, for some reason or other, to become active in the Queensland economy and to invest a considerable amount of money. The Premier of Queensland was so obsessed by his desire to acquire a considerable amount of money that all he could refer to in any discussion between the Bond Corporation and himself was the $1m demand that he had upon this particular television station arising from some idle comment which, in normal circumstances, may have attracted a payment of some $10,000 to $20,000, perhaps even $30,000.

My information is that the Bond Corporation on a number of occasions endeavoured to discuss the matter with the Premier of Queensland, and it said to him: `Look, we have a stake in Queensland. We bought a television station and we purchased a very successful brewing company and we want to talk to you about those investments'. The response from the Premier was this: `I am not interested in all that, I am not interested in what you are doing in Queensland; what I am interested in is the sum of $1m which you owe me. That is all I am interested in'. The $1m which the Premier demanded from this television station was all that he was interested in. The Bond Corporation came to the commercial conclusion that in order to protect its investments in Queensland it had to come to an arrangement with the Queensland Premier. The insurance company gave the Bond Corporation the advice that the Premier was not worth $30,000 let alone $1m and it said to the Bond Corporation: `Go and pay, but we are not paying. If you pay, it is your responsibility.' The Bond Corporation, in order to protect its interests in Queensland, paid the money, $400,000 in settlement of a $1m claim, to the Premier, in spite of the advice from the insurance company. That smacks of blackmail by the Premier of Queensland against the Bond Corporation. Nothing could be more despicable than that sort of action by a Premier of a State, because he was in a position to prejudice the investments of the Bond Corporation in Queensland.

The person Senator Sheil protects is not worthy of protection. Let me tell the honourable senator of another incident in which the Premier of Queensland was involved. Any sense of outrage in Queensland should have destroyed the Premier. I refer to the previous exposition of the amoral attitude of the Premier. At a liquidation sale he bought an oil rig and, having bought it, he then endeavoured to dispose of it. He approached a company which had contracts with the Queensland Government and said: `I have an oil rig for disposal. I would like you to buy it.' The engineer of that company said, `We have no requirement for it' and the Premier said: `Well, I have an oil rig and I think you want to have a requirement'. The engineer persisted and said that there was no requirement, and he lost his job. A small man lost his job because he came into conflict with the Premier of Queensland. Eventually that company did not buy the rig but leased it.

If the Queensland media was prepared to expose that story, on that issue alone the Premier would have gone down. But such is the situation in Queensland that the Premier is protected in every amoral position he takes. To my mind that single incident of the engineer losing his job because he resisted the pressure of the Premier of Queensland to have his company purchase an item which it did not require demonstrates the pattern of behaviour of the Queensland Premier. When Senator Sheil endeavours to protect him in this controversy concerning $400,000, he is really defending the indefensible, because the Premier of Queensland could be accused of blackmail, intimidation and using his powers as Premier of Queensland to extort.

TALK.START.PARA: —Bond's deposition confirms that.

—Exactly. The Premier could be accused of using his power to extort $400,000 from the Bond Corporation in spite of the advice that the Bond Corporation received from its insurers which said, in effect: `If you pay, we do not pay'. That is the situation. If the honourable senator wants to try to defend the Premier of Queensland he must realise that the truth will come out. The Premier of Queensland in a certain situation shows himself to be insupportable, exposed as a person who ought not to be the Premier of Queensland.
—Say it outside.

—It is not a matter of saying it outside. The honourable senator knows as well as I do what would happen if I was to move out of this House and say these things, where the privilege to expose roguery is given to me. What would the Premier do? He would issue a writ. He would put his millions which he has extorted from others--
—Order! The honourable senator cannot use that expression in respect of a member of another Parliament.

—I am sorry, I will replace that word. He would put the power of the millions that he has extracted from others against the miserable holdings I have. I would be defenceless in that sort of situation. Senator Sheil talks to me about going outside.
—Yes, if it is true, go outside and say it.

—The honourable senator should not anger me with that sort of defence of the Premier of Queensland, because I seldom get up in this place and use angry terms against people. But Senator Sheil defends the Premier of Queensland in this sort of situation in which he virtually extracted-since I cannot use the word `extorted'-$400,000 from the Bond Corporation by intimidating it and saying: `I am only interested, not in your investments in Queensland, but the $1m which you owe me'. That is virtually what he was saying and that is what the Bond Corporation is revealing before the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. I think that the Premier has to stand exposed by what is occurring at present.
—He had the case against the television mob. Mr Bond bought that. He wanted his money for the defamation.
—Yes. Well, by his avarice will he suffer; by his avarice he has been exposed; by his avarice he will be defeated.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 11.28 p.m.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 1 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Federal Government noted the action of the Government of New South Wales, which, as reported in the Sydney Morning Herald of 1 May 1986, has moved to ban the sale of household packs of organochlorine pesticides to the general public because they are considered to be a potential health hazard if used incorrectly.
(2) What are the brand names of the chemical products to be subjected to the proposed ban.
(3) Are any of the chemical components contained in them used in crop spraying.
(4) Has there been any evidence discovered in New South Wales of contamination caused to milk or any agricultural produce.

(5) What action has been taken or is proposed by the Federal Government in conjunction with all Australian States to monitor all pesticide products on a national basis with a view to banning the sale and use of any found to be dangerous to health.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. The National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) recently reviewed toxicology data on a number of organochlorine pesticides. The views of NHMRC were that further restrictions on the availability of these pesticides were justified. This information was relayed to the States and Territories for implementation where appropriate. The New South Wales action is in part a result of the advice provided by the NHMRC.
(2) Brand names vary from time to time but the most recent listing of affected products registered in New South Wales is listed below.

(3) Apart from the use of dieldrin for the control of White Fringed weevil larvae and Apple Root weevil larvae in fruit tree nursery stock and non-bearing fruit trees, the chemical components mentioned in the proposed ban are not used in crop spraying in New South Wales. The above use requires a special permit to be obtained by the user from the New South Wales authorities.

(4) In view of the persistence and previous widespread use of these compounds one would expect, from time to time, possible contamination of agricultural produce. All reports are investigated. There have been recent reports of the detection of pesticide residues in milk which are being followed up by New South Wales authorities. Stock foods are also being monitored as a possible source of the contamination.

(5) Pesticide residues in food are monitored nationally in the Marked Basket (Noxious Substances) Survey conducted by the National Health & Medical Research Council and in the National Residue Survey conducted by the Department of Primary Industry. These Surveys have demonstrated that the Australian public is not exposed to potentially hazardous levels of pesticides through pesticide residues in foods.
